The flood of Florence on August 13, 1547, was one of the most disastrous floods of the Arno, especially due to the damage caused to the Santa Croce district, as reported by some sources of the time.

According to many chroniclers of the time - including Giovan Battista Adriani, historian of Cosimo de’ Medici - the flood was caused by the intense rainfall that began on the evening of August 12, 1547, over the city of Florence, the entire Mugello area, and the mountains of La Verna in the province of Arezzo. The rivers in the Mugello area overflowed, particularly the Sieve, flooding the entire town of Pontassieve and destroying its bridge and the Franciscan convent. The water level rose to a height of forty braccia, about twenty-three meters above the riverbed, effectively flooding all the nearby fields and carrying with it tree trunks and much debris in the current. At the gates of Florence, at the confluence with the Sieve, which had flooded the Mugello area, the level of the Arno River quickly rose to a high level: the plain of San Salvi was submerged by about ten braccia (almost six meters), and the water reached the city center, passing through Porta alla Croce at one in the afternoon on August 13, 1547. The overflow of the Arno caused the flooding of Piazza Santa Croce, so much so that the river level rose to cover the church steps. Subsequently, the waters reached the Canto de’ Pazzi, passing through Piazza di San Pier Maggiore to Borgo Pinti and finally flooding the current areas of Santa Trinita, Borgo Ognissanti, and reaching San Niccolò. Between the Rubaconte Bridge, now Ponte alle Grazie, and Ponte Vecchio, the flood caused damage to two hundred and fifty braccia of riverbank. The river also invaded Piazza del Grano and the nearby Piazza della Signoria, submerging the offices of the Gabella del Sale and the Contracts Office, which were then located on the lower floor of Palazzo Vecchio. According to Giovan Battista Adriani, the victims in the Mugello area were about one hundred, and more than sixty bodies were found on the riverbanks, while Bernardo Segni estimated the damages at three hundred thousand scudi.

The inscriptions that commemorate this flood are located in the center of the city of Florence, particularly in the Santa Croce area, which is the most prone to the river's overflows. One inscription is located at the corner of Via delle Casine and Via Ghibellina, in what was already Via del Renaio no. 68, indicating the level of the Arno River at about two meters in height. Another inscription, however, is found on a stone at the corner of Piazza Santa Croce on the so-called House of the Flood.

Article_Name: Alluvione della provincia di Savona del 22 settembre 1992

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Province of Savona on September 22, 1992
Whole_Text.content: The flood in the province of Savona on September 22, 1992, occurred following very heavy rainfall in the province, caused by an Atlantic disturbance that affected the entire central-northern part of Italy, hitting Liguria with particular force. This resulted in the overflow of the Quiliano, Quazzola, Letimbro, Segno, Lavanestro, and Bormida watercourses. The disaster caused the death of 3 people. On September 27, 1992, another flood occurred in Genoa, causing 2 deaths in the Sturla district.

After two days and one night of uninterrupted rainfall, a series of torrents of water rushed towards the sea at high speed, carrying with them tons of material that struck the bridge piers with incredible force or bypassed them, overflowing the masonry embankments, invading provincial roads in many places, and effectively blocking road traffic. In fact, in the inland areas upstream of Savona, an impressive amount of rainfall formed rivulets, small streams, brooks, and waterfalls that became increasingly impetuous and violent as they descended from the heights to the main watercourses, which quickly flowed towards the coast, dragging along all sorts of debris, medium and large trees, vegetation, construction waste, caravans, large tanks, and various refuse. All this material caused a series of blockages along the watercourses descending towards the sea. The Letimbro stream crosses Savona, passing under about ten bridges and walkways, and receives water from 22 minor tributaries, plus one very significant one, the Lavanestro. The same dangerous situation arises for the Quiliano stream, which receives two tributaries, one of which is the Quazzola, and runs for about 15 kilometers in the valley of the same name to Zinola, where it flows into the open sea. A similar situation occurs in Altare, next to which flows the Bormida.

Following heavy rainfall in the municipality, it was the Quazzola stream, a tributary of the Quiliano, that first overflowed. Subsequently, the Quiliano also flooded, causing the collapse of some bridges, walkways, and pylons. The streets quickly turned into raging torrents, mud overflowed completely flooding shops, homes, and basements, and cars were swept away by the fury of the water.

In Savona, the Letimbro stream overflowed, causing the structural collapse of several bridges and the breaking of the Gian Carlo Ruffino Suspension Bridge. In Montemoro, on the hills behind Savona, Silvana Bertani, a 63-year-old woman, perished in the collapse of the roof of her home during the night while she was sleeping with her husband Ermanno, who was seriously injured.

When the Quiliano overflowed, its waters burst into a house in the locality of Murate. Rosa Perugino, 23 years old and three months pregnant, and her 3-year-old daughter Anna Maria lost their lives. Their bodies were carried for kilometers by the fury of the current towards the sea. The woman's body was found off the coast of Loano. In the locality of Murate, the Strada Statale 1 Via Aurelia was also flooded, and in the side street Via Leopardi, the external areas of the Zinox plant and the Peugeot car dealership were inundated.

No victims, but millions and millions of old lire in damages. The Val Bormida was also hit hard, especially Altare and Ferrania suffered significant damage. The glass city was devastated by that event, with the historic center invaded by mud, streets turned into torrents, cars piled up by the fury of the water, shops and basements completely flooded, as seen in the images archived by the then broadcaster TeleValBormida. The railway station was closed, connections interrupted and ensured only by the Savona-Turin highway. In Cadibona (Quiliano), a house remained balanced on the hill for years. The flood also hit the Cairnese district, and the Ferrania plant was evacuated in the early afternoon. In Altare, which was left without electricity for hours, it took years to restore the situation, and one of the most significant interventions at the end of the last millennium was the construction of a diversion channel on Via Gramsci to manage underground waters. A true catastrophe, albeit without human victims, but one that many still remember as an apocalyptic scenario.

Whole_Text.content: The flooding in southwestern Germany, caused by heavy rainfall in Saarland as well as parts of Rhineland-Palatinate and Baden-Württemberg in mid-May 2024, led to floods, power outages, and landslides. The German Weather Service (DWD) recorded more than 100 liters of rain per square meter in 24 hours in some areas. The Saarland state capital Saarbrücken and several districts in Saarland declared a major damage situation. Outside of Germany, parts of France, Belgium, and the Netherlands were affected. Saarland was particularly severely affected. Prime Minister Anke Rehlinger stated that the flood situation there was the worst since the century flood of 1993.

The floods were caused by low-pressure system Katinka, a small secondary low that remained almost stationary for 12 hours. This resulted in very heavy rainfall in a small region, instead of the precipitation being distributed over a larger area. Additionally, a humid and warm weather pattern caused a significant amount of water vapor in the Earth's atmosphere. This is occurring more frequently due to human-induced climate change, as the atmosphere can absorb more moisture at higher temperatures.  
Spring in Germany was the warmest since weather records began. Since the Mediterranean Sea was about 2 to 3 degrees too warm, the low-pressure system was able to absorb a lot of moisture there. According to a preliminary report from the DWD on May 17 at noon, the rain began in Baden-Württemberg, where widespread amounts of 40 to 50 liters, and even up to 70 liters per square meter in northern Baden, were recorded. The rain area then expanded to the southern parts of Rhineland-Palatinate and Saarland. For example, in Saarbrücken, between 70 and 80 liters per square meter fell within 12 hours, with the majority of this rain, which would normally fall in a month, occurring within six hours.  
Overall, on May 17, more than 100 liters of rain per square meter fell in some places within 24 hours; in large parts of Saarland, it was 60 to 100 liters per square meter. The DWD issued a warning of the highest category, "extremely heavy continuous rain," for some regions and warned of 20- to 50-year flood events and beyond in some water bodies. On May 18, Holger Schüttrumpf, a professor of hydraulic engineering and water management at RWTH Aachen, classified the floods in Saarland as 50- to 100-year floods, meaning they are rare but not "absolutely extraordinary."

In Saarland, widespread flooding occurred, with many basements, ground floors, and entire streets submerged. Almost the entire Saarland experienced flooded roads, water-filled basements, or landslides. Authorities anticipate significant property damage. In Fremersdorf, the Saar River reached a level of 7.65 meters, the highest since records began. In Saarbrücken, 16 transformer stations had to be shut down, causing power outages. Near Quierschied, a dam broke, flooding the grounds of the Weiher coal power plant. In Ottweiler, dams broke, flooding the old town. The district office was also evacuated, and power was preemptively shut off for safety reasons. In Blieskastel, the old town was flooded after water backed up from the sewer system. Many municipalities experienced power outages, and in some places, gas supply, internet, and telephone services also failed. At least 54 state roads and six federal roads were affected by the flooding over the weekend. The city highway in Saarbrücken was closed for several days, and a number of roads suffered severe damage from washouts, collapsed roadways, and landslides, requiring long-term closures. In several locations, people trapped by the floodwaters had to be rescued. In Neunkirchen, around 150 people were rescued from a hotel. Parts of Saarbrücken were evacuated; in the Rußhütte district, residents had to be rescued from their homes using boats and amphibious vehicles. Additionally, 100 residents of a nursing home had to be evacuated. Train services were severely disrupted. A woman was struck by an emergency vehicle and died. A Red Cross helper also died of heart failure after a mission. In total, there were well over 4,000 operations involving more than 10,000 rescue workers from several federal states, including the Technical Relief Agency and the German Armed Forces. Anke Rehlinger, the Minister-President of Saarland, which was particularly hard-hit, stated that the flooding situation there was the worst since the century flood of 1993. In addition to emergency workers from Saarland, helpers from Hesse, Baden-Württemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, and Bavaria were also deployed to manage the flooding. The extent of the damage is still unknown. On May 20, 2024, Rehlinger stated that the flooding had caused "massive damage to private property, as well as infrastructure such as roads, bridges, and daycare centers," and that Saarland would likely struggle with its consequences for years. The president of the Saarland Chamber of Agriculture, Ecker, stated that over 300 of the approximately 1,100 agricultural businesses in Saarland likely suffered damage from the flooding, particularly due to the destruction and contamination of crops by water and pollutants such as leaked heating oil, resulting in crop failures. He also anticipated a very high pressure from snails following the flooding.

In Rhineland-Palatinate, the Trier region and the Southwest Palatinate were particularly affected. There were flooded streets and waterlogged basements, and trees were uprooted. Many damages to private houses as well as impassable and damaged roads were reported. In the Trier-Saarburg district, more than 350 people were evacuated, including the residents of a nursing home.

In France, areas near the Moselle and in Alsace were particularly affected. One of the hardest-hit places was Diemeringen in the Bas-Rhin department, where about 100 people were evacuated. Diemeringen is located west of the main ridge of the Vosges on the Eichel, a tributary of the Saar.

Due to the flooding, the water level of the Rhine rose by several meters.  
In Cologne, for example, it rose from 3.92 m (May 18, 11 a.m.) to 6.98 m (May 20, 7 a.m.).

Initial estimates from insurance companies as of May 24 suggest insured damages of approximately 200 million euros in Saarland and Rhineland-Palatinate. This amount does not include damages to buildings without natural hazard insurance—around 50 percent of the buildings—as well as damages to public infrastructure such as roads and bridges.

The Hessian Prime Minister Boris Rhein – in his capacity as chairman of the Conference of Prime Ministers – has called on the federal government (Scholz cabinet) to introduce mandatory insurance against natural disaster damages.  
The background to this demand includes the flooding in southern Germany in May/June 2024, the flooding in southwestern Germany around Pentecost 2024, and the devastating flooding in the Ahr Valley in 2021, which caused damages amounting to 30 billion euros. After very large flood damages many years ago, Germany began a "National Flood Protection Program." Only 15 percent of the projects are in the construction phase; according to the Federal Ministry for the Environment, a large portion of the measures are still in planning or conceptual stages.  
Federal Chancellor Olaf Scholz and the states planned a high-level discussion on June 20, 2024, on the topic of mandatory insurance for natural disaster damages.

Whole_Text.content: The 1403 Mashhad flood occurred on May 16, 1403, following heavy rain and hail. This intense rainfall caused many streams in Khorasan Razavi to overflow, leading to a flood in Mashhad that caused significant human and financial losses along its path. The torrential rain, accompanied by thunder and lightning, at 2:30 PM on May 16 in Mashhad resulted in street flooding and darkened skies in this metropolis. According to the head of Khorasan Razavi's crisis management, 38 millimeters of rain fell in Mashhad within an hour. The primary cause of the Mashhad flood was this volume of rainfall. The most damage from this flood was reported in the Seyedi area. Many blame Mashhad Municipality as one of the main culprits for the damages caused by this disaster. An examination of the water's path shows that it first entered Namaz Boulevard and then the Seyedi and Sepah neighborhoods. Additionally, the water and flood entered the terminal bridge and accumulated there. Another issue being discussed is a hypothesis that Mashhad Municipality does not confirm: that there are gates at the terminal bridge in Mashhad that can pass a large volume of water, and naturally, water should not have accumulated there. It is said that these gates may not have functioned properly, or according to some experts, they may have been blocked on one side. However, the municipality rejects this hypothesis, stating that the channel was blocked due to debris in the floodwater, preventing proper water flow. This caused three meters of water to accumulate, leading to the death of two people. Investigations also show that 15 cars and about 8 motorcycles were trapped in the Enqelab Square and terminal bridge in Mashhad, which were removed from the water by firefighting equipment by the night of the incident. This process continued until the night of May 16, and the bridge and square were reopened the next day. This flood led to the dismissal of Mostafa Kalidari, Mashhad's crisis management director, after his denial of the incident. Three days later, on May 19, 1403, another flood and heavy rainfall occurred in Mashhad, with significant rainfall recorded at various rain gauge stations in the city, ranging from 19 to 25 millimeters within 30 minutes. The flooding of streets caused the main routes in the city to be blocked, leading to severe traffic restrictions on May 19. Following this event, the head of the National Center for Forecasting and Crisis Management of the Meteorological Organization stated that weather warnings about hazards such as torrential rains are issued days in advance to inform people and officials to take necessary precautions. Continuing to issue warnings during an event is not beneficial. The Secretary-General of the Red Crescent Society also said that this incident was due to the lack of proper infrastructure, and such rainfall and hail had no precedent in the city's history. It was as if stones were falling from the sky, damaging the windows and roofs of cars directly hit by the hail. The May 1403 rainfall in Mashhad was unprecedented, with the city experiencing 133.3 millimeters of rain in this month alone, marking a 300% increase in rainfall in just the second month of 1403.

Whole_Text.header: Flood in Lori and Tavush regions
Whole_Text.content: Flood in Lori and Tavush regions, a major disaster, a flood in the Lori and Tavush regions of Armenia, particularly in the basins of the Debed, Aghstev, and Tashir rivers, which occurred on May 26, 2024. Due to heavy rains, the Debed River overflowed and caused destruction from the Dzoraget village to the "Bagratashen" border checkpoint. Simultaneously, a similar disaster occurred in the town of Tashir in the Lori region, where the river waters overflowed and flooded residential neighborhoods.

At the Sanahin station, the river waters have reached the second floors of buildings. A section of Alaverdi's main Tumanyan Street has been submerged. As a result of the flood, land communication with the Debed district has been cut off. Significant damage has also been caused to the Akhtala and Karkop settlements. In Alaverdi, gas and electricity supply have been disrupted, and internet and telephone connections have been operating with interruptions. The river waters have swept away barns, livestock, and vehicles. Various sections of the M6 highway have been destroyed and rendered impassable. Communication issues have arisen with people trapped in flooded areas. The cities of Akhtala and Shamlugh, as well as the settlements of Pokr Ayrum, Mets Ayrum, Chochkan, Shnogh, and Teghut, have been isolated. The Ministry of Internal Affairs has reported that the 31st km of the Vanadzor-Alaverdi road has been flooded, and a section approximately 50 meters long has collapsed. International train services on the Yerevan-Tbilisi-Yerevan route have been canceled. Water supply to 16 communities has been suspended due to the flood.

The "Road Department" foundation has published a video from the 110th km of the M-4 interstate road (from Dilijan to Ijevan), where the collapse of the road occurred due to the flooding of the Aghstev River. The Prime Minister of Armenia, Nikol Pashinyan, wrote on his Facebook page that the floods in the Dilijan-Ijevan section of the Armenia-Georgia interstate road have caused significant damage.
As a result of the flood, there are at least 3 dead and 1 missing.

Whole_Text.header: Response and actions of the relevant authorities

Whole_Text.content: As of 11:30, 30 firefighting units of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Rescue Service with 324 rescue personnel have been working at the scene. 232 citizens have been evacuated from dangerous areas.

A few hours after the disaster began, the State Revenue Committee of the Republic of Armenia issued a statement urging economic operators to carry out cargo transportation to Georgia through the "Bavra" and "Gogavan" customs checkpoints, as the road to the "Bagratashen" checkpoint had become impassable due to the disaster.

A few hours after the disaster began, the "South Caucasus Railways" company announced that various sections of the Yerevan-Tbilisi railway were damaged as a result of the disaster, and therefore international railway communication was suspended from May 26.

Whole_Text.header: Ministry of Territorial Administration and Infrastructure of the Republic of Armenia
Whole_Text.content: On May 27, the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Infrastructure of Armenia announced that as of 1:00 PM, traffic on the "Bagratashen" customs checkpoint - Noyemberyan - Ijevan - Dilijan - Yerevan route has been restored. In the "Bagratashen" customs checkpoint - Haghtanak village and Ijevan - Dilijan sections, traffic has been organized using one lane of the road (one-way).

On the evening of May 29, under the leadership of Lori Governor Aram Ghazaryan, a concluding consultation was held, attended by Alaverdi Mayor Davit Ghumashyan, Deputy Governors Gor Asryan and Hovhannes Avetisyan, Head of the Lori Regional Center of the State Food Safety Inspection Body Kamo Soghoian, representatives of the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Infrastructure of Armenia, the Lori Governor's Office, the Alaverdi Municipality, and other responsible employees of the Food Safety Inspection Body. Aram Ghazaryan was presented with the results of the damage assessment work caused by the disaster. Issues related to the distribution of food supplies, as well as providing residents with necessary medications and healthcare services, were discussed. The progress of work aimed at managing the epizootic situation was presented. On June 9, the Rescue Service of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Armenia reported that, according to the "Road Department" Foundation, the Vanadzor-Alaverdi-Ayrum-Bagratashen highway (M6 road) is passable only for passenger vehicles.

On May 27, the "Road Department" foundation reported that as of 09:30, the Yerevan-Sevan-Ijevan-Armenia border highway (M4 road) section from Dilijan to Ijevan is passable, but in some areas, traffic is one-way. The "Road Department" foundation stated that the company servicing the road has carried out reinforcement works to prevent the destruction caused by the Aghstev River on the Dilijan-Ijevan road. On June 9, the Rescue Service of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Armenia reported that according to the "Road Department" foundation, the Yerevan-Sevan-Ijevan-Armenia border highway (M4 road) section from Dilijan to Ijevan is passable. However, in some areas, traffic is one-way, and the bridge leading to the villages of Khashtarak and Lusahovit is closed in both directions.

Whole_Text.content: Alaverdi flood, a natural disaster in the city of Alaverdi in the Tumanyan district of Soviet Armenia, part of the Soviet Union, which occurred on the night of August 14-15, 1970. Due to heavy rains, the flooding of the Debed and Lalvar rivers, and the flow of mudslides and floodwaters from the mountain slopes, massive destruction took place in various neighborhoods of Alaverdi city.

On the night of August 14 to 15, the floodwaters gathered in the area of the Sanahin village monastery destroyed the retaining wall, merged with floodwaters flowing from other ravines, and with a strong current, poured down the cliff onto the Engels district. The floodwaters initially destroyed the wooden dormitory houses of the district and deposited the debris in the yard of building 26, with the water level reaching the third floor of the building, resulting in the drowning of one resident. Due to the overflow of the Lalvar stream, the buildings of riverside warehouses and first-floor shops were destroyed, and the goods inside were carried into the Debed River. The overflow of the Debed River damaged the Yerevan-Tbilisi railway and highway, making transportation impossible. The hospital, court, and other state institutions, as well as the school, kindergarten, and residential buildings, were damaged. The floodwaters entered the first floors of the buildings, sweeping away the belongings inside. After the flood, layers of mud 1 to 3 meters thick formed on the city's streets. The city park, roads, and private houses were destroyed, and landslides and collapses occurred. Animal casualties were recorded. As a result of the disaster, the Haghpat and Sanahin stations suffered significant damage, and the water supply, sewage, electricity, gas supply, and communication networks were destroyed. The operations of some workshops of the metallurgical plant and the Alaverdi bread factory were halted. The floodwaters also entered the substation of the brewery, and the water swept away barrels filled with beer and bottles of lemonade.

On August 15, a headquarters for disaster relief was established during a joint session of the Tumanyan District Committee Bureau of the Communist Party of Armenia, the Alaverdi City Council, and the Tumanyan District Council Executive Committees. On the same day, a disaster relief headquarters was also established under the government of Soviet Armenia[1]. By the orders of the district and governmental headquarters, volunteer groups were formed to clean the mud that had appeared in the streets, parks, and building courtyards as a result of the floods[1].

Whole_Text.header: The breach of Dongting Lake in 2024
Whole_Text.content:
In 2024, the breach of Dongting Lake occurred on the afternoon of July 5, 2024, at around 3:32 PM [1] in Tuanzhou Dike, Huarong County, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, People's Republic of China, due to continuous heavy rainfall causing the dike to collapse. The breach reached its maximum width of approximately 226 meters the following morning [2]. The government and military began sealing operations on the afternoon of the second day [3][4][5], completing the closure by the night of July 8 [6][7]. 

After the dike breach was sealed, drainage operations commenced to clear the accumulated 210 million cubic meters of water [8]. By the night of July 10, the number of drainage devices at the Tuanzhou Dike floodwater pumping site had increased to 266, and the water level within the dike continued to decrease [9]. 

This disaster caused significant property damage, including the flooding of several villages within the dike area. However, due to timely warning responses, affected residents were urgently evacuated and resettled, resulting in no casualties [10].

Whole_Text.content: The 1924 Madras Provincial Flood refers to the massive flooding that occurred in July 1924 in the Madras Province of British India due to heavy rainfall in the Western Ghats, causing major floods in rivers like the Kaveri and Bhavani. This flood caused significant damage in areas ranging from the then Malabar district, Coimbatore district, Salem district, Tiruchirappalli district, to Tanjore district. During this flood, 12 bridges were destroyed in the Bhavani river flood, landslides occurred on the Ooty-Kotagiri-Mysore road, and breaches were reported in the Bhavani, Kaveri, and Kollidam rivers. A part of the Mukkombu dam was washed away.

In July 1924, heavy rains poured over the Eastern Ghats. In the South Canara district, rainfall recorded was between 97-155 cm. The grasslands and forested hills in the Western Ghats there had been destroyed by the British government for commercial purposes. Naturally, these areas used to retain water and control the flow of floods. Additionally, there were no dams in the hills at that time, and only structures like stone weirs and Kodiveri dams existed in the plains. As a result, the monsoon floods surged eastward without barriers. Due to the heavy southwest monsoon rains in the Western Ghats, the plains of Tamil Nadu experienced massive floods in July 1924, even without rainfall. Catastrophic floods occurred three times—on July 16, July 23, and later on July 26 and 27. On July 24, the Cauvery River carried 4.63 lakh cubic feet of water, and on July 26, it carried 4.56 lakh cubic feet of water. On July 16 and 18, near Sathyamangalam, the floodwaters rose to 23 feet, and in the Cauvery River, it rose to 36 feet. In the following two days, the flood level increased to 38 feet. The floodwaters rose two feet above the Bhavani Sagar Bridge.

Due to the heavy floods, 12 bridges were washed away. Landslides occurred on the Ooty-Kotagiri-Mysore road. Breaches occurred in the Bhavani, Kaveri, and Kollidam rivers. On the right side of the Mukkombu dam, 300 feet, and in the center, 700 feet of the structure were washed away. As a result, many villages and small towns were severely affected. The Uraiyur lake broke. In Murungapettai, the railway track was washed away, and the entire village was destroyed. In the Trichy-Coimbatore road area, the Kaveri river changed its course for five kilometers, destroying the road. The surrounding walls of the Srirangam Ranganatha Swamy Temple collapsed. On July 18, the Kollidam river bridge collapsed. Due to this flood, 22,000 houses in the Malabar district, 6,136 in the Coimbatore district, 1,323 in the Salem district, 7,710 in the Trichy district, and 4,000 in the Tanjore district were destroyed, totaling 43,209 houses. Additionally, in the adjoining areas, including the South Arcot district, sand deposits of 1.5 to 6 feet high formed over 12,202 acres of land. This flood caused the death of up to 10,000 people. The stench of corpses spread everywhere. Epidemics broke out. With food and shelter destroyed, prices rose, and wages decreased. Famine spread, forcing people to migrate in large numbers. A total of 274,985 people moved to Malaysia as plantation laborers.

The government was involved in rescue operations. Fishermen played a key role in saving people. Great attention was given to the restoration of the Kallanai. The construction of the Kollidam bridge, 80 miles west of its original location, began in January 1926 and was completed and opened for use in January 1928. After 90 years, the bridge collapsed in the 2018 floods. To remove the sand deposits caused by the floods in residential areas and fields, 285 tram wagons were brought in, tracks were laid in various places, and the sand was removed through them. That sand was used for railway constructions. Villages that were uninhabitable and destroyed were abandoned, and new villages were created in other locations.

The floods in the Balkans began in December 2010. The Drina River on the border of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia overflowed its banks, and parts of Montenegro, Albania, and Kosovo were also flooded. This was due to heavy rainfall. People in Albania sometimes had to move around in small boats. Albania was the hardest hit. Approximately 12,000 people were evacuated in Albania. There were no deaths or injuries. The storms in December 2010 in the Balkans were the heaviest in living memory.

Whole_Text.content: "When the downpour arrives, nothing is saved." [1] The 1940 flood or the Sant Lluc flood was an episode of torrential rains that took place in October 1940 in the eastern Pyrenees, specifically in Northern Catalonia and the northeastern part of Southern Catalonia, causing devastating floods. The period of rain in the Eastern Pyrenees lasted from October 16 to 20. Officially, 840 mm of rain was recorded on October 17 alone, making it the record for precipitation registered in Europe within 24 hours, despite meteorological services being interrupted due to World War II. However, a teacher from Sant Llorenç de Cerdans noted 1930 mm over the five days of the episode, 1,000 mm of which were concentrated on October 17. [2] The rains were less intense in the Black Mountain. The Canal du Midi broke due to the rains in the Pyrenees. Almost all rivers from the Llobregat basin to the Tet basin overflowed. In Catalonia, 58 bridges and 380 houses were destroyed. About 175,000 hectares of farmland were completely flooded. In Northern Catalonia, around 200 buildings collapsed, and three hydroelectric power plants were completely destroyed, including the one at Llau. [2] The human toll of the episode was over 400 deaths. The most devastated area was around the Canigó massif, where there were more than 200 victims. [2] This episode had a significant impact on the inhabitants of the regions that suffered the destruction. In Olot, it has remained in memory in the form of poems or songs that recall such an event with an ironic tone. [2]

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1856 in France affected a large number of rivers and remains a reference flood. It impacted, at the end of May and beginning of June, the Rhône or the Loire, devastating Lyon, Avignon, Tarascon which was cut off from Avignon, etc.

The flood of the Loire in 1856 remains to this day the most significant since 1790. It covered nearly 100,000 hectares, destroyed nearly 23 km of dikes, and caused the death of about thirty people in the Maine-et-Loire department alone. However, upstream of the confluence with the Allier, the level of this 1856 flood was significantly lower than in 1846 and 1866, and equivalent to that of 1907. Many towns were partially submerged: Blois, Tours, Trélazé, etc. In the latter municipality, the Ardoisières quarry was engulfed, causing production to halt for several months. Many old houses bear flood marks from the Loire on their walls. Many of these date back to the campaign of commemorative plaque installation in the flooded areas, which was undertaken in 1856 to preserve the memory of the disaster.

On June 1, 1856, the waters began to recede in Arles, but the damage was immense: In Avignon, on June 3, 1856, the flood swept away part of the ramparts between the St-Roch gate and the St-Dominique gate. In Lyon, the damage was very significant, particularly on the left bank, which was undergoing a period of construction. 18 people died in the commune of La Guillotière. Photographer Édouard Baldus, at the request of the Administration of Fine Arts, created a report (probably one of the very first photographic reports after those of the Crimean War) on the devastating Rhône floods in Lyon, Avignon, and Tarascon. We also have photographs taken by Louis Froissard, photographer for the municipal road service of Lyon.

Napoleon III will visit the damage in the south of France starting the first week of June 1856. He goes to Lyon (June 2, 1856), Dijon, Valence, Arles, and navigates through the streets of Tarascon. After a stop in Paris on June 5, 1856, he travels to Orléans, Blois, Angers, and Tours, also affected by the flooding of the Loire. This visit was not without political motives: he does not forget to pass through the commune of Trélazé, where the Marianne riots had taken place a year earlier. A decree dated June 2, 1856, allocates 300,000 francs to Lyon. Isère, Drôme, etc., also receive funds, while 27 million francs are allocated to repair bridges, churches, fountains, etc. Empress Eugénie launches a subscription, in which the Faubourg Saint-Antoine notably participates.

The floods in Tunisia in 2007 refer to heavy rainfall that caused flooding in several areas in Tunisia during the autumn of 2007.  
The most significant low-pressure system with thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain and hail occurred on October 13, coinciding with the second day of Eid al-Fitr, and particularly affected northern Tunisia, Greater Tunis, and the Cap Bon region.  
These floods resulted in 13 fatalities.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Polesine on September 17, 1882, was a disastrous event that affected the provinces of Verona and Rovigo and the municipality of Cavarzere.

On September 15, 1882, the flooding of the Adige had already caused severe damage in Verona. On September 17 at 3:30 AM, the Adige broke its banks on the right side at Boschetto di Angiari, near the "Galletto sluice," 100 km from the Adriatic Sea. The overflowing waters devastated the countryside of the lower Veronese and Polesine areas, eventually pouring into the Tartaro-Canalbianco, causing breaches in its banks at Bergantino, Zelo, and Frassinelle Polesine. When floods occurred south of the Canalbianco, Venetians would immediately cut the banks of the Fossa Polesella to facilitate the flow of water toward the sea; if this measure had been taken immediately in this case, the disaster would have been significantly less severe. On this occasion, the Civil Engineering Department of Rovigo acted with culpable delay, proceeding to cut the Fossa only on September 30; in the meantime, the entire territory from the Valli Grandi Veronesi to the Fossa had been flooded. Thirty-nine municipalities were devastated. The commission appointed by the Ministry of Public Works decided to build two new drainage channels in Polesine, one on each side of the Canalbianco, leaving the latter as the exclusive outlet for the Valli Grandi Veronesi; however, only the Collettore Padano Polesano on the right side was actually built.

A period of severe famine followed, during which 63,000 people emigrated to South America. The foundations were also laid for the movements known as "La Boje." In memory of the catastrophe, a plaque was placed in the portico of the Rotonda in Rovigo, where many evacuees from the countryside were temporarily housed in the days following the flood.

Whole_Text.content: The Danube flood of February 1862 was an exceptionally severe flood of the Danube. It caused particularly great destruction in Vienna and Passau.

The flood, caused by persistent thawing, inundated areas on both sides of the Danube in Vienna at the beginning of February, particularly Leopoldstadt, Brigittenau, Zwischenbrücken, Rossau, Floridsdorf, Mühlschüttel, Stadlau, the area around the Great Danube Bridge, and Langenzersdorf. In Passau, the flood reached its peak on February 2 with a level of 11.6 m.
This and the previous major Danube flood of 1830 ultimately gave the impetus for the Vienna Danube regulation in Vienna.

The 1934 Tabriz flood was a flood that occurred on August 8, 1934, in Tabriz. The Tabriz flood did not cause widespread loss of life; however, it caused significant financial damage by destroying about 1,300 houses and shops and leaving behind a large amount of sand, mud, and large boulders that had to be cleared.

Following rainfall in the highlands and eastern outskirts of Tabriz on the afternoon of August 8, 1934, while there was no indication in the city itself of the likelihood of such an event, a flood surged along the paths of the Quri-Chay and Meydan-Chay rivers. After destroying obstacles such as bridge foundations, dams, and channel walls, it flowed along Pahlavi Street, one of the city's main streets, engulfing all the surrounding buildings. This flood, which lasted about two hours and took three hours to gradually subside, continued towards areas such as the railway station and parts of neighborhoods like Bagh Golestan, Ahrab, Shah Abad, and Kucheh Bagh. In addition to destroying homes and warehouses, such as the Saray Amir, it also disrupted some administrative centers, including the buildings of the police, judiciary, municipality, and provincial offices. It is said that after the dam's destruction, the flood flowed onto Pahlavi Street and immediately began destroying houses, buildings, and shops along the street. It quickly reached in front of Karim Khan Mosque, where it split into two parts: one part rushed towards the old street, engulfing the street bazaar, the city's finance office, and the tobacco office. The power station, Shapur Square, the statistics office, the education department, the police departments, the judiciary, the municipality, the police headquarters, the provincial building (Ali Qapu), and Saray Amir were among the places partially or completely destroyed or surrounded by water due to the flood. This flood turned the entire Pahlavi Street into a muddy river, and throughout the city, the sound of collapsing houses, water-filled buildings, and the cries of flood victims could be heard.

The Tabriz flood did not cause widespread loss of life, but financially, it inflicted significant damage by destroying about 1,300 houses and shops and leaving behind a large amount of sand, mud, and large boulders that needed to be cleared. According to the report of the secretary of the flood victims' commission, the approximate amount of these damages, excluding the damages to the city's streets and government offices and institutions, was estimated at around fifteen million rials in terms of building destruction, household furniture, and loss of merchandise. Approximately ten million rials of this amount belonged to the city's wealthy residents, and five million rials to non-wealthy individuals. The damages to government offices also exceeded two hundred thousand tomans.

The actions of Fahimi, the governor of Azerbaijan, and Brigadier General Saif, the head of the police, along with Amir Lashkar Mohtashami, the head of the division, and their subordinates, including 1,200 military personnel, to provide aid and rescue flood victims, were the first reactions of officials to this incident. This was while, due to the disruption of telegraph lines, officials in Tehran and other provinces did not have accurate information about the event. On August 2, at Fahimi's invitation, a meeting of the heads of civil and military departments, as well as prominent city figures, was held. After the governor's remarks describing the city's situation and the flood victims, about twenty prominent individuals present were elected as representatives of Tabriz's seven districts to join the "Flood Victims Commission," which began its work on August 4. The main task of this commission was to collect donations and aid from the wealthy in Tabriz and other parts of the country and distribute these financial aids among the flood victims. Meanwhile, as damaged departments were relocated to other buildings and administrative affairs became more organized, with the re-establishment of direct telegraph communication between Tabriz and Tehran on August 4, national officials, upon learning of the extensive scale of the flood and its destruction, initiated a series of measures to address the issue. Initially, aid from the capital was individual and uncoordinated, such as a donation of one hundred thousand tomans by Reza Shah or contributions from Azerbaijan's representatives in the National Assembly and some Azerbaijani merchants residing in the capital, which were quickly sent to Tabriz. However, after receiving and publishing more detailed reports on the matter, a committee of sixteen members was formed to establish a relief commission. This commission took on the main responsibility of collecting and directing public donations. According to available reports, in addition to other cities in Azerbaijan, centers for collecting aid were opened in places such as Mashhad, Qazvin, Sari, Babol, Borujerd, Rasht, Hamedan, Yazd, Arak, Kermanshah, and Khuzestan. Based on the detailed list of received donations published in the booklet "Income and Expenditure Report of the Flood Victims Commission," about 62% of the total received aid was collected from the capital and other cities in Iran.

While the clearing of mud and rocks left by the flood in Tabriz continued throughout the city, the presence and supervision of Mirza Mahmoud Khan Jam, the Minister of Interior in Foroughi's cabinet, in Tabriz from August 18 to September 2 of the same year also led to increased activity in ongoing efforts. One of the first actions taken after the flood occurred was the assignment of a municipal engineering team to rebuild the waterways. The restoration of the Quri Chay and Meydan Chay waterways through excavation, rebuilding walls, demolishing constructions that had been built in them, and the construction of dams in Nazamiyeh and other areas were among the measures initiated with the allocation of a 200,000-toman budget by the government.

Whole_Text.header: Widening the river path and constructing a flood control dam
Whole_Text.content: One year after the occurrence of this flood, Aref al-Molk Jalili, the then mayor of Tabriz in 1935, decided to build a dam to control the city's floods. In those years, he allocated 2 million tomans of funds and took action to widen the 12-kilometer path of the Meydan Chay and Quri Chay rivers from the west to the east of the city. With the completion of this project after three years, Jalili permanently saved the city of Tabriz from the danger of floods. The main sections of this stone wall remain intact to this day, although many new constructions, including part of Tabriz Metro Line 1 between 29 Bahman Station and the University Station, as well as some structures of the non-level intersections in Parkway Chay-Kenar, pass through the flood barrier wall.

Whole_Text.content: The Riyadh storm of November 2013 was a torrential flood storm that swept through the city of Riyadh on November 16, 2013. The storm caused floods and torrents in several neighborhoods in Riyadh, with alarm sirens sounding in the Al-Suwaidi neighborhood in the southwest of Riyadh. The Civil Defense Directorate announced the death of a Yemeni resident due to the floods and torrents caused by the storm. The storm is considered the most severe in Riyadh since 1997, with rainfall in Riyadh exceeding 60 mm. The storm was caused by the passage of a low-pressure system in northern Saudi Arabia and the formation of a surface low over Al-Majma'ah Governorate, located north of Riyadh. The surface low caused cloud rotation and their persistence for several hours over Riyadh.

Whole_Text.content: The 2016 Xingtai flood refers to the flood disaster that occurred in Xingtai City, Hebei Province, China, from July 19 to 21, 2016. The flood, triggered by continuous heavy rainfall, caused widespread damage in Xingtai City, affecting all counties, cities, and districts within its jurisdiction. Particularly on the night of July 19, the Qili River experienced a levee breach, flooding 12 villages, including Daxian Village in Dongwang Town, resulting in multiple deaths or disappearances, with the disaster being extremely severe. As of 7 a.m. on July 24, statistics showed that the flood had caused 130 deaths and 110 missing persons in Xingtai City, with the affected population in Hebei reaching 9.04 million. [1]

On July 19, 2016, at 8:00 PM, the Huanghuai cyclone formed in Henan. As this extratropical cyclone developed, it slowly moved northeastward and reached its peak in Hebei at around 2:00 PM on July 20. The Huanghuai cyclone caused extreme heavy rainfall in many northern regions, including Hebei.

Since July 19, Xingtai City has experienced the strongest rainfall since the start of the flood season. The Xingtai Meteorological Observatory issued a red rainstorm warning signal at 14:00 on July 19. As of 16:00 on July 20, the city's average rainfall was 167.7 millimeters, with the maximum rainfall recorded at Shangweisi in Lincheng County at 673.5 millimeters. Multiple areas, including Shahe City, Neiqiu County, Lincheng County, Qiaodong District, Qiaoxi District, Xingtai County, Longyao County, and Nanhe County, experienced rainfall exceeding 350 millimeters. Several data points have surpassed the values of the "63·8" and "96·8" extraordinary rainstorms. From 8:00 on July 18 to 8:00 on July 21, the average rainfall in Xingtai City during the event was 204 millimeters.

The water levels of all six large and medium-sized reservoirs in Xingtai City exceeded the flood limit, with a sharp increase in the average inflow rate. The maximum inflow occurred between 1:00 and 3:00 on July 20. The peak inflow rate of Zhuzhuang Reservoir was 7,780 cubic meters per second, Lincheng Reservoir was 3,215 cubic meters per second, Yegoumen Reservoir was 3,053 cubic meters per second, and Dongshiling Reservoir was 1,108 cubic meters per second. [6] At 19:10 on July 19, the peak flow rate at the Luoluochuan Podi Hydrological Station was 1,650 cubic meters per second. At 0:10 on July 20, the peak flow rate at the Xitaiyu Hydrological Station on the south branch of the Zhihe River was 800 cubic meters per second. At 0:00 on July 20, the peak flow rate at the Liulin Hydrological Station on the Xiaoma River was 361 cubic meters per second. At 19:50 on July 20, the peak flow rate at the Duanzhuang Hydrological Station on the Dasha River was 1,140 cubic meters per second. At 4:30 on July 22, the peak flow rate at the Xingjiawan Hydrological Station on the Beili River was 205 cubic meters per second. At 2:00 on July 21, the peak flow rate at the Aixinzhuang Hydrological Station on the Fuyang New River was 450 cubic meters per second. Additionally, the maximum flow rate at the Linmingguan Hydrological Station on the Shaming River was 5,710 cubic meters per second, and the maximum flow rate at the Macun Hydrological Station on the Beisha River was 1,100 cubic meters per second. Significant flood processes also occurred in the Qili River and Baima River. Due to river channels exceeding the standard flood discharge capacity, breaches occurred in multiple river sections. [6] Flood detention areas were activated. The flood discharge areas of Nanhe, Baixiang, Ningjin, Longyao, and Renxian were successively inundated, and flood detention was carried out in Baixiang, Ningjin, Longyao, and Renxian. [6]

Continuous heavy rainfall has caused the largest flood in Xingtai City since August 1996, resulting in widespread disaster affecting all counties, cities, and districts within Xingtai City. As of 4:00 PM on July 24, the flood has caused 130 deaths, 110 missing persons, and affected a population of 1.678 million; over 28,000 houses have collapsed, more than 8,000 houses have been severely damaged, and approximately 17,000 houses have been moderately damaged; the affected agricultural area exceeds 110,000 hectares, with direct economic losses exceeding 1 billion yuan. On the night of July 19, the floodwaters of Qili River breached the embankment and flooded 12 villages, including Daxian Village in Dongwang Town, causing multiple deaths or missing persons and extremely severe damage.

After the flood occurred, Xingtai City initiated a Level I emergency response for flood control and rescue. Under the guidance of the city's flood control office, flood control and drought relief command institutions in subordinate counties, cities, and districts relocated people from dangerous areas according to the plan. The stationed troops arranged 28 assault boats and over 280 soldiers, organized 1,200 local cadres and residents to carry out emergency repairs on dikes with risks, and evacuated trapped residents. The Xingtai Economic Development Zone dispatched 15 working groups to inspect disaster conditions in 12 flooded villages, including Daxian Village, house by house, resettled relocated people, and fully launched epidemic prevention work in the disaster area. On July 21, due to the impact of continuous water levels exceeding the warning level, the dike sections in Nanzhangzhuang Village of Nanhe County's Nanlihe River and Gaomiao section of Dashao River in Shahe City experienced collapse risks. Soldiers stationed in Xingtai, along with local cadres and residents, organized emergency repairs, even using scrapped buses filled with sandbags to build underwater dikes, effectively controlling the collapse risks. The Hebei Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China and the provincial government established a flood control and disaster relief working group to guide and assist in post-disaster reconstruction, resettlement of residents, and follow-up handling in Xingtai and other areas, as well as to verify and address hot issues of public concern. On July 24, entrusted by Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Communist Party of China and President of the State, and Li Keqiang, member of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China and Premier of the State Council, State Councilor and Director of the National Disaster Reduction Committee Wang Yong led a State Council working group to visit disaster-stricken areas in Handan, Xingtai, Shijiazhuang, and other places in Hebei Province to console affected residents and guide their resettlement.

On the night of July 19, a flood overflowed the banks of the Qili River and entered villages, causing multiple deaths or disappearances. This disaster only came to public attention through reports by ordinary users on social media, rather than official announcements. It was not until 7 p.m. on July 22 that the official Weibo account of the Xingtai Municipal Party Committee's Publicity Office, "Xingtai Release," mentioned the death toll for the first time in its flood disaster report. The delay in the official reporting of the disaster has been widely questioned. [13][14] On July 20, Wang Qingfei, Deputy Secretary of the Party Working Committee of the Xingtai Economic Development Zone, stated in a media interview that the Qili River flood had not caused any casualties. This statement angered affected villagers. On the morning of the 22nd, some affected villagers and families of the deceased from Dongwang Town and Wangkuai Town blocked roads. Coincidentally, Wang Qingfei was on his way to nearby areas to direct disaster relief efforts, leading to an incident where Wang Qingfei and several disaster victims knelt to each other. After persuasion from government staff and police, the villagers ended the road blockade around 11 a.m. Later, Wang Qingfei explained to the media that kneeling was an effort to appease the public and gain their understanding. [15][16]

Whole_Text.header: Villagers block the road, officials kneel, flooding incident exposed.
Whole_Text.content: Due to the flood that struck Daxian Village around 2 a.m. on the 20th, villagers were awakened from their sleep and fled for their lives, but 8 people unfortunately lost their lives, including 5 children under the age of 10, and a 3-year-old girl remains missing. After the flooding incident, Wang Qingfei, Deputy Secretary of the Party Working Committee of the Xingtai Economic and Technological Development Zone, told the media that the villagers had been evacuated and "no casualties" occurred, igniting the anger of the villagers. On the 22nd, they collectively blocked the main road, paralyzing traffic and demanding a response from the Xingtai municipal government. Wang Qingfei eventually appeared, kneeling on the ground with villagers who were crying in grief. The incidents of "villagers blocking the road" and "officials kneeling" brought attention to the flooding incident in Daxian Village.

Whole_Text.header: The cause of the breach of the Qili River embankment
Whole_Text.content:
After the flood overflowed the banks of Qili River, rumors circulated online claiming that the flood was directly caused by the discharge of an upstream reservoir and questioning why downstream villages were not notified in time about the reservoir's discharge. The Xingtai authorities responded, stating that the only upstream reservoir, Dongchuankou Reservoir, is an open-type reservoir where discharge cannot be controlled, and there is no issue of human scheduling of the discharge. The floodwaters entering Qili River came from two sources: one from the overflow of Dongchuankou Reservoir and interval inflows, and the other from the flood diversion channel in Xingtai's urban area. These two sources converged to form a major flood. Additionally, the sudden narrowing of Qili River at Daxian Bridge caused the flood to overflow the banks and breach, leading to water entering villages in the development zone.

Around the time of the Spring Festival, Xingtai City began a centralized urban heating project. The construction unit, in order to allow the heating pipeline to pass through Qili River, piled the excavated soil in front of Daxian Bridge to build a dam, blocking the river channel horizontally. The original earthen dam was also removed and piled into the river channel. The Xingtai flood control department had twice urged the clearing of the river channel, but the construction unit failed to act in time. Many villagers believe that the lack of local flood control awareness, the removal of the dam, the blockage of the river channel, and the near-filling of the bridge opening were the main reasons why the upstream floodwaters suddenly surged near Daxian Village and rushed into the villages.

After the Hebei Provincial Party Committee and Provincial Government workgroup arrived in Xingtai, they reviewed relevant meteorological data and conducted on-site inspections of the Qili River channel, the breach site, and the upstream Dongchuankou Reservoir. They preliminarily concluded that the breach of Qili River on the night of July 19 was caused by a flood peak formed by localized heavy rainfall rather than human factors.

Whole_Text.header: The government is ineffective in emergency disaster relief.
Whole_Text.content: After the flood in Qilihe, local villagers questioned the official warning measures before the flood entered the village. Villagers stated that apart from a broadcast warning about half an hour before the flood entered the village, they did not receive any other warnings. An official from the Water Resources Bureau of the Xingtai Economic Development Zone said in a media interview that the development zone did not receive a notice from the higher-level flood control office to evacuate residents from the night of July 19 to the early morning of July 20. Meanwhile, an official from the Xingtai City Flood Control and Drought Relief Command Office stated that the city flood control office did issue an evacuation notice to the economic development zone at that time but could not recall the specific time. On July 23, the deputy mayor of Xingtai City stated at a press conference that the city flood control office notified the development zone to organize the evacuation of residents at 1:40 a.m. on July 20, and the relevant departments of the development zone immediately entered Daxian Village. Multiple villagers in Daxian Village reported to the media that during the approximately seven hours from the early morning of July 20, when the flood entered the village, until around noon that day, rescue forces were slow to arrive, and most of the rescue work was organized spontaneously by villagers after the floodwaters receded slightly. In response, the head of the Xingtai Municipal Party Committee's External Publicity Office stated in an interview with reporters that rescue forces rushed to the disaster area immediately after the flood broke out, "It was definitely notified in time to evacuate, but the specific rescue situation is not yet clear."

On the afternoon of July 24, staff from the Ningjin County Water Resources Bureau in Xingtai City, while following the instructions of the city's flood control command and the flood prevention plan to close the Fu You Sluice at Gengzhuangqiao Town, were obstructed by some villagers from the flood detention area and clashed with police maintaining order at the scene.

Whole_Text.header: The government apologizes and holds accountability.
Whole_Text.content: On the evening of July 23, Xingtai Mayor Dong Xiaoyu admitted at a press conference that the government had underestimated the intensity of the short-term heavy rainfall, lacked sufficient emergency response capabilities for the flood disaster, and failed to accurately and promptly report and verify the disaster situation. He deeply reflected on these shortcomings and apologized to the families of the victims, the affected residents, and the public. The Xingtai Municipal Party Committee and the Municipal Commission for Discipline Inspection initiated accountability procedures, suspending and investigating those responsible for inadequate performance during the flood response. Duan Xiaoyong, Secretary of the Party Working Committee and Director of the Management Committee of Xingtai Economic Development Zone, Zhang Guowei, Secretary of the Party Committee of Dongwang Town, and Guo Tongheng, Deputy Secretary of the Party Committee of Wangkuai Town, were suspended and investigated.
