Whole_Text.content: The flood in the Czech Republic in 2013 occurred in three consecutive waves: the first from May 29 to June 5 after several days of rain, mainly in the area of the Central Bohemian Uplands, but also in the northwest and northeast of Bohemia; the second, far less intense, came as a result of heavy local rains in the saturated South Bohemian basins from June 10 to June 12; and the third, the weakest wave, from June 24 to June 27, 2013, in the areas of the Krkonoše Mountains, Jizera Mountains, and the Bohemian-Moravian Highlands. Especially during the first wave, streams and rivers in many places reached levels of 20- to 50-year floods, and not uncommonly even 100-year floods. A total of 970 municipalities across the Czech Republic were affected, including several large cities such as Ústí nad Labem, Děčín, Prague, Plzeň, and České Budějovice. The Czech government also declared a state of emergency on Sunday, June 2, 2013, by decision no. 140/2013 Coll., for the capital city of Prague (effective until June 19) and for the regions of Liberec (until June 12), South Bohemia, Plzeň (until June 19), Hradec Králové, Central Bohemia, and Ústí (until June 28). However, the army remained on alert until July 15, 2013. Firefighters responded to 9,611 incidents related to the floods, deploying 9,518 fire units (3,748 professional and 5,770 volunteer) with approximately 28,500 personnel. Additionally, in accordance with the Central Alarm Plan of the Integrated Rescue System, 21,000 members of the Czech Police (including dozens of dog handlers and bomb disposal experts) were deployed, and 9,324 soldiers of the Czech Army (including members of the Castle Guard) with 1,585 pieces of equipment were rotated in 71 towns and municipalities. The Czech Red Cross Water Rescue Service was also activated. A total of 26,438 people were evacuated, and 618 people were rescued. The floods claimed 15 lives (including five victims among kayakers attempting adrenaline descents on swollen rivers; one other kayaker is missing) and caused at least 75 landslides (arguably the most serious above the village of Litochovice nad Labem, where a sliding slope over an area of approximately 10 hectares destroyed railway line 097 and the under-construction D8 motorway). Additionally, 214 road sections of all classes had to be closed. The necessary direct (initial) costs for measures to address the crisis situation amounted to 1.16 billion CZK, and the total damages are in the tens of billions. The morning peak of the Elbe River in Děčín on June 6, 2013, at 4:00 a.m. reached a height of 1,071 cm and a flow rate of 3,910 m³/s, making it the fourth-largest flood in the Czech Republic. The 2013 floods also affected Germany, Austria, and Switzerland, as well as western Slovakia (mainly Bratislava), Hungary, and Poland.

After a relatively overcast and rainy spring in 2013, a significant part of the Czech Republic's territory was saturated with water from spring thaw and rainfall. Particularly, the month of May was above average in precipitation for the Bohemia region (approximately 2/3 more rainfall), which naturally led to higher soil saturation. The immediate cause was a low-pressure system over Central Europe, which brought intense rainfall activity in a north-south direction over the areas of Saxony, Bavaria, Bohemia, and Austria by the end of May. Additionally, a chain of strong storms occurred in this zone, with extensive areas recording precipitation totals exceeding 100 mm/24 hours. On May 28, 2013, the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute issued a serious warning about the threat of storms with heavy rain and hail for the period of May 29–30. A flood warning followed the next day, particularly for the Lužická Nisa basin, the Berounka tributaries, and the upper Elbe. On May 31, 2013, a flood alert was in effect for the South Bohemian Region and a flood warning for the Plzeň Region.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the Vltava River Basin
Whole_Text.content: Since May 20, workers of the Vltava River Basin had been preparing for the possibility of floods, and on the same day, for example, the Orlík Reservoir began intensive water release and increasing its retention capacity; at the start of the floods, the Vltava Cascade had storage volumes of around 180 million m³, nearly double the standard allocation. However, the high rainfall initially caused rivers in the Pilsen area to overflow – perhaps with the exception of the Mže River. On Tuesday, June 4, the release from the cascade was halted to ease the peak flow on the lower Elbe, but from June 7 to June 11, the Central Crisis Staff's directive to ensure maximum possible retention capacities in case of further heavy rainfall was reinstated. During these four days, the Vltava Cascade managed to empty 215 million m³. The flood also affected the Troja slalom canal.

Úslava in Prádlo reached the 1st flood stage (140 cm) already on Friday, May 31, 2013, after noon. Although it briefly dropped on Saturday, by 9:00 PM it was already at the 3rd flood stage (180 cm) and continued to rise slowly throughout Sunday, reaching its maximum on Monday at 1:00 AM: 225 cm, 22 m³/s (two-year water). The 3rd flood stage was left only on Tuesday evening, June 4, and the 1st flood stage on Thursday morning, June 6. In Ždírec, only the 2nd flood stage was reached with 33 m³/s; the flood state lasted from June 1, 4:00 PM to June 6, 10:00 AM. However, in Koterov, Úslava was at the 1st flood stage already on May 31 at 6:00 AM, and from Saturday 11:00 PM to Tuesday 10:00 PM, it was at the 3rd flood stage (above 200 cm), with a maximum of 270 cm / 132 m³/s on Monday around 4:00 AM. It returned to normal on Thursday after 3:00 AM. Úhlava also rose, exceeding the 1st flood stage (250 cm) in Klatovy on Friday morning, May 31, and the 3rd flood stage (300 cm) on Sunday at 5:00 AM, maintaining it until Monday evening with a peak of 315 cm / 69 m³/s, dropping below the 1st flood stage on Thursday after 7:00 PM. The limnigraph in Přeštice recorded the 1st flood stage (180 cm) on Friday morning, the 3rd flood stage (250 cm) after midnight on Saturday, and a peak of 315 cm / 160 m³/s (twenty-year water) on Monday morning. The 3rd flood stage was canceled on June 5 after 6:00 PM, and the 1st flood stage on Saturday, June 8, around 2:00 PM. In Štěnovice, the 1st flood stage (160 cm) was exceeded on Friday after 7:00 PM, the 3rd flood stage (320 cm) on Sunday around 5:00 PM, and the peak occurred on June 3 at 2:30 AM at 370 cm / 170 m³/s (more than twenty-year water). Radbuza in Tasnovice surpassed the 1st flood stage (120 cm) already on Friday, May 31, before 6:00 PM, the 3rd flood stage (180 cm) on Monday, June 3, between 2:00 AM and 2:00 PM, with the river peaking around 4:00 AM at 280 cm / 48 m³/s (ten-year water). The 1st flood stage was canceled on June 4 after 7:00 PM and re-declared on Monday, June 10, after 9:00 AM, with a peak in the 2nd flood stage occurring on Tuesday, June 11, around 4:00 AM at 160 cm / 16 m³/s, and a drop below the 1st flood stage occurred the same day after 1:00 PM. In Staňkov, Radbuza reached the 1st flood stage (160 cm) even earlier, on Friday around 8:00 AM, and remained below the 3rd flood stage (220 cm) from Friday evening, exceeding it from Saturday 3:00 PM to Wednesday 6:00 AM, with a peak at 306 cm / 99 m³/s (almost ten-year water) on Monday after 7:00 PM. It returned to normal on Thursday, June 6, just after midnight, and fluctuated around the 1st flood stage again on Sunday, exceeding it on Monday, June 10, after 6:00 AM, and rising sharply to the 3rd flood stage within about ten hours, with a peak of 255 cm / 60 m³/s on Tuesday before noon. The water level then dropped even faster than it rose, and the 3rd flood stage was canceled five hours later, with the 1st flood stage canceled on Wednesday, June 12, at 7:00 AM. Mže was initially the calmest; for example, the Lučina reservoir recorded the 1st flood stage only briefly on Saturday, June 1. However, in Kočov, the river fluctuated, exceeding the 1st flood stage (120 cm) for several hours on Saturday, June 1, and reaching the 2nd flood stage on Monday, June 3, peaking there before 6:00 AM at 105 cm / 29 m³/s (almost five-year water) and returning below the 1st flood stage just before midnight. Due to the inflow from Úhlavka, however, it exceeded the 1st flood stage (150 cm) in Stříbro on Saturday evening, peaking on Monday after noon at 220 cm / 84 m³/s (two-year water, just below the 3rd flood stage), and dropped below the 1st flood stage only on June 6 after noon. The Hracholusky reservoir partially captured this wave, but after filling the reservoir, it had to start releasing water in the 1st flood stage range (above 200 cm) at a flow rate of 54 to 56 m³/s for several days, ending this release only on Friday, June 14, after 7:00 AM. Střela, which exceeded the 1st flood stage (120 cm) at the Žlutice reservoir outlet on Saturday, June 1, around 8:00 AM, peaked 48 hours later at 205 cm / 20 m³/s (two-year water) in the 2nd flood stage range. It returned to the 1st flood stage on Wednesday at noon and maintained an outflow of around 8 m³/s in the 1st flood stage range in the following days. In Čichořice, it exceeded the 1st flood stage on Saturday after 2:00 PM and left it on Wednesday after 9:00 PM, rising twice to the 2nd flood stage in the meantime and peaking on Tuesday, June 4, around 10:00 AM at 170 cm / 26 m³/s (two-year water). In Plasy, it was at the 1st flood stage (120 cm) from June 1, 2:00 PM, and from June 2, 6:00 AM to 12:00 PM, it was also in the 3rd flood stage (above 200 mm), with a peak of 230 cm / 60 m³/s around 8:00 AM. It returned to normal only on Friday, but new rains raised it again on Sunday, June 9, and it peaked on Monday, June 10, in the 2nd flood stage range at 190 cm / 43 m³/s, returning to normal on Wednesday, June 12, before 10:00 PM. Klabava in Hrádek u Rokycan was at the 1st flood stage already from Thursday evening, May 30, and subsequently fluctuated: for example, the 3rd flood stage was declared three times, reaching 215 cm / 53 m³/s (ten-year water) twice – on Saturday, June 1, before 11:00 PM, and on Sunday, June 2, before midnight; it dropped below the 1st flood stage only on Wednesday, June 5, in the afternoon. Further downstream, in Nová Huť, Klabava reached the 1st flood stage (120 cm) on Friday after 5:00 AM and the 3rd flood stage (200 cm) already that day at noon, peaking on Monday at 7:00 AM with a water level of 250 cm and a flow rate of 138 m³/s (twenty-year water), and returned to normal on Thursday after 9:00 PM. The second wave of rain raised it to the 1st flood stage in most places only for a few hours on Monday, June 10, but increased outflow from the Klabava reservoir caused a new peak of 210 cm / 48 m³/s (two-year water) in Nová Huť on Tuesday, June 11, after 7:00 AM. The 3rd flood stage was in effect there from 3:00 AM to 3:00 PM on the same day, and the 1st flood stage was definitively canceled on Wednesday, June 12, around 8:00 PM. It is therefore clear that the Berounka, as the collecting river for southwest Bohemia, could not avoid flooding. On Friday, May 31, after 2:00 PM, it reached the 1st flood stage (250 cm) in Plzeň, and on Sunday, June 2, after 6:00 PM, it reached the 3rd flood stage (450 cm), peaking on Monday, June 3, around 7:00 AM at 525 cm / 388 m³/s (ten-year water). Although it left the 3rd flood stage range on Wednesday, June 5, around 6:00 AM, it did not return to normal even by the end of the week despite a gradual decline. After taking in tens of cubic meters of water from Klabava and Střela, the Liblín limnigraph recorded the 1st flood stage (180 cm) on Friday after 3:00 PM, the 3rd flood stage (340 cm) on Sunday after 7:00 AM, and a maximum of 440 cm / 640 m³/s on Monday, June 3, at noon. The 3rd flood stage was canceled only on Wednesday morning, and the 1st flood stage even on Sunday after noon. Due to new intense rains, a new wave arrived, but this time the river only rose to the 2nd flood stage range, peaking with a flow rate of 290 m³/s on Tuesday, June 11, in the morning; it returned to normal only on Thursday, June 13, in the afternoon. A similar course was registered in Zbečno: the 1st flood stage (240 cm) was reached on Friday, May 31, before noon, the 3rd flood stage (400 cm) on Saturday, June 1, before midnight, and a maximum of 610 cm / 900 m³/s on Monday, June 3, after 8:00 PM. The 3rd flood stage lasted until Thursday at 5:00 AM, and in the following days, the river remained in the 1st flood stage range. On Monday, June 10, before 11:00 PM, it rose again to the 2nd flood stage range, peaking at 320 m³/s on Tuesday, June 11, after noon. It returned to normal only on Saturday, June 15, around 1:00 AM. Litavka only reached the 1st flood stage thanks to the flood on the upper course being slowed by the Láz reservoir. In Příbram, the peak occurred at 74 cm / 5 m³/s on Monday after 5:00 PM, but due to streams from the Brdy area, it rose to the 1st flood stage (150 cm) on the inflow to Beroun on Saturday and to the 3rd flood stage (250 cm) on Sunday evening, peaking on Monday just after midnight at 260 cm / 145 m³/s (ten-year water) and quickly dropping, falling below the 1st flood stage on Tuesday, June 4, at 9:00 PM. On the Berounka in Beroun, the 1st flood stage (260 cm) was exceeded on Friday after 8:00 PM, and the 3rd flood stage (400 cm) at the turn of Saturday and Sunday, with the highest level reached on Monday at 9:30 PM at 577 cm / 1150 m³/s (more than twenty-year water). The 3rd flood stage was canceled only on Wednesday, June 5, after 5:00 PM, and the 1st flood stage on Saturday, June 8, before 6:00 PM. However, a new flood occurred shortly after, and the river peaked again on Tuesday, June 11, after 2:00 PM, this time in the 2nd flood stage range with a flow rate of over 320 m³/s. The 1st flood stage was then canceled on Thursday, June 13, before noon.

The Cold Vltava reached only the 1st flood activity stage (SPA) at the Černý Kříž limnigraph on the morning of Saturday, June 1, 2013, and maintained it until the evening, when it dropped again. In contrast, the Warm Vltava in Lenora was already rising at that time, reaching the 1st SPA (130 cm) after 11 p.m. on June 1, and by around 7 a.m. on Sunday, June 2, it reached the 2nd SPA (170 cm), peaking around 9 a.m. at 176 cm / 63 m³/s, narrowly surpassing the threshold of a ten-year flood. It dropped below the 1st SPA here on the evening of Monday, June 3. At the Chlum limnigraph, the 1st SPA (220 cm) was recorded only on June 2 at 7 a.m., and the water level narrowly (did not) reached the 3rd SPA (270 cm) after 12 p.m. with a flow rate of 90 m³/s (surpassing a five-year flood), then slowly decreased, with the 1st SPA being canceled only on Tuesday, June 4, before 6 a.m. The entire Vltava cascade showed a free volume of about 180 million cubic meters on Saturday, June 1. The flood wave from both Vltavas was partially mitigated by the Lipno Reservoir: in Vyšší Brod, the 1st SPA (185 cm) was exceeded only on June 2 between 6 and 11 a.m., but due to the increase in the retention capacity of the Lipno Reservoir, it was reached again around 6 p.m., and after midnight, the 2nd SPA (210 cm) was also exceeded; from then on, the flow (or outflow) ranged at the level of a two-year flood between 98 and 106 m³/s, increasing to 120 m³/s from Wednesday evening, and as the water receded in the lower reaches, water managers were able to increase the outflow from Lipno to 130 m³/s (from Friday morning, June 7, to Sunday morning, June 9) at the level of the 3rd SPA, which, however, did not cause major problems in other locations. High outflows from Lipno continued into the following week, approximately 110 m³/s until Wednesday, June 12, and only with a drop below 80 m³/s on Thursday evening, June 13, could the 1st SPA be canceled here. In Zátoň, the Vltava rose to the 1st SPA (160 cm) at 4 a.m. on Sunday, June 2, and between 8 a.m. and 3 p.m., it even maintained the 3rd SPA (210 cm) at 230 cm and 200 m³/s, oscillating in the 2nd SPA range in the following days due to the release from the Lipno Reservoir with a flow rate of up to 160 m³/s (i.e., again a two-year flood), later in the 1st SPA range with flow rates of 110–140 m³/s, and the river dropped below the 1st SPA here at noon on Thursday, June 13. A few kilometers downstream, the Vltava met the flood wave from the Polečnice (45 m³/s in Novosedly around 10 a.m. on Sunday) and the Chvalšinský stream (23 m³/s in Chvalšiny at the same time), so the Polečnice rushed into Český Krumlov as a swollen stream – it exceeded the 1st SPA (100 cm) before midnight on June 1 and reached the 3rd SPA (170 cm) around 3 a.m. on Sunday, peaking at 290 cm / 101 m³/s before noon and leaving the 3rd SPA only on Monday, June 3, after 9 a.m., and the 1st SPA on Wednesday, June 5, after 10 p.m. The Vltava was not to be outdone; in Spolí, the local 1st SPA (185 cm) was exceeded shortly after midnight on Sunday, June 2, and the 3rd SPA before 4 a.m., with the Vltava peaking at 290 cm / 310 m³/s simultaneously with the Polečnice; both exceeded the twenty-year flood level. The Vltava then maintained the 3rd SPA here until Wednesday, June 12, and returned to normal only on Friday, June 14, before noon. Above České Budějovice, the 1st SPA (170 cm) was also exceeded in Březí after midnight, and by 3 p.m., the water level briefly approached the 3rd SPA! (337 cm), the extreme flood threshold, with a height of 324 cm, and the flow rate at that time was over 480 m³/s (almost a fifty-year flood), with the 3rd SPA being canceled only on Tuesday, June 4, after 2 p.m.; the Vltava maintained the 2nd SPA (above 200 cm) until Sunday and dropped below the 1st SPA only on Wednesday, June 12, before midnight. The Malše in Kaplice reached the 1st SPA (110 cm) shortly after midnight on June 2, 2013, exceeded the 3rd SPA (160 cm) at 3 a.m., and the water level continued to rise to a maximum after 6 p.m. at 237 cm / 82 m³/s, with the 3rd SPA lasting until Monday afternoon and the 1st SPA until Wednesday evening. The subsequent limnigraph in Pořešín (already below the confluence with the also swollen Černá stream) recorded the 1st SPA (130 cm) at 1 a.m., the 3rd SPA (190 cm) was exceeded about 1.5 hours later, and the peak occurred around 6 p.m. at 300 cm / 178 m³/s, with the 3rd SPA lasting until Tuesday at 5 p.m. and the 1st SPA until Thursday at 7 a.m. Additional cubic meters were added by the Stropnice, which exceeded the 1st SPA (180 cm) in Borovany on Sunday before 6 a.m. and the 3rd SPA (260 cm) 24 hours later, peaking on Monday, June 3, after 6 p.m. at 315 cm / 30 m³/s (a two-year flood) and remaining in the 3rd SPA range until Wednesday noon, dropping below the 1st SPA only on Sunday before 4 a.m. Similarly, at the Pašinovice-Komařice station, it peaked twice: 345 cm / 106 m³/s (a ten-year flood) on Sunday afternoon and 286 cm / 67 m³/s on Tuesday after midnight, with the Stropnice dropping below the 3rd SPA on Wednesday around 4 p.m. and below the 1st SPA on Thursday before midnight. The last Malše limnigraph before the confluence with the Vltava, in Roudné, recorded the 1st SPA (160 cm) already on June 1, 2013, after 11 p.m., the 3rd SPA (270 cm) was exceeded at 3 a.m., and the Malše maintained it until Wednesday at 5 p.m., peaking at the level of a ten-year flood on Monday, June 3, after 2 a.m. at 380 cm / 230 m³/s. It returned to normal only on Saturday, June 8, at noon. In České Budějovice, the main flood waves from the Vltava and Malše combined, but only briefly: the 1st SPA (300 cm) was recorded on Sunday, June 2, after 3 a.m., and the 3rd SPA (430 cm) shortly before noon, with the peak occurring around 7 p.m. at 490 cm / 580 m³/s (a twenty-year flood), and then the water quickly receded; the 3rd SPA was canceled on Monday after 2 a.m., and the 1st SPA on Wednesday at 6 p.m. Despite high outflows from Lipno and Římov and the persistent 2nd SPA on the Vltava and Malše, the river below České Budějovice remained at a relatively safe level, below the 1st SPA.

Blanice (tributary of Otava) rose rapidly from Saturday afternoon, surpassing the 1st flood stage (120 cm) at Blanický Mill on Saturday before 9 PM and the 3rd flood stage (180 cm) shortly after midnight, reaching a maximum of 249 cm / 60 m³/s (twenty-year water) around 10 AM. The 3rd flood stage was canceled on June 3 before 3 AM, and the 1st flood stage on June 4 after 10 PM. At the Husinec reservoir outflow, Blanice held the 1st flood stage (95 cm) on the morning of June 2, quickly rising to the 3rd flood stage (130 cm) by 1 PM and reaching 250 cm with a flow of up to 95 m³/s (fifty-year water) after 3 PM. It dropped below the 3rd flood stage only on June 6 after 10 AM and below the 1st flood stage on Friday after 9 PM. In Bavorov, Blanice reached the 1st flood stage (140 cm) on Saturday before 10 PM, the 3rd flood stage (190 cm) on Sunday after 3 AM, and rose to 300 cm / 185 m³/s (more than fifty-year water) at 5:30 PM. The 3rd flood stage was canceled only on June 6 after 7 PM, and later the river fell to the 1st flood stage. However, a new wave of rain raised Blanice again to the 3rd flood stage on Monday evening, June 10, with a new peak at 240 cm / 103 m³/s (more than ten-year water) on Tuesday, June 11, around 2 AM. The river dropped below the 1st flood stage only on Wednesday, June 12, before 6 PM. At the Heřmaň station, the 1st flood stage (110 cm) was reached on June 1, 2013, at 11 PM, and the 3rd flood stage (180 cm) on Sunday after 8 AM. Twenty-four hours later, the maximum was reached at 275 cm (the 3rd flood stage threshold is 288 cm) / 200 m³/s, i.e., fifty-year water. The 3rd flood stage persisted until Friday at 3 AM, but the river did not return to normal by the end of the week and rose again to the 3rd flood stage on Tuesday, June 11, after noon, peaking at 190 cm / 84 m³/s (five-year water) at midnight, and within five hours, the river dropped below the 3rd flood stage, returning below the 1st flood stage only on Thursday, June 13, after 1 PM. The Otava itself reached the 1st flood stage (140 cm) in Rejštejn only on June 1, 2013, around 11 PM, and on Sunday, it occasionally reached the 2nd flood stage, peaking after 7 PM at 170 cm / 111 m³/s, and returned to normal after 6 AM on Monday. In Sušice, the 1st flood stage was reached on Saturday at 10 PM, and the 3rd flood stage (175 cm) was reached twice on Sunday, with a maximum of 220 cm and 205 m³/s (almost ten-year water) at 9 PM. The 3rd flood stage was canceled on June 3 at 5 AM, and the 1st flood stage on June 4 before noon. Below the confluence with Blanice, in Písek, the Otava has the 1st flood stage set at 250 cm (reached on June 2, 2013, at 1:30 AM), the 3rd flood stage at 380 cm (exceeded after 3 PM), and a maximum of 525 cm / 545 m³/s (more than twenty-year water) was reached on Monday after noon. It returned below the 3rd flood stage on Wednesday after 8 AM and below the 1st flood stage 72 hours later. A new flood from Blanice then slightly raised the Otava into the 1st flood stage zone on Monday evening, June 10, which was also canceled on Wednesday morning, June 12. The Nežárka in Rodvínov reached the 1st flood stage on Sunday, June 2, at noon, peaking at 160 cm (just surpassing the 3rd flood stage) / 47 m³/s on Monday at 6 AM, and dropped below the 1st flood stage on Wednesday after 4 AM. After receiving twenty-year water from the Hamerský stream (approximately 19 / 20 m³/s from Monday evening to Wednesday morning), the Lásenice limnigraph recorded the 1st flood stage (150 mm) on Sunday, June 2, at 5 AM, and narrowly reached the 3rd flood stage (230 cm) on Monday for about 11 hours, with a flow of 73 m³/s (more than five-year water). The flood state lasted until Friday at 11 AM. On the Nová River, which relieved the Lužnice, the 3rd flood stage was in place in Mláka from Tuesday, with a maximum of 330 cm / 75 m³/s (ten-year water) on Wednesday morning. The water level dropped very slowly, and the 3rd flood stage was canceled only on Saturday afternoon. However, around 55 to 60 m³/s continued to flow, on Tuesday, June 11, even just 45 m³/s (1st flood stage), but on Thursday, June 13, again up to 55 m³/s (2nd flood stage again). This amount decreased only slowly, and the 1st flood stage was canceled only on Sunday, June 16, at 6 PM. Similarly, the Hamr limnigraph reached the 1st flood stage (290 cm) on Sunday, June 2, at 10 PM, and the 3rd flood stage (350 cm) on Monday after 1 PM, peaking on June 5 at 7 AM at 424 cm / 148 m³/s (twenty-year water). The 3rd flood stage persisted until Monday, June 10, at 2 AM, and dropped below the 1st flood stage only on Saturday, June 15, at noon. The Lužnice was also flooded along its entire length. The Nová Ves limnigraph exceeded the 1st flood stage (150 cm) on June 2 around 1 PM, peaking at 202 cm / 98 m³/s (ten-year water) in the 2nd flood stage zone, and returned to normal on June 5 around 1 PM. The Pilař limnigraph exceeded the 1st flood stage (300 cm) on June 2 after 4 PM, the 3rd flood stage on June 3 at noon, and peaked at midnight at 420 cm / 131 m³/s (twenty-year water). It dropped below the 3rd flood stage on June 5 before noon and below the 1st flood stage only on Sunday after 1 PM. Thanks to the relief Nová River, however, the Kazdovna, Rožmberk, and Frahelž stations did not record a flood extreme worse than ten-year water. Below the confluence of the Nežárka and Lužnice, the Černovický stream also flowed into the river (where the Tučapy station recorded up to 13 m³/s on Sunday evening, June 2), and the Klenovice limnigraph easily exceeded the 1st flood stage (190 cm) on Sunday, June 2, around 2 AM, and the 3rd flood stage (300 cm) on Monday, June 3, at noon. The maximum of 330 cm / 220 m³/s (ten-year water) lasted from Wednesday noon to evening, and then the level slowly dropped. However, it returned below the 3rd flood stage only on Friday after 4 PM – temporarily, as the 3rd flood stage was again present on Sunday evening and was definitively left on Monday, June 10, before 3 AM. For most of the week, two-year water flowed here in the 2nd flood stage (canceled only on June 14 at 10:30 PM), and even on Sunday, June 16, the 1st flood stage persisted here. After the Lužnice was further strengthened by the Smutná stream (which had the 1st flood stage in Rataje from Saturday at 10 PM and the 3rd flood stage from Sunday at 4 AM to Tuesday at 3 AM; the maximum of 347 cm / 131 m³/s on Sunday, June 2, before noon even exceeded the 3rd flood stage and represented hundred-year water; the 1st flood stage ended only on Wednesday, June 5, at noon), the devastation in Bechyně was practically inevitable: the 1st flood stage (240 cm) was exceeded just before midnight on Saturday, and the 3rd flood stage (330 cm) on Sunday, June 2, at 3 AM. The 3rd flood stage threshold (525 cm) was exceeded at 9 AM, peaking after 3 PM with a water level height of over 590 cm and a flow of around 610 m³/s (hundred-year water exceeded). The 3rd flood stage lasted until Friday at 10 PM, and the water continued to drop only slowly. On Monday, June 10, it even returned to the 3rd flood stage for several hours, peaking at 340 cm / 200 m³/s (more than two-year water). It dropped below the 2nd flood stage only on Wednesday, June 12, and the 1st flood stage was approached only on Sunday evening, June 16. To the Orlík reservoir, where the waters of all three rivers converge, about 1500 m³/s was heading on Sunday afternoon. Therefore, a reserve was already made for this wave by increasing the outflow – on June 2, 2013, at 6 AM, up to 350 m³/s was released, but this outflow had to be quickly reduced to 178 m³/s to protect other places along the flow. However, the reservoir filled unexpectedly quickly: the predicted inflow maximum of 910 m³/s had to be revised several times due to heavy rains and the rapid rise of all tributaries, and the real maximum at the level of hundred-year water (2300 m³/s) occurred during Sunday. The reservoir's retention space was used to the maximum (the level stopped 2 cm below the maximum), and from Sunday evening, it was necessary to release 1400 to 1700 m³/s again, peaking at up to 1950 m³/s on the night from Monday to Tuesday. This gradually emptied the Orlík retention space, and by Sunday morning, the outflow could already drop to "only" 650 m³/s, on Tuesday, June 12, to 320 m³/s, and then temporarily rose to 500 m³/s, later dropping to normal values below 300 m³/s. This wave was not significantly slowed down even by the Slapy Reservoir, which maintained most of the day outflow at 205 or 305 m³/s on Saturday, June 1, and Sunday, June 2. However, on Sunday afternoon, 380 m³/s was already being released here, and from the evening up to 1600 m³/s, later up to 2050 m³/s on the night to Tuesday. Here too, the reservoir's storage space was increased, and the outflow could gradually be reduced, from Saturday evening, June 8, to 1000 m³/s, and on Sunday even to 900 m³/s, later 650 m³/s or less. The Sázava sent additional masses of water into the Vltava already on Sunday afternoon. The Český Šternberk station recorded the 1st flood stage (100 cm) on Sunday before noon and the 3rd flood stage (160 cm) shortly after noon, peaking at 227 cm / 370 m³/s (ten-year water) before 10 PM. Then the level quickly dropped, the 3rd flood stage was left already on Monday, June 3, at 4 AM, and the 1st flood stage 48 hours later. The Nespeky limnigraph recorded the 1st flood stage (230 cm) on Sunday, June 2, after 3 AM, and the 3rd flood stage (380 cm) was maintained from noon, peaking on Monday at 4 AM at 540 cm / 510 m³/s. The 3rd flood stage lasted until Tuesday at 11 PM, and the 1st flood stage until Saturday at 10 PM. The Kocába also significantly flooded on Sunday, June 2, 2013. The previous day at 6 PM, it exceeded the 1st flood stage (110 cm) in Štěchovice, and on Sunday after 6 AM, the 3rd flood stage (150 cm), peaking before 6 PM at 240 cm / 104 m³/s (hundred-year water exceeded). It returned below the 3rd flood stage on Wednesday after 1 AM and below the 1st flood stage on Friday, June 8, around 4 AM. The Vrané Reservoir tried to balance the flood wave from the unregulated Berounka, which flows into the Vltava a few kilometers below it. On the night from Saturday, June 1, to Sunday, June 2, it had an outflow of up to 500 m³/s, but this quickly rose during the day, exceeding 1000 m³/s after 2 PM, and by 5 PM, 1290 m³/s was being released to Prague. At 7 PM, only 954 m³/s, but by 8 PM, already 1712 m³/s. The subsequent extreme flood then disabled the flow meter.

The water level gradually rose in Prague as well, for which the city had prepared in advance: the city council cleared the embankments and closed Čertovka.[15] The limnigraph at Malá Chuchle recorded the 1st flood stage (130 cm) already on Friday, May 31, 2013, at noon, and the 3rd flood stage (307 cm) was exceeded 48 hours later with a flow rate of 1500 m³/s. During Saturday, boats were being removed from the Vltava River in Prague[13], and on Sunday at 9:45, the mayor declared a "State of Danger" for the capital city[6]. By the afternoon, the water level in Chuchle had reached 350 cm with a flow rate of over 1770 m³/s. Thanks to the management of the Vltava Cascade, the flow rate through Prague was maintained at 2100 m³/s for a long time, reaching 2900 m³/s on Sunday evening[13]. However, the uncontrolled tributaries of the Vltava, especially the Berounka, Botič (which flooded areas like Hostivař and Záběhlice), and Rokytka, swelled significantly. The Vltava peaked in Prague on Tuesday, June 4, at 3:50 a.m., with a flow rate of 3210 m³/s and a water level of 545 cm (the 3rd flood stage threshold here is 574 cm)[13]. Afterward, the flow rate sharply decreased as the management of the Vltava Cascade gradually managed to balance the uncontrolled tributaries from the Berounka or free up reservoir spaces in dams for the forecasted new rains. It dropped below the 3rd flood stage only on Saturday, June 8, after noon, with the flow rate decreasing from 1600 to 1250 m³/s within three hours. On Monday, June 10, it briefly dropped to the 1st flood stage, but a new wave of water due to further rains raised the level back to the 2nd flood stage on Tuesday, June 11, with a maximum of "only" 240 cm / 1008 m³/s. However, it was not until Sunday, June 16, before 3 a.m., that the water dropped below the 1st flood stage. The limnigraph in the center of Prague, near Na Františku Hospital, recorded an increase from 300 cm / 500 m³/s on Friday, May 31, at night to 547 cm / 3193 m³/s on Tuesday, June 4, at 7:00 a.m., which was the peak there. The Prague Public Transit Company had already suspended tram service to Troja on Saturday, and on Sunday, June 2, it closed the first 8 metro stations (trains only passed through them).[16] On Monday, June 3, metro service in the city center was completely halted. The metro stopped running in the sections Dejvická – Muzeum, Smíchovské nádraží – Českomoravská, and Muzeum – Kobylisy. Some tram lines were also canceled.[17] As a replacement for the metro, two substitute tram lines (X-A, X-B) and one bus line (X-C) were established, and tram service was suspended in some sections (Palmovka – Ke Stírce, the line to Modřany). All ferry services were suspended. Ferries P3 and P5 were restored during June, ferry P6 was reopened on July 13, 2013, and ferries P1 and P2 were expected to be operational by July 20, 2013.[18][19]

On the weekend of June 1st (until June 3rd), most animals were evacuated from the lower part of Prague Zoo. Only the gorillas were temporarily confined in the flood tower of their pavilion. During the week, some of the evacuated animals were transferred to zoos in Brno, Olomouc, Ústí nad Labem, and Dvůr Králové nad Labem.

As soon as the Vltava River left the relatively narrow valley above Roztoky near Prague, it began flooding the surrounding areas. Kralupy nad Vltavou was significantly affected, with even road junctions submerged. The limnigraph at Vraňany has the 1st flood stage (SPA) set at 370 cm (reached on Saturday, June 1) and the 3rd SPA at 610 cm (exceeded on Sunday, June 2), with the Vltava's water level peaking at 785 cm / 3100 m³/s on Tuesday, June 4, around 11 a.m. Only a few centimeters separated the basin from declaring the 3rd SPA! (792 cm), and the fifty-year flood level (3490 m³/s) was not exceeded either. The Vltava at Vraňany dropped below the 3rd SPA on Saturday, June 8, after 8 p.m., below the 2nd SPA on Tuesday, June 12, before 3 a.m., and below the 1st SPA on Friday, June 14, around 10 p.m.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the Ohře River Basin

Whole_Text.content: The level of the Ohře River gradually rose from May 31, 2013. In Cheb, it exceeded the 1st flood stage (158 cm) around 9 p.m., peaked at 220 cm and 50 m³/s in the 2nd flood stage zone during the night, and then gradually decreased on Sunday. On Tuesday, June 4, water managers maintained the outflow from the Skalka reservoir just below the 1st flood stage level. Similarly, the Svatava River exceeded the 1st flood stage (94 cm) at the Kraslice gauge on Saturday, June 1, 2013, at 11 p.m., and peaked on Sunday around 9 a.m. with a water level of 138 cm and a flow rate of 55 m³/s (a twenty-year flood), returning to normal on Tuesday after 3 a.m. Conversely, the Odrava River could not be regulated further at the Jesenice reservoir near Cheb: it exceeded the 1st flood stage (80 cm) on May 31 before 9 p.m. and rose slowly, exceeding the 3rd flood stage (170 cm) on Tuesday, June 4, and peaked at midnight at 190 cm and 29 m³/s, which corresponds to a two-year flood. It left the 3rd flood stage on Wednesday, June 5, after 9 p.m., and remained at the 1st flood stage until the following week. New rains on Tuesday, June 11, raised the water level to the 3rd flood stage for several hours during the night, but flow rates remained well below 20 m³/s. The Teplá River increased its flow throughout Sunday, June 2, and remained in the 1st flood stage along its entire length, with its inflow into the Ohře reaching up to 44 m³/s on Monday morning. As a result, the Drahovice gauge on the Ohře exceeded the 1st flood stage (190 cm) shortly after midnight on Saturday and the 3rd flood stage (270 cm) after midnight on Sunday. The maximum was 273 cm / 275 m³/s (a five-year flood) on Sunday, June 3, around 3 a.m., but the water level soon dropped, and the 3rd flood stage was canceled around 7 a.m. The Ohře returned to normal on Thursday, June 6, around 3 a.m. The Rolava River temporarily reached the 1st flood stage on Sunday morning, peaking at 180 cm / 58 m³/s (a ten-year flood) around 4 a.m. The lower-lying Klášterec nad Ohří recorded a maximum on Monday, June 3, around 7 a.m., at 272 cm / 402 m³/s (a five-year flood), and dropped sharply to normal levels during Tuesday and Wednesday. The Chomutovka River exceeded the 1st flood stage on Saturday evening and remained at the 2nd flood stage for about thirty hours, leaving the flood stage on Tuesday evening (peaking on Sunday afternoon with a ten-year flood at 118 cm / 20 m³/s). Meanwhile, in Žatec, the 1st flood stage on the Ohře did not need to be declared despite a flow rate of 275 m³/s (a two-year flood). However, below the confluence of the Ohře, Chomutovka, and Blšanka in Louny, the Ohře exceeded the 1st flood stage (400 cm) on Saturday around 6 p.m. and the 3rd flood stage (490 cm) on Monday at 10 p.m. At a water level of 545 cm, the flow rate reached up to 316 m³/s but did not exceed a two-year flood. The 3rd flood stage was maintained until Friday, June 7, when it began to drop at noon, and alternated between the 2nd and 1st flood stages until the following week. The flood stage ended on Thursday, June 13, before 4 p.m. The last gauge before the Elbe, Brozany, also showed increasing flow and peaked on Thursday, June 6, between 3 and 9 a.m., at 394 cm / 340 m³/s, dropping to a normal level of 280 cm / 195 m³/s by Sunday morning. Two new small peaks due to new rains occurred on Monday, June 10, and Tuesday, June 11, in the evening, but only reached approximately 300 cm / 220 m³/s.

The Bílina in Jirkov briefly exceeded the 1st flood stage (60 cm) during Sunday morning and again on the night from Monday to Tuesday, but the flow did not exceed 5 m³/s. The inflow of the Bílý potok was much more significant, which on Saturday evening increased from the usual half-cubic-meter flow to ten times that, exceeded the 1st flood stage (63 cm), and on June 3rd around 3 PM approached the 3rd flood stage (85 cm) with a flow over 10 m³/s; it left the flood stage only on June 6th around 2 AM. In Bílina, for most of Sunday, June 2nd, the water level was at 180 cm / 28 m³/s, and from Monday evening to Tuesday afternoon, it maintained a peak level of 200 cm / 37 m³/s (more than a twenty-year water level). In Trmice, the 1st flood stage (170 cm) was reached on Saturday, June 1st, around 1 PM, and by Monday afternoon, even the 3rd flood stage (230 cm) was reached, with the water level steadily rising; the peak of 275 cm / 62 m³/s (again more than a twenty-year water level) was reached on Wednesday, June 5th, in the morning, but the 3rd flood stage lasted until Thursday at 9 PM, and the river only managed to leave the 1st flood stage on Tuesday, June 11th, before 3 PM.

The Ploučnice River exceeded the 1st flood stage (100 cm) in Stráž pod Ralskem on the afternoon of June 1, 2013. By Sunday before 6 p.m., it surpassed the 3rd flood stage (170 cm) and peaked at 182 cm with a flow rate of 25 m³/s at 9 p.m., then began to recede, leaving the flood stage on Tuesday after 6 p.m. A few kilometers downstream in Mimoň, however, it picked up a flood wave (up to 17 m³/s) from the Panenský Stream, reaching the 1st flood stage (90 cm) on Saturday afternoon, surpassing the 3rd flood stage (145 cm) on Sunday afternoon, and peaking on Monday, June 3, before 5 a.m. at 165 cm / 37 m³/s. The high water then moved toward Česká Lípa, where the 1st flood stage (70 cm) was declared at 8 a.m., and later the river fluctuated at the 2nd flood stage with a flow rate of 42 m³/s (one-year water) at a water level of 105 cm. The flood stage was canceled only on Wednesday, June 5. The limnigraph in Benešov nad Ploučnicí recorded a significantly prolonged flood, remaining at the 1st flood stage (above 140 cm) from June 1, 1 p.m., to June 4, 10 p.m., with a maximum flow rate of 96 m³/s (five-year water) recorded on Sunday at noon. The Mandava River in Varnsdorf fluctuated significantly starting Thursday, May 30, 2013, exceeding the 1st flood stage (70 cm) on May 31, then receding, surpassing it again on Saturday, June 1, and exceeding the 3rd flood stage (110 cm) on Sunday, June 2, 2013, after noon. It peaked at 115 cm / 21.5 m³/s (two-year water) at 1 p.m. and then slowly receded, leaving the flood stage on June 4 before 11 p.m. The Chřibská Kamenice River showed elevated levels but did not reach flood stage. Similarly, the Srbská Kamenice River did not experience significant extremes: on both Saturday, June 1, and Sunday, June 2, it briefly reached the 1st flood stage (120 cm) and the 2nd flood stage (145 cm) for only a few hours. The highest flow rate of 36 m³/s (twenty-year water) at a water level of 157 cm occurred on Saturday around 4 p.m.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the Elbe River Basin

Whole_Text.content: The Elbe, according to the limnigraph in Vestřev, reached the 1st flood activity level (SPA) (110 cm) on June 1, 2013, before midnight, with a peak at SPA 3! (SPA 3 here is 160 cm and SPA 3! is 349 cm) following on June 2, 2013, at 8:00 a.m. with a water level of 354 cm and a flow rate of 310 m³/s, which meant more than a hundred-year flood. The water then quickly receded, and SPA 3 was canceled the same day before 11 p.m., with the Elbe returning below SPA 1 on Monday after 7 p.m. However, the Elbe itself caused almost no damage – the problem was caused by the left-bank tributary, the Čistá stream: after a night of continuous downpour, it unexpectedly gathered a large amount of water from Hertvíkovice on Sunday morning, and a wave of water rushed through Rudník and Arnultovice to Hostinné, where the water rose 3 meters above normal at 7:00 a.m., and the immediate water flow in the Elbe was more than 260 m³/s (instead of the usual 3–4 m³/s), but within the next 6 hours, it had already dropped by half. An army helicopter had to assist with the evacuation of residents. This flood wave then moved along the Elbe and dispersed; the Les Království dam reached SPA 1 (150 cm) on June 2, 2013, before 3 a.m., but SPA 3 (180 cm) was declared just two hours later. After 10 a.m., the water level stabilized for the entire day at around 233 cm and an outflow of about 147 m³/s (more than a ten-year flood). On Monday, June 3, the Elbe quickly receded, and SPA 3 was canceled after 3 p.m., SPA 1 after 9 p.m. Another limnigraph in Brod recorded SPA 1 (300 cm) at 4 a.m., SPA 3 (370 cm) around 7:30 a.m., and the water level continued to rise, reaching 470 cm and 140 m³/s at 5 p.m., which meant a five-year flood. This level was maintained by the Elbe until Monday morning, after which it began to drop rapidly, and on the morning of June 4, 2013, the water level fell below SPA 1.

The Úpa River narrowly avoided the declaration of the third flood stage (SPA) in its upper course: after an extreme 123 mm of rainfall fell in the Horní Maršov area during the night of June 1-2 within 24 hours, smaller tributaries of the Úpa almost reached tropical proportions, causing landslides and flooding the Maršov square. The Úpa River in Horní Maršov reached a water level of 157 cm with a flow rate of 53 m³/s (just under a five-year flood; the limit for the third SPA here is 160 cm) on June 2 at 2 a.m., and although the level dropped to 97 cm two hours later, a new peak occurred the same day at noon at 152 cm / 51 m³/s, after which the level dropped again almost to normal. Volunteer firefighters from the village, who ironically had celebrated the 140th anniversary of their brigade the day before, organized rescue operations during the night, including moving cars, clearing blocked bridges, etc. In the Lysečinský stream, they even searched for a shepherd swept away by water along with a piece of meadow from which he tried to save a tied goat – he survived with injuries. A few kilometers downstream in Svoboda nad Úpou, however, the situation was much worse: the same all-night downpour that caused a flash flood in Rudník and Hostinné also washed away several tourist trails on the slopes of Černá hora (e.g., a two-kilometer section of the cobbled Zvonková trail to a depth of up to 120 cm) and sent a landslide directly into the Černohorský stream. The water and stones first "excavated" the streambed in Těsný důl and its banks to a height of about three meters, clearing decades-old deposits, then gained high speed in the regulated section of the stream along the road. Water, sand, and smaller pebbles acted as perfect sliding bearings for ton-sized stone blocks, so this torrent destroyed everything in its path to the Úpa, including stone walls and several small bridges. At the site near the Prom Hotel, where the streambed begins to be covered, the boulders lost speed and quickly got stuck, with gaps between them clogged by finer material, causing the stream to find a new path not only through the hotel grounds but also along the recently repaired road II/297, which partially turned into a new streambed in the section between Janské Lázně and Svoboda nad Úpou. The connecting road II/296 to Trutnov was also damaged, and dozens of properties were affected, with Svoboda's mayor Jiří Špetla estimating damages at tens of millions of crowns at the time. Clearing the blocked covered streambed in Svoboda took about three days, with the greatest credit going to amateur cavers who uncovered the deposits from below and managed to loosen the stone blocks enough to be pulled away by heavy machinery using cables. Several dozen kilometers downstream in Zlíč, where the Úpa transitions from a mountainous to a flatter region, the river exceeded its first SPA (130 cm) at 3 a.m., the third SPA (210 cm) before 6 a.m., and peaked at 220 cm / 77 m³/s (a two-year flood) around 10 p.m. on Sunday. It returned below the first SPA only on Wednesday after 8 p.m. Flood waves from the Elbe and Úpa rivers met at their confluence in Jaroměř, where the Elbe peaked at 370 cm / 240 m³/s (a ten-year flood) after midnight on June 3, while the Úpa contributed 77 m³/s at the same time, and the Metuje added its share of 73 m³/s (although it exceeded the first SPA on the Hronov and Krčín limnigraphs on Sunday by a maximum of 10 cm and for no more than 12 hours). However, all rivers dropped relatively quickly during Monday. This surge of water in Jaroměř caused the historic steel bridge from 1884 to collapse, as the Elbe undermined one of its pillars during the night on Monday, breaking the bridge, with one side walkway even falling into the water and being recovered with two heavy cranes only on Monday evening. The rest of the bridge was demolished during June and July. A new bridge was opened in March 2015.

The Javorka stream overflowed its banks after an overnight rain on June 2, 2013. In Lázně Bělohrad, it reached the 1st flood stage (90 cm) around 4:30 AM and the 3rd flood stage (150 cm) after 6:00 AM, peaking at 165 cm / 18.3 m³/s shortly thereafter. By 7:00 PM, even the 1st flood stage was canceled. The Cidlina in Jičín exceeded the 1st flood stage (55 cm) only on Sunday afternoon, with a flow not exceeding 3.5 m³/s, and returned to normal on Monday. However, the limnigraph in Nový Bydžov, located downstream of the confluence with the Javorka, exceeded the 1st flood stage (150 cm) as early as 4:00 AM and rose steeply throughout Sunday. The 3rd flood stage (230 cm) was exceeded on Monday after 5:00 AM, and by the morning, it surpassed the 3rd flood stage. The maximum at 1:00 PM was 285 cm / 91 m³/s (nearly a 20-year flood). Despite a slight decrease, the 3rd flood stage persisted into Tuesday, and the Cidlina returned below the 1st flood stage only on Thursday, June 6, after noon. Local thunderstorms the following weekend briefly raised it to the 1st flood stage again on Monday, June 10, but the flow did not exceed 33 m³/s, and by Tuesday, June 11, before midnight, it was back below the 1st flood stage. The Sány station, located about 7 km before the confluence with the also swollen Elbe, recorded the 1st flood stage (190 cm) on Sunday, June 2, before 11:00 AM, and the 3rd flood stage (230 cm) was exceeded at 2:00 PM. For the rest of the day, the water level remained around 233 cm, with a flow of approximately 58 m³/s. From Monday, the water level rose more rapidly, reaching a maximum of 325 cm / 147 m³/s (a 20-year flood) on Wednesday, June 5, after midnight, followed by a very slow decrease in water level. The 3rd flood stage persisted throughout Thursday, and only on Friday, June 7, did the Cidlina begin to drop rapidly, falling below the flood stage after 2:00 PM.

The Kamenice River, which drains water from the same area as the upper course of the Jizera River, recorded the 1st flood stage (90 cm) in Plavy on Saturday evening. On Sunday, between 1 a.m. and 7 a.m., it also reached the 2nd flood stage with a maximum water level of 119 cm and a flow rate of 51 m³/s, but it gradually decreased and fell below the 1st flood stage by Tuesday around noon. The Jizera River itself traditionally posed a threat, especially in Jablonec nad Jizerou, where the 1st flood stage (150 cm) was exceeded on Saturday evening, June 1, and the 3rd flood stage (210 cm) was reached on Sunday between 2 a.m. and 4 a.m., with a peak at 218 cm / 100 m³/s. Despite intense overnight rainfall, no other limnigraphs recorded such a strong flood. In Dolní Sytová, the 1st flood stage (180 cm) was exceeded from midnight to 8 a.m., with a maximum flow rate of 135 m³/s. Below the confluence of the Jizera and Kamenice Rivers above Železný Brod, the 2nd flood stage (above 310 cm) occurred on Sunday between 2 a.m. and 8 a.m., with the water level reaching 330 cm and a flow rate of 210 m³/s. By morning, the water level dropped back to the 1st flood stage, falling below its threshold (220 cm) on Tuesday, June 4, around 1 a.m. In Bakov, the 1st flood stage (480 cm) was exceeded before 8 a.m., and from 12 p.m. to 9 p.m., the river was at the 2nd flood stage, peaking at 518 cm / 186 m³/s around 5 p.m., which does not represent even a one-year flood event. Similarly, at the last limnigraph before the confluence with the Elbe River in Předměřice, the highest water level was recorded on Monday at noon, at 390 cm / 165 m³/s.

In the Pardubice region, the Labe limnigraph in Němčice recorded the exceeding of the 1st flood stage (350 cm) on Sunday, June 2, around 2:30 PM. On Monday morning, the water level slightly exceeded the 2nd flood stage, with the Labe peaking at noon at 415 cm / 340 m³/s. By Tuesday morning, June 4, it had dropped below the 1st flood stage. Similarly, in Přelouč, the 1st flood stage (240 cm) was exceeded on Sunday around 3:00 PM and was lifted on Tuesday afternoon, with the peak occurring on Monday afternoon at 295 cm / 320 m³/s. At both locations, this represented less than a two-year flood. However, several dozen kilometers further, the left-bank tributary of the Labe, Vrchlice, exceeded the 1st flood stage (105 cm) on Sunday after 11:00 AM, the 3rd flood stage (130 cm) was exceeded after noon, and the peak at 184 cm / 36 m³/s (a fifty-year flood) occurred after 7:00 PM. By Tuesday morning, the river had dropped below the 1st flood stage. 

The situation was more serious with the Výrovka stream, which in Plaňany exceeded the 1st flood stage (150 cm) after 9:00 AM and the 3rd flood stage (250 cm) after noon. On Sunday at 8:00 PM, it peaked at 453 cm / 122 m³/s (the hundred-year flood threshold here is 75 m³/s), and by Tuesday before noon, it had dropped below the 3rd flood stage, and by Thursday before 9:00 AM, it was below the 1st flood stage. 

Probably the worst situation was caused by the Mrlina stream above Nymburk: at the Vestec limnigraph, it exceeded the 1st flood stage (150 cm) on Sunday before noon and the 3rd flood stage (240 cm) after 8:00 PM. At 10:00 PM, the 3rd flood stage limit (271 cm) was also exceeded, and shortly after midnight on Monday, it reached 310 cm, which it maintained for several dozen hours. The peak occurred on Tuesday morning, June 4, at 314 cm and 85 m³/s (almost a hundred-year flood). Due to the threat of dam breaches in local ponds, a complete evacuation of residents was ordered in the village of Vestec, and later in the villages of Budiměřice, Křinec, Rašovice, and Šlotava. The Mrlina then receded relatively quickly, leaving the 3rd flood stage on Wednesday before noon and the 1st flood stage on Thursday before midnight. 

In Brandýs nad Labem, the water level rose relatively slowly. The 1st flood stage (280 cm) was surpassed early Sunday morning, with the peak in the 2nd flood stage range occurring on Tuesday, June 4, between 6:00 and 9:00 AM at 430 cm / 670 m³/s – roughly five times less than the Vltava at the same time. Nevertheless, preparations for the flood began in places like Neratovice and especially at the local chemical plant Spolana. During the 2002 floods, unexpected problems were caused not by the Labe itself but by its confluence with the Vltava – the overwhelming Vltava waters caused the "stopping" of the Labe's flow and its subsequent backflow, which significantly endangered places like Neratovice, located about 7 km above the confluence. During the 2013 floods, Spolana therefore preemptively halted production and, for example, moved chlorine and other substances to safety over the weekend.

In Mělník, where the waters of the Vltava and Elbe rivers meet, both flood waves naturally converged. In Mělník itself, the 1st flood stage (Elbe water level 400 cm) was declared at the turn of Saturday and Sunday, reaching the 3rd flood stage (550 cm) by the evening of Sunday, June 2, and the water level continued to rise steeply. The peak occurred on Wednesday, June 5, 2013, when the Elbe maintained a level of 930 cm from midnight until 7 a.m., with a flow rate exceeding 3900 m³/s, corresponding to more than a fifty-year flood. The inner part of Mělník was not threatened, but the high water flooding properties affected, for example, the local part of Mlazice. The receding flood from the Vltava allowed the 3rd flood stage to be lifted only on Monday, June 10, after 2 a.m., when the flow rate dropped below a two-year flood level, and the 1st flood stage was definitively canceled on Friday, June 14, after midnight. The flood gradually moved downstream. In Litoměřice, as with every flood, the area at the confluence of the Elbe and Ohře rivers (both rivers were flooded) was completely submerged, and the Tyrš Bridge was out of service because water flooded its left approach in Želetice, and the nearby left-bank village of Mlékojedy was also flooded. The new František Chábera road bridge remained fully operational. The water flooded not only the town of Terezín and its surroundings but also, on Wednesday, June 5, water from the Ohře penetrated its former riverbed in the fields into the village of Nové Kopisty, where it breached a temporarily built field embankment and reached beyond the main railway line from Prague to Děčín. In the Litoměřice area, the water completely overflowed the mobile flood barriers in the village of Křešice. The Litoměřice limnigraph below the Ohře inflow had to be disconnected from the power supply due to high water, so data from it was unavailable, but the limnigraph in Ústí nad Labem continued to operate and recorded the gradual rise in water level and flow rate – by midnight on Monday, June 3, it was already in the 3rd flood stage zone (water level above 600 cm), and the water kept rising. Due to the flooding of the left-bank four-lane road (carrying important roads I/30 and I/62), the Mariánský Bridge was first closed, and after surpassing the 800 cm mark, the Beneš Bridge was also closed, leaving the two parts of the city connected only via the old railway bridge, where motor units operated in a 10–15 minute shuttle between the Ústí nad Labem – Střekov and Ústí nad Labem – west stations for several days. The main Ústí nad Labem railway station was out of service due to the flooding of the ground-floor ticket hall and the entire forecourt area. On Wednesday, June 5, after surpassing the 10 m mark, the water breached the flood walls in the Střekov district and flooded residential houses there. The Elbe's peak occurred on the night of Wednesday, June 5, to Thursday, June 6, at a level of 10.8 m, with an instantaneous flow rate exceeding 3700 m³/s, and despite the catastrophic consequences for Ústí nad Labem, it was not yet a fifty-year flood (the 3rd flood stage threshold was just two centimeters away, and in 2002, up to 4700 m³/s flowed here). The water then receded very slowly as the flow rates from the upper Elbe, Vltava, Ohře, and Bílina decreased: the 3rd flood stage could only be lifted at midnight from Wednesday, June 12, to Thursday, June 13, the 2nd flood stage on Friday morning, June 14, and finally, the 1st flood stage on Saturday, June 15, after 4 p.m. Děčín was, of course, also affected, although the flood wave was progressing more slowly. The peak in Děčín occurred roughly three hours after the one in Ústí. Firefighters, with all their strength and full human and technical deployment, managed to keep the bridge on road I/13 operational.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the Nisa River Basin
Whole_Text.content: Traditionally, the most serious situation was in the Frýdlant region: as a result of recurring heavy rains, the Smědá river at the Bílý Potok limnigraph (1st SPA threshold 80 cm, 2nd SPA 100 cm) recorded its first peak on Saturday, June 1, at midnight at 87 cm / 21 m³/s, the second on Sunday evening at 108 cm / 27 m³/s, and the third on Monday morning at 85 cm / 20 m³/s. This water rushed towards Frýdlant in Bohemia, which experienced the first wave without a flood state, but declared the 1st SPA (130 cm) on Sunday evening and subsequently recorded the first peak at 153 cm / 64 m³/s, and the second on Monday morning at 157 cm / 66 m³/s. However, the flood was called off the same evening. In Frýdlant, the Smědá is joined by the Řasnice, which reached a flow of 19 m³/s on Monday noon, and these combined waters flowed through Višňová into Poland. Together with the collected rainfall from the entire basin, this meant that the 1st SPA (200 cm) was declared in this village already on Saturday around 7 p.m., and even the 3rd SPA (240 cm) was reached before midnight. Over the following hours, four peak waves followed, the first (270 cm / 72 m³/s) on Sunday morning, and the third and strongest (282 cm / 89 m³/s) on Monday at 12:00, but even here the two-year water level was not exceeded. The Smědá returned to normal on Tuesday afternoon. The Černá Nisa in Rudolfov did not exceed a flow of 6 m³/s, which is ten times the normal level, and the Lužická Nisa in Liberec reached the 1st SPA (85 cm) on Sunday, June 2, in the morning and peaked after noon at 117 cm / 22 m³/s, returning to normal on Tuesday, June 4, in the afternoon. The Jeřice, which flows into the Lužická Nisa in Chrastava, was significantly more swollen despite the retention capacity of the Fojtka reservoir: in Mníšek, the 1st SPA (60 cm) was declared on Saturday around 9 p.m., but after the reservoir filled, the Jeřice rose above the 3rd SPA (100 cm) on Sunday afternoon, although the peak of 155 cm / 6.5 m³ did not even represent a one-year water level. Here too, the water returned to normal on Tuesday morning. The Lužická Nisa in Hrádek nad Nisou reached the 1st SPA (175 cm) on Saturday around 8 p.m. and then peaked twice in the 2nd SPA range (above 210 cm), first on Sunday around 8 p.m. and again on Monday around 9 a.m., each time at 220 cm / 79 m³/s (not reaching the five-year water level). The flood was called off on Tuesday morning, June 4.

Whole_Text.header: Events in the Morava River Basin
Whole_Text.content: In the Morava river basin, the Austrian border area was particularly at risk. Thanks to appropriate management of the waterworks system on the Dyje and Svratka rivers, all flows were kept at a maximum of 2nd flood activity level.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

The flooding of the Meuse in 1926 was a result of high water levels in the Meuse River and its tributaries in the Netherlands, Belgium, and France. In the Netherlands, this was one of the most catastrophic floods of the 20th century in the Meuse Valley in terms of damage. Areas in the provinces of Limburg, North Brabant, and Gelderland were flooded.

Abundant rains from December 19, 1925, combined with the meltwater from the snow that had fallen since the end of November that year, led to exceptionally high water levels in the rivers. On the morning of January 1, 1926, the Maas dike near Overasselt and Nederasselt in the Netherlands broke, causing the Land van Maas en Waal to flood. In the days that followed, large parts of the river area were affected by the water. Among others, Nederasselt, Overasselt, Balgoy, Hernen, Leur, and Bergharen were submerged.

Due to the incoming water and ice, 3,000 houses were damaged or destroyed. The damage amounted to 10 million guilders. On January 3, the broadcast of the Hilversumsche Draadlooze Omroep was interrupted for a call for help. It was the last major flood disaster in the river area. Postcards with images of the floods were issued, the proceeds of which were intended for victims of the disaster.

Article_Name: Powódź w Prudniku (1977) – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: Poland Prudnik, Szybowice, Niemysłowice, Czyżowice flood August 21–22, 1977 1 Flood in Prudnik in 1977 – a flood that struck Prudnik and the surrounding areas on August 21–22, 1977, caused by heavy rainfall.

Between August 2–8, 1977, the first small flood occurred in the Prudnik River basin. From August 18, rain began to fall again. The rainfall intensified, taking the form of a "cloudburst" on the afternoon of August 21. At rainfall measurement stations, the following amounts were recorded: in Jarnołtówek – 61.5 mm, in Trzebina – 80.7 mm, in Prudnik – 117 mm. Lesser rainfall was recorded at stations in Głogówek, Głuchołazy, Nowy Świętów, Wierzbięcice, Ścinawa Mała, and Korfantów[1]. The record water flow in the Prudnik River occurred in the afternoon and evening of August 21 and the morning of August 22. A rapid rise in water levels was noted in the tributaries of the Prudnik River, mainly in Potoczyń. On August 21 at 4:00 PM, the alarm level was exceeded at the water gauge in Prudnik. At 8:00 PM, the highest level in the history of this water gauge was recorded – 476 cm. Part of the water overflowed the riverbanks near Chrobrego Street and flowed through Kolejowa, Wiejska, Morcinka, and Konopnicka Streets, returning to the riverbed about half a kilometer further[1]. The course of the flood was rapid. "Trybuna Odrzańska" published a statement from a farmer in Szybowice: "It all lasted no longer than 20 minutes. Before I realized the stream was rising, the yard was already full of water. I ran outside to catch the chickens and let the pigs out of the sty." The farmer's wife added: "When I was leaving the barn, the water swept me away and threw me against the fence. Holding onto it, I slowly made my way to the neighbor's house. I didn’t manage to let the pigs out, and they were carried away. The water was so high that they floated over the cage fences..."[1] Father Marcin Bajer from Niemysłowice described the flood: "The sky was exceptionally black. (...) Within half an hour of the downpour, people who had entered the church could not leave. A great torrent of water flowed through the stream and the road. People were helpless; no one expected this on such a beautiful Sunday afternoon. The water level kept rising, pouring through windows into houses, flooding floors, furniture, and equipment. Panic gripped people; the water carried geese, chickens, ducks, pigs. (...) It was a biblical flood on a small scale. Many families suffered very great damage and material losses. (...) A similar disaster struck Czyżowice, Prudnik, and Szybowice. The road to the city was closed. (...) The hand of the Lord touched us"[2].

The most affected were Szybowice and Prudnik. The flood wave significantly damaged the railway viaduct in Prudnik on Słowicza Street. In Szybowice, one person died – a woman grazing a cow in a meadow. Losses in livestock were recorded. Residential and farm buildings in Szybowice and Niemysłowice were damaged. Water flooded the weaving mill, dyeing plant, yarn, and raw fabric warehouses of the "Frotex" Cotton Industry Plant. Factory workers were evacuated by soldiers of the 45th WOP Battalion.
