Article_Name: Powódź w Europie Środkowej (2024) – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: This is the reviewed version of this page Poland Czechia Serbia Slovakia Austria Slovenia Croatia Romania Moldova Germany Hungary Italy flood September 2024 26 people (including: 9 in Poland, 7 in Romania, 5 in Austria, 5 in Czechia) 9 people (of which 8 in Czechia and 1 in Poland) The Central European Flood (2024) – a flood particularly in the southern Oder River basin in September 2024, caused by a Genoa low, which contributed to heavy and intense rainfall and a general weather breakdown in Central Europe. The source of the water level rise in the Oder River basin began in the Sudetes and the Silesian Lowland. The phenomenon of flooding or flood risk occurred in the area of the Lower Silesian, Opole, Silesian, and Lubusz voivodeships as well as the rest of Central Europe. The flood, due to its scale, was compared to the millennium flood of 1997[1][2].

The flood in 2024 in Poland in the Lower Silesian, Opole, and Silesian Voivodeships, as well as in Central Europe, was caused by heavy and prolonged rainfall triggered by a Genoa low, which led to rivers overflowing, including in the Oder River basin. The low-pressure system formed due to a significant thermal contrast between warm Mediterranean air masses and cold air from the Alps. It was characterized by warm and humid air from the Mediterranean moving northward and, upon colliding with the Alps, forcing these air masses upward. In the river basins flowing through Poland, the heaviest rainfall from September 12–15 occurred in the northern and northwestern parts of the Jeseníky Mountains and the Golden Mountains in the Czech Republic. At meteorological stations in this region, the recorded rainfall totals were: Rejvíz – 517 mm, Červenohorské sedlo – 474 mm, Jeseník – 465 mm, Zlaté Hory – 416 mm, Staré Město pod Sněžníkem – 413 mm. Most of this rainfall occurred on September 14, with daily totals exceeding 200 mm at some stations. Extremely heavy rainfall also occurred near Ostrava (approximately 300 mm). Rainfall in the Eastern Sudetes region and throughout the Czech Republic was also intense, for example, in Opava, where the total rainfall during this period exceeded 200 mm. In Poland, the highest recorded rainfall at a measurement station was on Śnieżnik, with 400 mm and 472 mm according to the RainGRS system. In the northern part of the Eastern Sudetes and the foothills on the Czech-Polish border (south of the Paczków–Prudnik line), rainfall during this time exceeded 200 mm. At the turn of September and October, a second Genoa low formed, causing prolonged heavy rainfall in southern Europe and flooding in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, North Macedonia, Montenegro, and Albania.

On September 9, IMGW published a second-degree weather threat forecast for heavy rainfall on September 13, with the possibility of flooding in the Upper Oder basin. On September 11, IMGW issued a meteorological warning about floods and inundations caused by rainfall exceeding 150 mm locally from September 12 to 15 in the Lower Silesian, Opole, and Silesian Voivodeships. On September 11, the Czech Ministry of the Interior stated in a press release that the situation would be similar to the floods of 1997 and 2002. The ministry reported preparations, including increased outflow from retention reservoirs. The heaviest rainfall was forecasted in the Jeseníky Mountains, with 400 mm in the optimistic scenario and 450 mm in the pessimistic scenario. The press release included maps of total rainfall for September 11–15. In the pessimistic scenario, the highest rainfall totals were expected to be 330 mm in the Pardubice Region, 310 mm in the Jelenia Góra Basin area, 300 mm in the Moravian-Silesian Beskids, and 300 mm on the Czech-Austrian border near České Budějovice. On September 12, IMGW-PIB forecasted up to 300 mm of rainfall. According to the September 12 forecast, the level of the Biała Głuchołaska River in Głuchołazy was expected to reach 3.2 m on September 14, exceeding the alarm level by 2 meters according to the HBV hydrological model. The first IMGW bulletin on September 13 included a forecast of "maximum rainfall totals from 250 to 400 mm in the Nysa Kłodzka basin, and from 200 to 300 mm in the Mała Wisła basin." The bulletin also included water level forecasts until 8:00 PM on September 15, according to which the Nysa Kłodzka level in the Opole Voivodeship was expected to be moderate, the lower course of the Biała Głuchołaska high, and the Bóbr River level was not expected to exceed warning levels. On September 13, the spokesperson for RZGW in Wrocław stated that there was no need to increase the flood reserve in the Nysa Kłodzka cascade, as it was sufficient in the context of the forecasted rainfall. The same amount of water was flowing out of Lake Nyskie as was flowing in. On that day at 6:00 AM, all water reservoirs in the cascade were below normal levels by a total of 48 million m³. Wody Polskie issued a statement on September 18 that on September 13, meteorological and hydrological forecasts had changed significantly, but floodwaters were still expected to remain within river channels.

Despite the warning issued the day before by IMGW about expected heavy rainfall in the coming days, in the report issued by Wody Polskie on that day at 11 a.m., it was stated that there were no hydrological and meteorological warnings (noting that only data collected by the national hydrological and meteorological service was used to prepare the report). During the previous 24 hours, heavier rainfall was recorded only locally. The water levels in most rivers were within the low and medium water zones. Maximum rainfall in the Oder basin locally reached up to 40 mm. Almost all retention reservoirs had levels below normal, particularly the reservoirs of the so-called Nysa Kłodzka cascade, which had a flood reserve of 178.92 million m³, constituting 132% of the normal reserve. The inflow to it was 4.96, and the outflow 8.34 m³/s. Dry reservoirs and polders were empty[19].

Heavy and intense rainfall forecasted for southern Poland (Lower Silesian, Opole, and Silesian Voivodeships) for the period from September 12 to 16, 2024, was associated with the arrival of the Genoa low "Borys" at the Polish-Czech border. Forecasts indicated that the epicenter of the rainfall would be in the Eastern Sudetes in the Jeseníky Mountains, where the total rainfall was expected to reach 400 mm. The area of intense rainfall was expected to cover areas north of the Jeseníky Mountains, including the towns of Złoty Stok, Paczków, Głuchołazy, and Prudnik. River levels were predicted to rise most rapidly in the Nysa and Prudnik counties. Flooding and so-called flash floods were anticipated. Uniformed services and crisis management staff were put on high alert.

At 2:00 PM, the warning level was exceeded at the water gauge point in Głuchołazy, and the water rise surpasses forecasts. The authorities of the Czech town of Mikulovice, located on the Biała Głuchołaska River, announced that according to hydrological forecasts, the "flood of the century," larger than the one in 1997, is expected to occur on September 15th. In Wrocław, a crisis management meeting was held with the participation of Prime Minister Donald Tusk, Minister of Internal Affairs and Administration Tomasz Siemoniak, as well as voivodes and heads of services. Before midnight, the water level in Prudnik exceeded the alarm level.

During the night of September 13-14, villages near Prudnik were flooded: Czyżowice, Wierzbiec, Rudziczka, Szybowice, as well as Morów near Nysa. The mayor of Prudnik declared a flood state in the city, and the district governor announced a flood alert for the entire Prudnik district. The mayor of Głuchołazy decided to evacuate residents from several streets. In the morning hours, the Lubrzanka stream flooded the village of Lubrza, and the Prudnik river flooded Skrzypiec, Trzebina, and Krzyżkowice. Before noon, at the dam in Jarnołtówek near Prudnik, which is crucial for the safety of towns along the Złoty Potok, Prudnik, and Osobłoga rivers, water began to overflow through the upper spillway. Authorities ordered the evacuation of residents near Złoty Potok in Jarnołtówek and Pokrzywna. The dam in Jarnołtówek was visited by Tomasz Siemoniak and Wiesław Leśniakiewicz. The mayor of Prudnik ordered the evacuation of residents from Moszczanka and Łąka Prudnicka. People were also evacuated from Morów and Dziewiętlice. A flood alert was declared for the Nysa district and the Głuchołazy municipality. After a crisis team meeting in Nysa, Minister Siemoniak announced the concentration of services in the Nysa and Prudnik districts. In the afternoon, water levels in the Oder River rose in Kędzierzyn-Koźle, Opole, and Brzeg. The Buków Polder began operations on the upper Oder. Residents of several dozen homes in Lądek-Zdrój were evacuated. The Kaczawa River flooded properties in Złotoryja and the village of Nowy Kościół. In Prudnik, residents of Chrobrego, Kochanowskiego, Kołłątaja, and Morcinka streets were evacuated. The production plant of the "Pionier" Cooperative on Batorego Street and allotment gardens were flooded. Water flooded Racławice Śląskie, Dzierżysławice, and Mochów near Głogówek. Railway tracks in the Niemysłowice Forest area were undermined, leading PKP PLK to suspend traffic on line 137 between Prudnik and Nysa. Train traffic was also halted on the Jelenia Góra – Szklarska Poręba Górna section. The flood situation in the Otmuchów municipality was deemed "very serious," affecting the villages of Kałków, Broniszowice, and Śliwice (part of the town of Otmuchów). At 3:00 PM, a flood alert began in the Strzeleczki and Krapkowice municipalities. The villages of Ścinawa Mała and Ścinawa Nyska in the Korfantów municipality were flooded. In the evening, flood embankments in Moszczanka and Łąka Prudnicka were breached. Biskupów and most properties in Broniszowice were flooded. Forty cadets from the Fire Academy in Warsaw arrived in Prudnik. Evacuations were carried out in nearby Lubrza. A briefing was held at the County Headquarters of the State Fire Service in Nysa regarding the flood threat, attended by Donald Tusk, who then went to Głuchołazy. Residents of the orphanage in Czechowice-Dziedzice, Międzyrzecze Dolne, and Graniczna Street in Dankowice were evacuated. Around 11:00 PM, water began to overflow the dam in Międzygórze, prompting the evacuation of the facility's technical staff (losing control over water releases) and residents of lower-lying areas. In the Wodzisław district, the number of floods increased. The Piotrówka River overflowed on the Czech side, leading to the closure of border crossings with the Czech Republic in Gołkowice and Skrbeńsko.

On the night of September 14-15, a flood alert was issued for the Nysa municipality. The Biała Głuchołaska River breached the embankments above Biała Nyska, flooding the village and bypassing Lake Nyskie. It then flowed through fields, flooding a significant part of Nysa. Residents of Łowkowice near Strzeleczki were evacuated. The Racibórz Dolny dry reservoir began retaining Odra River waters at 4:20 AM, capturing the flood wave. In the morning hours, water overflowed the embankments in Głuchołazy, flooding the city center. The Osobłoga River breached the embankment in Kierpień and overflowed its banks, cutting off roads to the village. Water also entered Głogówek and flooded other villages near Prudnik, including Niemysłowice, Szybowice, and Mieszkowice. Children's homes in Mochów and Prudnik were evacuated, along with individual residents of Racławice Śląskie. The mayor of Prudnik urged residents to limit water usage and informed that the dam in Jarnołtówek was close to overflowing. In the center of Prudnik, the Prudnik River began to overflow, flooding the city center. Authorities started evacuating endangered residents. Due to flooding of transformers, power was cut off in parts of Prudnik and Łąka Prudnicka. Around 11:00 AM, water destroyed both the temporary and under-construction bridges in Głuchołazy, increasing local water accumulation. At 10:35 AM, the dam in Stronie Śląskie was destroyed, which had started overflowing around 10:00 PM the previous day. Almost all the stored water (about 1.4 million m³) flowed out of the reservoir in a short time, causing significant damage. The evacuation of 1,600 people was ordered in the Kłodzko County, in towns such as Lądek-Zdrój, Stronie Śląskie, Kłodzko, Bystrzyca Kłodzka, and villages including Międzygórze, Wilkanów, Gorzanów, Ołdrzychowice Kłodzkie, Krosnowice, Żelazno, Trzebieszowice, Radochów, Domaszków, Długopole-Zdrój, Długopole Dolne, and Długopole Górne. The mayor of Wrocław declared a flood alert for the entire city at 11:00 PM. Evacuations were also announced for residents of areas adjacent to the Nysa Kłodzka River in the Bardo and Kamieniec Ząbkowicki municipalities. In Bielsko-Biała, residents of Sobieskiego, Żywiecka, and Wodna streets were evacuated. Individual evacuations took place in Zabełków, Chałupki, Rydułtowy, Połomia, Zebrzydowice, and Jasienica. The first fatality of the flood in Poland was a man in Krosnowice. In the afternoon, the body of a 42-year-old man was found in a stream in Bielsko-Biała. Intercity train services to the Czech Republic were suspended. Due to the evacuation of residents from Chałupki, train traffic was suspended on the Racibórz–Chałupki and Wodzisław Śląski–Chałupki routes. The A1 motorway at the Polish-Czech border was passable only up to the Gorzyce junction, as the Odra River overflowed on the Czech side in Bohumín. National road No. 78 from Olza to Chałupki was also impassable, as were some provincial and county roads. In the Lubomia municipality, about 20 properties were at risk of flooding. The head of the Opole County, Henryk Lakwa, declared a flood alert for the Niemodlin and Popielów municipalities, while the head of the Brzeg County, Jacek Monkiewicz, declared a flood alert for the Grodków and Lewin Brzeski municipalities. A flood alert was also declared in Kędzierzyn-Koźle and Kraków. The mayor of Nysa, Kordian Kolbiarz, announced an increase in water discharge from Lake Nyskie to 1,000 m³ per second due to the breach of the dam in Stronie Śląskie. He appealed to Nysa residents to evacuate or move to higher floors of buildings. Territorial Defense Force soldiers were deployed to the city. After 5:00 PM, the mayor of Prudnik, the head of the State Fire Service in Prudnik, Krzysztof Wiciak, and the head of the Prudnik County reported a breach in the embankment in Jarnołtówek, again urging residents of Jarnołtówek, Pokrzywna, Moszczanka, Łąka Prudnicka, and Prudnik to evacuate immediately. The military with amphibious vehicles was brought in to assist near Prudnik. A flood alert was declared for the entire Krapkowice County, where the Osobłoga River flooded villages such as Pietna, Steblów, Żywocice, and parts of Krapkowice. Houses near the Żelazna polder near Opole were evacuated. The village of Kamienica near Paczków was flooded. In the late afternoon, Prime Minister Donald Tusk announced the preparation of a regulation to implement a state of natural disaster due to the ongoing flood catastrophe. In the evening, water flowing through Głuchołazy began to recede. The city was left without electricity, gas, and landline telephony. The third fatality of the flood in Poland was a resident of Nowy Świętów near Prudnik, found dead in a flooded building. The city of Korfantów and the villages of Kuźnica Ligocka and Przechód were flooded. Water levels began to drop in the Złoty Potok and Prudnik rivers, as well as in the Jarnołtówek reservoir. In the evening, it was also announced that the Polish government would seek maximum financial aid from the European Union to address the flood's aftermath. According to authorities, the EU has a special assistance mechanism for such situations. From that day, reports began to emerge about the completely destroyed historic St. John Bridge in Lądek-Zdrój. However, it turned out that the Gothic bridge over the Biała Lądecka River survived the flood waves but was in a critical structural condition and still at risk of collapse. The statue of St. John of Nepomuk adorning the bridge was lost. In Prudnik, the water destroyed three pedestrian bridges: a footbridge in the garden allotment complex over the Złoty Potok, and footbridges under Czyżykowa Góra and Piaskówka over the Prudnik River.

Shortly after midnight, information began to flow about the increasingly rapid drop in water levels of the Nysa Kłodzka River in Kłodzko. According to reporters, the water level dropped from its peak by about 1–2 meters [citation needed]. Authorities managed to patch a breach in the embankment in Jarnołtówek, temporarily securing villages in the Złoty Potok valley and the town of Prudnik [94]. In Brzeg, an "early evacuation action" was initiated for residents of Grobla, Wał Śluzowy, Błonie, Nadodrzańska, Nadbrzeżna, Cegielniana, Strzelecka streets, and Drzewny Square. A collection of essential items for flood victims began in the city [95]. School activities were canceled in over 350 educational institutions in the Lower Silesian, Opole, Silesian, and Lubusz voivodeships [96]. District prosecutor's offices in Nysa, Prudnik, Bystrzyca Kłodzka, Kłodzko, and Lwówek Śląski were closed. All trials and hearings scheduled for September 16, 2024, in the District Courts in Prudnik, Kłodzko, Nysa, and Kamienna Góra were canceled [97]. Due to the flooding of the platform near Wyszków Śląski, train traffic was suspended on the section of railway line no. 287 Opole – Nysa (trains stopped in Kubice). The section of railway line no. 288 Nysa – Brzeg was also closed, as well as an impassable fragment of railway line no. 137 from Głogówek towards Prudnik [98]. National road no. 45 collapsed on the bridge in Żywocice [99]. Residents of Kopic near Grodków were evacuated [100]. A flood alert was issued for Kędzierzyn-Koźle [101]. Before noon, the Topola reservoir on the Nysa Kłodzka River burst [102]. The flood control reservoir on the Oder – Polder Buków – received over 50 million m³ of water and was completely filled [34]. A state of natural disaster was declared in parts of the Lower Silesian, Opole, and Silesian voivodeships [103].

On the night of September 16 to 17, news emerged that the first flood wave was reaching Oława. It was expected to arrive during the night. This town is located about 30 km from Wrocław. Residents prepared large amounts of embankments and reinforcements made of sandbags to protect the area. Nysa is continuously fighting for the flood embankment, which is the last resort to prevent the complete flooding of the town. People, along with services, are reinforcing the embankments with sandbags. Water is being continuously released to lower the water level in the Nysa Kłodzka as quickly as possible. At 12:20 AM, the water level in the Oder River in Opole was 654 cm, in Brzeg 651 cm, and in Oława 629 cm. Since Sunday, the Racibórz Dolny reservoir has been operating, aiming to flatten the flood wave coming from Ostrava in the Czech Republic towards Wrocław as much as possible. By September 17 at 4:00 PM, it had taken in 147 million m³ of water (about 80% of its capacity at that time, while the neighboring Buków Polder retained an additional 50 million m³ of water), after which it began to be slowly emptied. Shortly after midnight, a decision was also made to evacuate the entire town of Lewin Brzeski, located on the Nysa Kłodzka, after the embankments were breached and water began entering the town. The river level near the town exceeded 780 cm. Evacuations were also ordered in nearby villages. Wody Polskie reported a minor water leak in the forefield of the Racibórz Dolny reservoir, which, however, did not threaten the operation of the reservoir's inlet and outlet mechanisms. The Municipal Crisis Management Team in Kędzierzyn-Koźle decided to prepare for the potential evacuation of three districts of Kędzierzyn-Koźle: Rogów, Zachód, and Południe. In the city, efforts were also underway to raise embankments in Lasoki (Rogi district) and to set up protective sleeves over the Lineta stream at the height of Emilii Plater Street. On that day, the flood had already reached the Lubusz Voivodeship and, through the Bóbr and Szprotawa rivers, flooded Szprotawa in the Żagań County. The water also posed a threat to another nearby town, Żagań. During a crisis meeting around 6:55 PM with the participation of Prime Minister Donald Tusk, it was reported that in Żagań, the alarm level on the local river had been exceeded by 178 cm. This level was also exceeded in Łozy, located on the Kwisa River.

The peak of the flood wave reached Wrocław after midnight. Due to its flattening, the wave did not cause significant damage, only moderate flooding was visible, mostly in uninhabited areas. The Lubusz Voivode, Marek Cebula, declared a flood alert in the districts of Gorzów, Krosno, Nowa Sól, Słubice, Wschowa, and Zielona Góra.

The flood in the Czech Republic began on September 13 after heavy rains. By September 15, it was reported that over 200 rivers had overflowed their banks. The most critical situation is in South Moravia, followed by Central and Northern Moravia, and South Bohemia. Four people were reported missing, thousands were displaced, and about 250,000 people were without power. Several roads and railway lines were closed. Water also leaked into the Museum metro station, but it remained operational. The Husinec dam in the South Bohemian region overflowed on September 15, and water began spilling over the dam's crest. Around noon on September 16, information emerged about damage to the right bank of the flood embankment in Ostrava. This is a very dangerous incident, as no flood plans accounted for this event. An urgent evacuation of residents from areas at risk of flooding was immediately ordered. A crane arrived at the site to place sandbags in the gap. The water is heading toward chemical plants and a coking plant, which could lead to catastrophic consequences and an even greater tragedy. At this point, about 2,500 residents have been evacuated from the Ostrava area. Railway routes Bohumin – Ostrava and Ostrava – Ostrava Svinov, including access from the Polish border crossings Chałupki and Zebrzydowice to the Czech Republic, are also impassable. It may take at least a week to restore railway traffic at the Ostrava railway junction. The mountain resort of Malá Úpa in the Trutnov District in the Krkonoše Mountains has been completely cut off from the outside world due to a mudslide. On September 17, after 10:00, no location was under an "extreme flood danger" alert anymore. Only standard third-degree flood alerts remained. The situation in Ostrava was still critical at that time.

The flood threat did not spare Slovakia, where there were fears of flooding in Bratislava. On September 13, areas that could be flooded were identified, leading to certain actions being taken to minimize potential effects. The level of the Danube rose slightly, but it did not result in the flooding of the historic center of the Slovak capital. On September 15, it was reported that the Danube overflowed in Bratislava. Areas near the river, including some historic sites, were flooded. On September 17, the peak wave reached the Slovak capital. It reached 9.8 meters before starting to recede. Meteorological services reassured that there was no danger to the Slovak capital. According to the Slovak opposition, the government underestimated the threat and did not take sufficient measures to protect people and buildings in the immediate vicinity of the Danube.

The Austrian authorities, using available forecasts, began creating space for incoming water in reservoirs, including the Ottenstein Reservoir in Lower Austria. In addition to heavy rainfall, there was snowfall, particularly in southern Austria. Besides Lower Austria, rivers also overflowed in Burgenland, such as the Wulka and Leitha. On September 14, 24 towns in the districts of Horn, Krems, Tulln, and Zwettl were classified as disaster areas due to the high water levels in the Kamp River. That same evening, the area was expanded to include 18 more towns. Early in the morning on September 15, the government of the federal state of Lower Austria announced that the entire state was now under a state of disaster. In many places, it was necessary to evacuate residents. Numerous streams, such as the Perschling or the Vienna River, overflowed their banks, also forcing evacuations in Vienna. At 10:00 local time, it was reported that a firefighter had died, the first fatality from the floods in the country. On September 15, the Danube in the Austrian capital overflowed its banks and flooded many areas. Due to the severe weather conditions caused by storms and their aftermath, about 25,000 households in Styria were without electricity. The worst situation in this region was in the valleys of the Mürz and Salza rivers. On the evening of September 15, the city of Kapfenberg, located on the Mürz, was underwater. On Monday, September 16, three more fatalities were reported in Lower Austria. In the morning, 256 national roads, including parts of highways, were closed. Rail traffic was also heavily affected. Dam breaches, particularly near St. Pölten, placed a significant burden on local services. This led to the complete evacuation of the village of Rust im Tullnerfeld, with about 600 residents, due to fears of a massive influx of water from the Perschling River. After 6:00 PM on September 17, it was reported that five people had died as a result of the floods in Lower Austria. Many towns, however, remain cut off from the world. According to Austrian police, the tragedy occurred in the town of Tulln an der Donau.

Since September 14, in Germany, in several rivers in Bavaria, including the Danube and the Elbe, water levels have risen, but they remained within permissible limits. The highest water level increase was expected in Passau, in the federal state of Bavaria near the border with Austria. In this city, two smaller rivers – the Inn and the Ilz – flow into the Danube. Local authorities in Passau reported that the Danube's water level at that time reached 7.9 meters, and the Inn River 5.5 meters.

On September 13, European media reported numerous downpours in this country. The most tragic and violent flood phenomena were observed in the municipality of Nova Gorica, right on the border with Italy, on the river in the town of Neblo. Problems caused by the rain most severely affected the city of Celje, partially paralyzing it. In the municipality of Žalec in the Savinja Valley, the Ložnica River overflowed its banks, flooding some houses.

On September 14, authorities in Romania reported information about 4 fatalities due to floods in the Galati and Vaslui districts. By September 15, approximately 5,000 houses had been damaged. On September 16, by 3:00 PM, 6 fatalities were confirmed. On September 17, authorities in Romania announced that the number of victims in the country had risen to 7. Another person was identified in the village of Grivita in the Galati district. Furthermore, in the Galati, Vaslui, and Iasi districts, the red (highest) flood alert level is in effect. In the remaining northeastern districts, an orange or yellow alert is in place.

On September 15, the media warned that on Tuesday, September 17, the water level in the Danube in Budapest would rise significantly. Authorities estimate the water level could increase to as much as 930 cm. Services began preparations for the drastic rise approaching the Hungarian capital. On September 17, reports emerged that hydrologists predicted the peak wave on the Danube had significantly stretched. This, in turn, means it will move through Hungarian territory much longer than initially anticipated. Its peak will pass the town of Nagybajcs (near the Slovak border) on Thursday and will not reach Budapest until Saturday. On that day, the maximum forecasted water level in the capital is expected to be 860 cm.

On Saturday, September 14, many streets in Chisinau were flooded due to heavy rainfall. The Byk River, which flows through the capital, overflowed. The flood situation also occurred in other localities in Moldova, including Puhoi, Lărguța, Leca, Strășeni, and Tătărășeni.
As a result of the flood, 27 people lost their lives. Excluding Poland, this number was: 9 people went missing during the disaster.

During the flood in Poland, cities such as Kłodzko, Lądek-Zdrój, Stronie Śląskie, Głuchołazy, Prudnik, Nysa, Bystrzyca Kłodzka, Szprotawa, and Lewin Brzeski were affected. The latter was 90% flooded. Many villages near overflowing rivers were damaged to varying degrees. The water damaged or destroyed historic and heritage sites, such as the 16th-century bridge in Lądek-Zdrój, the Franciscan monastery in Kłodzko, and the fence near the former ZPB "Frotex" in Prudnik. In Stronie Śląskie, the wave swept away the Police and Municipal Guard building. The flood caused damage to railway infrastructure and disruptions in train traffic. Traffic was halted at the Kłodzko junction and on the Kamieniec Ząbkowicki-Paczków-Nysa-Prudnik line. The greatest damage was recorded in the area of the Głuchołazy station, where track deformations occurred, among other issues. Losses in Poland caused by the phenomenon and its aftermath are estimated in billions of zlotys. Nine victims lost their lives, among whom were: Damage and destruction also occurred in other countries affected by the Genoa low. Abroad, the most severely flooded were the Czech Republic, Austria, and Romania. An indeterminate number of domestic, farm, and wild animals perished in the flood. In Lwówek Śląski, over 80 rabbits, pigeons, and chickens drowned in the "Wyzwolenie" Family Allotment Gardens, while in Hajduki Nyskie, 30 piglets perished. According to the Lower Silesian Animal Protection Inspectorate, "hundreds" of domestic dogs and cats did not survive the disaster. A beaver rescued in Wrocław died from sepsis caused by contaminated water. Fish left behind by the receding flood wave died en masse, and the water also swept away large numbers of red wood ants, spiders, and other insects, posing a threat to the survival of their populations.

On September 21, the Lower Silesian Voivode Maciej Awiżeń announced that the preliminary losses in the voivodeship caused by the flood are estimated at 3,832,623,000 PLN. The largest amount of losses concerns the city of Jelenia Góra – 750 million PLN. For comparison, the losses caused by the 1997 flood in the Lower Silesian Voivodeship were estimated at 5.6 billion PLN (approximately 16.2 billion PLN according to 2024 values).

Głuchołazy was the city that suffered the most during the flood in the Opole Voivodeship. The water destroyed buildings, streets, and infrastructure in the city. According to the mayor's account, dozens of tenement houses in the city were flooded, and on the left-bank side of the city, "all the shops were washed away from the surface." The river's current swept away a temporary bridge and the structure of a new bridge. A pipe supplying drinking water was damaged. The Municipal Stadium was flooded. The cobblestones laid in the Market Square were torn out. Since the dam in Jarnołtówek withstood the pressure of the water, the city of Prudnik and villages in the Złoty Potok valley avoided massive destruction. The municipal sports facilities in Prudnik were flooded: the "Obuwnik" hall, the archery track, and the Municipal Stadium, which was under reconstruction. The "Pionier" Cooperative and the Henniges Automotive plant were "largely" destroyed. The water damaged roads in Moszczanka, Łąka Prudnicka, and Jarnołtówek. The water destroyed three pedestrian bridges: the footbridge in the garden allotment complex over the Złoty Potok, as well as the footbridges under Czyżykowa Góra and under Piaskówka over the Prudnik River. The Prudnik municipality estimated the flood damage at over 100 million PLN. The infrastructure of the Paczków municipality was also affected. In Paczków, the water supply and sewage systems were damaged. The water completely destroyed the sewage treatment plants.

On September 21, 2024, a recording of a new version of the song "Moja i twoja nadzieja" by the band Hey took place as part of the #RazemDlaWas campaign organized by Telewizja Polska, encouraging aid for flood victims. A number of Polish artists participated, including Katarzyna Nosowska and Edyta Bartosiewicz, who sang in the original recording. The song was created as a reference to the charitable single "Moja i twoja nadzieja ’97," recorded in 1997 for the victims of the millennium flood. The premiere of the song and its accompanying music video took place on September 26, 2024. All proceeds from advertisements on the material on YouTube are donated to the TVP Foundation to provide assistance to flood victims. In an interview given to "Gazeta Polska" on October 2, 2024, the head of the National Security Bureau, Jacek Siewiera, assessed that during crisis management, the flow of information from the European and governmental levels to the local level failed, as did the decisions of Wody Polskie regarding the Topola retention reservoir on the Nysa Kłodzka River and communication following the damage to the dam in Stronie Śląskie. He also expressed satisfaction with the Territorial Defense Forces, which played a leading role in combating the disaster.

Countries: Poland, Czech Republic, Serbia, Slovakia, Austria, Slovenia, Croatia, Romania, Moldova, Germany, Hungary, Italy  
Type of event: flood  
Date: September 2024  
Fatalities: 26 people (including: 9 in Poland, 7 in Romania, 5 in Austria, 5 in the Czech Republic)  
Missing: 9 people (of which 8 in the Czech Republic and 1 in Poland)

Article_Name: อุทกภัยในประเทศไทย พ.ศ. 2567 - วิกิพีเดีย

Whole_Text.content: Since August 2024, flash floods and landslides have occurred in several provinces of Thailand, particularly in the northern region, due to the influence of Typhoon Yagi and Typhoon Surigae. Currently, the Department of Disaster Prevention and Mitigation has reported that the floods have affected 19 provinces, with 45 fatalities and over 43,535 households impacted.

On August 14, 2024, continuous rainfall occurred, and the amount of rain increased due to the influence of the monsoon trough passing over the upper northern region, combined with the southwest monsoon. This caused continuous rainfall almost every day and heavy to very heavy rain during August 17–21, 2024. Especially in high mountainous areas, the accumulated rainfall increased rapidly, resulting in a massive amount of rainwater flowing quickly into the main river basins and tributaries.

On August 14, heavy rain combined with flash floods occurred in front of Chiang Rai Rajabhat University, Ban Du Subdistrict, Mueang Chiang Rai District, Chiang Rai Province, at the intersection in front of the university, making it difficult for people to commute. The main route leading to the university gate was cut off, affecting Phahonyothin Road. Later, flooding occurred at the Khua Khrae intersection, allowing only some small vehicles to pass, as the water could not be drained in time. On August 17, in Chiang Rai Province, flash floods from forest runoff affected nine districts: Mueang Chiang Rai, Thoeng, Wiang Chai, Mae Lao, Khun Tan, Pa Daet, Phaya Mengrai, Chiang Saen, and Mae Sai. A total of 1,665 households were affected, and agricultural areas were impacted. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities. In Chiang Saen District, the water in the Ruak, Kam, and Kok Rivers could not drain into the Mekong River, and in Khun Tan District, the Ing River flooded agricultural areas. Puttipong Sirimat, the Governor of Chiang Rai Province, ordered all districts to continuously monitor the situation of forest runoff and overflowing rivers, as well as prepare equipment and personnel to provide immediate assistance upon request.

On August 18, in Chiang Rai Province, flash floods from continuous rain occurred in Mae Sai Subdistrict, Mueang Phayao District, causing forest runoff to flood the area. Residents had to urgently move their belongings to higher ground. Agricultural areas were affected, but there were no reports of injuries or fatalities. In Mae Hong Son Province, flash floods occurred in Huai Pha Subdistrict, Mueang Mae Hong Son District. Government agencies repaired and restored the area, including removing large fallen trees blocking roads and cutting high-voltage power lines to reopen normal routes. Authorities also ordered vigilance as rain continued in many areas.

On August 19, in Phetchabun Province, flash floods from forest runoff occurred in Huai Pong Subdistrict, Nong Phai District, and Bung Nam Tao Subdistrict, Lom Sak District, affecting 650 households. The Phetchabun Provincial Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Command prepared personnel, equipment, and machinery to handle the situation and warned residents to prepare for the floods.

On August 21, in Chiang Rai Province, two fatalities were reported from flash floods in Thoeng District and Doi Luang District. Meanwhile, 146 students were stranded at Wiang Kaen Witthayakhom School in Wiang Kaen District due to impassable roads caused by forest runoff. In Nan Province, flash floods from murky red forest runoff damaged the Duang Kham suspension bridge, and residents in Thung Chang District were affected. Chaiyanarong Wongyai, the Governor of Nan Province, warned residents near rivers to move belongings to higher ground and prepare essential supplies. He also ordered all subdistricts to set up kitchens to distribute food to affected residents.

On August 23, in Nan Province, the economic zone in Mueang Nan District continued to experience widespread flooding, including at Phumin Temple. Some locals stated they had never seen flooding at Phumin Temple before. Surapol Thiansut, the Mayor of Nan Municipality, said this was the worst flood in 100 years. Meanwhile, in the low-lying Ban Tha Li community, water levels reached up to 3 meters in some areas, making it the hardest-hit area in Mueang Nan District. In Phrae Province, flooding from the Yom River inundated Mueang Phrae District, affecting the economic zone, government centers, and surrounding communities. Many roads were impassable, and schools announced temporary closures. Chutidet Meechan, the Governor of Phrae Province, instructed local administrative organizations to deploy personnel to assist residents unable to leave the area.

On September 11, in Chiang Rai Province, a major flood occurred in Mueang Chiang Rai District, causing the area around the King Mengrai Monument intersection to be heavily flooded, making it impossible for vehicles to pass. This led to the closure of traffic routes on Phahonyothin Road at the Kok River Bridge, the western Chiang Rai bypass at the Kok River Bridge (Hong O-Nong Dan), Wiang Burapha Road at the Chalerm Phrakiat Bridge, while Mae Fah Luang Road at the Mae Fah Luang Bridge and Klang Wiang Road at the Khua Phaya Mangrai Bridge were partially passable. The province requested cooperation to avoid these routes. On September 12, all types of vehicles were unable to pass as the Kok River Bridge was swept by strong currents at all points, reaching the bridge's base, affecting bridges crossing the Kok River in Wiang Chai District, Wiang Chiang Rung District, Doi Luang District, and Chiang Saen District. Authorities had to close all routes crossing the Kok River to allow the water level to decrease. By September 13, the water began to recede in Mueang Chiang Rai District, and by September 14, main roads in Mueang Chiang Rai District were passable again. The Kok River flowed towards Chiang Saen District, heavily impacting the area. Mae Sai District also experienced severe flooding in the Sai Lom Joy Market area near the Mae Sai permanent checkpoint, affecting both sides of Mae Sai District and Tachileik Province in Myanmar. Relief centers were set up to assist flood victims, providing food and aid due to the impact of Typhoon Yagi.

In the northeastern region, on September 13, in Pak Chom District, Loei Province, the Mekong River's water level rose, flooding the immigration checkpoint and customs office in Ban Khok Phai. In Chiang Khan District, tributaries flowing into the Mekong River, such as the Huai River, overflowed their banks, flooding homes. On September 14, the Mekong River's water level rose sharply, causing sudden flooding in Mueang Nong Khai District, with water levels on Prajak Sinlapakhom Road reaching 30–50 centimeters. In Nakhon Phanom Province, in Ban Phaeng District, the Mekong River overflowed its banks in low-lying areas, flooding rice fields, livestock areas, and homes.

On September 17, in the southern part of Chiang Rai Province, particularly in Wiang Pa Pao District, heavy rainfall caused the Mae Lao River to rise, flooding Wiang and Pa Ngio Subdistricts. This made the main Chiang Rai-Chiang Mai highway impassable, with the impact continuing until September 25–26. On September 21, a water retention dam in Ban Lai Lao, Tha Ko Subdistrict, Mae Suai District, broke, and the Mae Lao River eroded the base of the Mae Lao Bridge at the junction of Pa Daet Subdistrict, Si Thoi Subdistrict, and Mae Phrik Subdistrict. This bridge is a main route for residents of Pa Daet Subdistrict traveling to Wiang Pa Pao District and Mae Suai Hospital. Si Thoi Subdistrict uses this main road to reach Mae Suai District. On September 27–28, the Mae Lao River flowed into Mae Lao District, affecting the Phahonyothin Road bridge at the junction of Mae Lao and Phan Districts. The river then entered Mae Lao District, severely impacting villages in Bua Sali Subdistrict. The water then rushed into Wiang Chai District and flowed into the Kok River.

Meanwhile, in Phayao Province, flooding occurred in front of Phayao University in Mueang Phayao District, affecting students living in university dormitories, forcing them to stay on the dormitory rooftops. The water also reached Mae Tam Subdistrict in Mueang Phayao District, impacting the Phayao Municipality area. On September 23–24, the Ping River received runoff from several districts in northern Chiang Mai Province, causing the Ping River's water level to rise steadily, surpassing critical levels on September 24. The water level rose and flooded Chiang Mai city through drainage pipes in surrounding areas, with water levels stabilizing in the morning of September 25.

On September 30, it was reported that a monsoon trough passed through the northern provinces, causing heavy rainfall. At 00:00 on October 1, there was heavy rain almost all day. The Meteorological Department predicted that this would be the last rain of the season. The affected province was Chiang Rai, particularly in Mueang Chiang Rai District, where heavy impacts were seen on Phaholyothin Road in the areas of Nang Lae Subdistrict and Tha Sut Subdistrict. Especially in front of Mae Fah Luang University, small vehicles could not pass through. In Ban Du Subdistrict, lightning struck near the B-Quik tire shop in Ban Du branch, located along the road to Mae Fah Luang Chiang Rai Airport, next to Big C Chiang Rai 2, causing a large fire. In front of Chiang Rai Rajabhat University, there were also impacts as water from Doi Phrabat Mountain overflowed. Areas previously affected by floods on September 11 were hit again. Mae Sai District also suffered severe impacts, particularly in areas previously flooded on September 11. Additionally, the Kok River rose in Mueang Chiang Rai District, Wiang Chai District, Wiang Chiang Rung District, Mae Chan District, Doi Luang District, and Chiang Saen District, causing further impacts. In Chiang Mai Province, Mae Ai District was affected by the Kok River. On October 5, the Ping River overflowed its banks, flooding Tha Phae Road from Nawarat Bridge and spreading widely. On the eastern side of the Ping River, water flooded over a 2-kilometer radius. Kaew Nawarat Road was heavily flooded from the base of Nakornping Bridge to the Child Court intersection and the Arcade Bus Station area. On October 6, water expanded in all directions from the Ping River, from Chiang Mai Municipality to downstream areas in Saraphi District and several areas in Lamphun Province. The overflow from the Ping River breached the flood barriers of Chiang Mai Municipality, flooding economic and community areas such as the Night Bazaar, Chang Klan Road, and Kad Luang. On the same day, in Thammamun Subdistrict, Mueang Chai Nat District, Chai Nat Province, located north of the Chao Phraya Dam, water from the Chao Phraya River overflowed into Moo 4, Thammamun Subdistrict, as the earthen embankment used as a flood barrier collapsed. Authorities were unable to bring machinery, tools, or sandbags to seal the breach, resulting in flooding of residential and agricultural areas, affecting over 100 households.
November 27, floods occurred in Narathiwat Province, Pattani Province, Yala Province, and Songkhla Province, which are provinces in the southern region.

His Majesty King Vajiralongkorn and Her Majesty Queen Suthida granted high-pressure water sprayers to assist in cleaning the homes of flood victims in Chiang Rai Province. Paetongtarn Shinawatra, the Prime Minister, posted on Facebook, stating that she has been monitoring the flood situation in the northern provinces and expressed concern and worry, while sending encouragement to all affected families and officials currently working to their fullest capacity. Phumtham Wechayachai, Deputy Prime Minister, stated that after meeting with relevant agencies, it was confirmed that the current flood situation is not as severe as the floods in 2011. The Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Interior issued an order appointing the Deputy Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Interior to act as the Governor of Chiang Rai Province and transferred the Deputy Governor of Chiang Rai Province, effective October 2, 2024.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Florence on November 4, 1333, was one of the most disastrous floods of the Arno that struck the Tuscan capital and its surroundings. Although the waters did not reach the level of November 4, 1966, the damages were probably the most extensive ever recorded in the city for such an event, with the highest number of victims: around three hundred.

Many chroniclers remember the events of this flood. The most famous of all is Giovanni Villani, who was an eyewitness and reported that from November 1st there was a great deluge of water, which poured over Florence and all of Tuscany for four days and four nights. The river level rose rapidly and began to overflow already in the Casentino, the plain of Arezzo, and the Upper Valdarno. At the gates of Florence, at the confluence with the Sieve - a river that had also flooded the Mugello area - the Arno was already extremely high, and on November 4th (coincidentally the same date as the 1966 flood) it inundated the San Salvi and Bisarno areas, reaching a height of ten braccia (almost six meters). In the evening, the waters broke the embankment wall near the Corso dei Tintori, severely flooding the Santa Croce area, then reaching San Pier Scheraggio, San Pier Maggiore, and even the Duomo's gate. We know that in the Baptistery of San Giovanni, the water reached almost to the matronea and covered halfway up the porphyry columns beside the central portal; in the church of Santa Reparata, it reached the vaults and caused the nearby column of San Zanobi to collapse; in the Badia Fiorentina and Santa Croce, it submerged the central altar. In the inner courtyard of Palazzo Vecchio, the water reached six braccia in height, more than three meters. At Vespers, the waters broke the Ognissanti weir and caused the collapse of the Ponte alla Carraia, leaving only two arches on the north side. The second bridge to collapse was the Ponte Santa Trinita, of which only one pier and an arch on the side of the church of the same name remained. The third was the Ponte Vecchio, which had been rebuilt about 150 years earlier after the 1177 flood, and in the collapse, the statue of Mars positioned on a pillar at the bridge's entrance, at the corner of Via Por Santa Maria, was also lost. The statue, also mentioned by Dante in the thirteenth canto of the Inferno (v. 144), had already been swept away by previous river floods but, although damaged, had been recovered and placed back to guard the Arno to protect the city. However, during the 1333 flood, it was no longer recovered from the waters, and its destruction was seen as a forewarning of future misfortunes. The only bridge to withstand was the Ponte di Rubaconte (the current Ponte alle Grazie), although damaged by the collapse of its parapets, while the nearby Altafronte castle was destroyed. The flood caused severe damage in the countryside as well, in Brozzi, Campi Bisenzio, Signa, the Prato countryside, the lower Valdarno, and Empoli, which lost its walls, all the way to Pisa. When the waters finally receded, streets, houses, cellars, and shops were invaded by foul-smelling mud, and it took more than six months of work for cleanup operations; wells were damaged and had to be dug anew and deeper; there was also damage to crops, mills, and ovens, causing a shortage of food supplies, mitigated by aid received from surrounding cities such as Pistoia, Poggibonsi, and Prato. According to Villani, the confirmed human victims were about three hundred, and a vast amount of livestock was lost. The damage to homes, public buildings, and road infrastructure, especially the bridges, in the city of Florence was estimated at more than 150,000 florins.

Memories of this catastrophic flood are still visible in the city today. The most famous is perhaps the plaque at Canto dei Soldani in Via San Remigio, where an inscription in rhyme recalls the level reached by the waters here, 4.22 meters above the current walking level. M CCC XXXIIIDI QUATRO DINOVEMBRE GIUOVEDILA NOCTE POI VEGNENDOL VENERDIFU ALTA LACQUA DARNO ĪFINO AQUI  
_ Above it is, much higher by about thirty centimeters, the plaque marking the water level during the 1966 flood. On the Ponte Vecchio, there are also two plaques (one in vernacular and one in Latin) commemorating its reconstruction twelve years later, in the form that remains today. On the Arno-facing side, near the building north of the monument to Benvenuto Cellini, there is a plaque in Gothic characters in very poor condition (half is illegible). A small carved hand indicates the beginning of the text: † IN THE THIRTY-THREE AFTER THE THOUSAND THREE HUNDRED THE BRIDGE FELL DUE TO A FLOOD OF WATERS THEN TWELVE YEARS LATER THE MUNICIPALITY DECIDED TO REBUILD IT WITH THIS ADORNMENT On the opposite side, under the arches of the Vasari Corridor, another 14th-century plaque in Latin recalls the collapse and reconstruction of the bridge. To the left of the text is a winged idol on a pedestal, also referenced in the text, though its presence is not entirely clear. Translation: "On November 4, 1333, this bridge collapsed due to a whirlwind of many waters; then in 1345, it was rebuilt more beautiful and adorned. This child briefly shows what happened." The tragic Florentine flood of November 4, 1333, is the subject of an ancient serventese by a poet of the time, Antonio Pucci, titled "Novello sermintese, lagrimando" and handed down through the so-called "Kirkup" manuscript. The author, a firsthand witness to the disaster, identified its fundamental cause in the unbridled desire for wealth of the Florentines. Over the years, they had exploited the course of the Arno River by constructing numerous docks that were meant to ensure, along with the bridges providing connectivity between the two banks, a road and river network essential for the activities carried out upstream and downstream of its bed. Mills, fulling mills, and weirs (at the time placed on large wooden rafts anchored to the riverbanks) were also built to facilitate water supply during dry periods. One of the causes of the disaster was attributed precisely to the multitude of these productive structures along the river's course: it was believed that, together with the weirs that fed them and the bridges, they had hindered the free flow of the river. A few centuries later, Giovanni Targioni Tozzetti also mentioned the flood of 1333. The Florentine scholar wrote in 1767 to Grand Duke Leopold of Tuscany in the "Examination of some projects made in the 16th century to save Florence from the floods of the Arno," regarding the river, the problems related to its bed, and its floods such as the disastrous flood of 1333: "many times it has caused, and will increasingly cause in the future, the Arno River, its [Florence's] discontented and treacherous guest (...) but what is worse, with the constructions its natural bed was usurped and disrupted (...) on November 4, 1333, swollen with water and almost indignant at the constraints in which the good Florentines intended to keep it, delivering a furious blow to the Ponte Vecchio and the other two bridges of S. Trinita and Carraia, it destroyed them and carried them away along with the Ognissanti weir; then, to regain possession of its ancient and proper bed (...)."

Article_Name: Riada de San Calixto, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The great flood of the Segura in 1651, also known as the San Calixto flood, was a devastating natural disaster that affected the lower valley of the Segura River in the early hours of October 14 of that same year. This event occurred due to an isolated depression at high levels (DANA), which caused intense rainfall in the region, estimated at more than a thousand liters per square meter in a few hours. The overflowing waters of the Segura flooded much of the valley, causing severe damage in towns such as Murcia, Orihuela, Molíns, Algorfa, Almoradí, Benijófar, Rojales, and Guardamar del Segura. The impact of the flood was devastating. It is estimated that at least a thousand people died, mainly in areas located near the riverbed, due to the collapse of houses and the sweeping away of people by the strong current.

On the night of Saturday, October 14, an intense storm surprised the city's population while they slept. Unlike previous occasions, there was no time for a general alert or the activation of a parish emergency organization, and the defenses, already weakened by a previous flood on September 20, were in critical condition. The force of this flood far exceeded the previous one, breaking the dikes and defensive structures that still remained. The storm began to unleash its force at three in the morning. Shortly after, the waters of the Segura, Mula, Guadalentín rivers, and the Nogalte and Sangonera ravines converged, increasing the flow of the Segura River and causing a violent surge that swept away everything in its path. The current broke dikes and the river's weir, in addition to causing severe damage to the Malecón. Buildings located near the river were flooded, forcing the evacuation of several convents, such as San Agustín and those of the nuns of Verónica and the Mother of God. The material damage was immense. In Murcia, the flood destroyed the parishes of San Antolín, Santa Eulalia, San Juan, San Lorenzo, San Miguel, and San Andrés, and demolished hundreds of houses. The cathedral also suffered the onslaught of the waters, which entered during the celebration of a mass, forcing the officiant to take refuge in the tower with the Blessed Sacrament. Although nearly a thousand deaths were reported, mainly in neighborhoods and hamlets near the river's course, other estimates suggest that the deaths numbered several hundred. The waters reached heights of up to three stadia, remaining at that level for hours. At nine in the morning, after a brief respite in the rains, the river level continued to rise until three in the afternoon, that is, twelve hours after the storm began.

Once the flood had subsided, the Murcia City Council focused on two urgent priorities: repairing the city's defenses to prevent a future catastrophe and cleaning the water and mud accumulated in the streets. The presence of stagnant water raised concerns about possible outbreaks of diseases. During the first three days after the flood, the water level remained high, and although it later began to recede, the city's streets remained flooded due to a change in the course of the Segura River, which now flowed through the city via the broken weir. To divert the water flow, a commission was sent, which decided to break the counter-weir on October 28, helping to drain the city. The repair of the Malecón, one of the key defenses, was essential. To ensure its prompt reconstruction, the City Council required all citizens to participate in the work or hire someone to do it on their behalf, with jurors organizing the work groups. This order caused discontent among the hidalgos, who resisted performing physical labor, claiming that their privileges exempted them from such obligations. However, the City Council responded that, in the face of the emergency, no one was exempt, as there were no "privileges to avoid the risks and damages of the flood." Even the Count of Castro and other councilors hired people in their place to support the work. To reassure the nobility, the City Council clarified that participating in the reconstruction of the dyke did not harm their privileges, as it was a "virtue" in service of the public good and the protection of the city. This act reflects a more modern perspective of the time: although the system of privileges was accepted and defended, in the face of extreme necessity, the common good could prevail, albeit without affecting the essence of those privileges. Among the testimonies of the time is that of María Ángela Astorch, a Barcelonan nun of converso origin and abbess of the Capuchins of Murcia, who described in detail the effects of the flood in a memorial addressed to King Philip IV. In her writing, Astorch denounced the state of ruin and misery in which the region had been left. The flood occurred at a critical moment, as the Segura Valley was recovering from a deep economic crisis, worsened by the expulsion of the Moriscos in 1609. However, despite the magnitude of the tragedy, the Spanish Crown did not allocate aid for the recovery of the territory.

Article_Name: Inundaciones de la provincia de Badajoz de 1997, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods in the province of Badajoz in 1997
Whole_Text.content: The floods in the province of Badajoz in 1997 were a natural disaster that took place between November 5 and 6, 1997, severely affecting the city of Badajoz (Extremadura, Spain) and its surroundings. This event was caused by a process of explosive cyclogenesis that generated an episode of torrential rains.

The meteorological phenomenon that triggered the floods was a subtropical-origin storm that underwent an explosive cyclogenesis process as it moved toward the Iberian Peninsula. This storm, accompanied by highly organized storm systems, caused intense and persistent rainfall in Extremadura, with particular significance in the province of Badajoz.

During the night of November 5 to 6, torrential rains saturated the already wet soils from previous precipitation. Numerous points in the province recorded rainfall exceeding 100 l/m², notably the city of Badajoz, where up to 125 l/m² and wind gusts of 130 km/h were recorded, and Valverde de Leganés, where the 136 l/m² caused the overflow of the Las Piletas stream, which ran underground through the town. The Rivillas and Calamón streams overflowed, devastating the Cerro de Reyes neighborhood in the south of the capital of Badajoz.

The floods caused the death of 3 people in Valverde de Leganés and another 22 in Badajoz. Hundreds of families were affected by the destruction of homes and businesses. The Cerro de Reyes neighborhood in the capital of Badajoz was the most affected, but the flood also devastated the neighborhoods of Antonio Domínguez, San Roque, and Pardaleras. The response from the authorities included the construction of new homes and the investment of more than 100 million euros to expropriate houses near the waterways, demolish them, and adapt the stream banks into parks as exclusion zones against possible future floods.

Article_Name: Riada de Alicante de 1997, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Alicante flood of 1997 was an episode of torrential rains that occurred on September 30, 1997, considered one of the most severe natural disasters in the history of the city of Alicante (Spain). This phenomenon, caused by a cold drop, resulted in a tragic toll of four deaths, hundreds of injuries, and significant material damage that transformed the urban landscape and infrastructure planning of the city.

The event was caused by a pocket of cold air in the upper layers of the atmosphere that interacted with the moisture accumulated in the Mediterranean Sea after a hot summer. This phenomenon, known as a cold drop, is common in southeastern Spain, but the intensity and concentration of the rainfall exceeded previous records. During the storm, up to 267 liters per square meter were recorded in six hours, with a maximum intensity of 156 liters per square meter in just an hour and a half.

The day began with heavy rains around 8:00 in the morning, coinciding with the start of daily activities. At that time, the city was bustling, with workers heading to their jobs and children on their way to school. In just over an hour, the water flooded streets, basements, and commercial premises, paralyzing traffic and leaving vehicles floating as if they were made of paper.

Although there was a brief respite mid-morning, the rain intensified significantly around 1:00 PM, causing the city to collapse completely. The most affected areas included Playa de San Juan, La Albufereta, Sangueta, and the center of Alicante, where water flooded the construction site of the Alfonso el Sabio parking lot, turning it into a gigantic pool. In some places, such as the Juncaret, Bonhivern, and Orgegia ravines, the water reached over 1.5 meters in height. In urban areas, such as Plaza de la Montañeta, the water swept away vehicles and urban furniture. At the train station, more than 400 people were trapped, and the University of Alicante was completely flooded, requiring the evacuation of students and professors.

The flood left a toll of four dead, including a mother and her son who were swept away by a sewer, and more than 200 injured. The material losses were incalculable, with entire neighborhoods flooded, businesses destroyed, and communication routes cut off. The sewer system collapsed, and railway and airport operations were suspended.

The security forces, such as the Police, firefighters, the Civil Guard, and Civil Protection, worked tirelessly during the emergency. Human chains were organized to rescue trapped people, and in some areas, inflatable boats were used to reach isolated residents. Citizen solidarity was key to facing the catastrophe, with dramatic rescue images and collective efforts standing out.

After the disaster, the Anti-Flood Plan was implemented, an ambitious infrastructure project designed to mitigate the impact of future torrential rains. The plan included the construction of 40 kilometers of underground collectors, 18 kilometers of them beneath the urban core, and additional works such as the San Gabriel rainwater reservoir, with a capacity to store 60,000 cubic meters of water, and the floodable park of La Marjal, which acts as a containment area in San Juan Beach.

Whole_Text.content:
Polish Flood of 1924  
The flood in Poland in 1924 was a natural disaster that affected most of Poland at the beginning of spring 1924. The Vistula River overflowed its banks. Along its course, ice floes carried away elements of homes, railway lines, and bridges. Near Modlin, ice jams were broken up using artillery. On the section of the river from Warsaw to Włocławek, a strip 3-5 km wide along its course was flooded. In Włocławek, the river level rose by three meters. Fatalities were reported in this area. In the vicinity of Toruń, despite attempts to prevent it, water overflowed, flooding the Ciechocinek valley. In the Gdańsk region, railway traffic operated through water. Bydgoszcz was flooded. The Lviv-Warsaw railway line was out of service due to the destruction of railway embankments. In addition to the Vistula, the Brda, Narew, San, Warta, Dniester, and Prut rivers also overflowed. Across the country, many bridges were destroyed, and embankments were undermined.

Article_Name: Ola de calor en Argentina de 2023, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heat wave in Argentina in 2023 was an extraordinarily late extreme heat phenomenon that occurred from February 28 to March 20 of that year, mainly in the central region of the country, as well as in the northern and coastal areas. It was the longest heat wave experienced in Argentina since the heat wave in 2013, affecting especially the provinces of Buenos Aires, Santa Fe, Córdoba, and all the northern provinces where multiple cities recorded record temperatures. It was characterized as an unusual heat phenomenon, not only because of the duration of the event but also because of the magnitude of temperatures during the month it occurred, as in March in Argentina, temperatures tend to drop due to the beginning of autumn. The heat wave is associated with the Atlantic anticyclone, a new extremely intense La Niña phenomenon in the Pacific, and the regional effects of climate change. A heat wave is characterized by a marked and sustained increase in temperatures, especially the maximums, occurring in several cities, above what is considered extreme.

According to the National Meteorological Service, the heat wave is due to the presence of high pressures that create an atmospheric blockage interacting with a constant influx of warm air coming from the north through a high-pressure system in the South Atlantic Ocean, which results in persistent and unusually late high temperatures for this time of year.

The National Meteorological Service reports, through its daily updates, information on the development of the heatwave. It covers the center and north of the country, encompassing 18 provinces, with two more added if the north of Patagonia is considered.

During the heatwave, new records of national electricity demand were set, exceeding 28,500 MW. On March 1, a massive blackout occurred, affecting more than 6 million users in the north and center of the country, impacting half of the nation. According to the Secretariat of Energy, a grassland fire affected a power line, prompting the Atucha I plant to suspend its activities preventively. Intense increases and decreases in the number of households without power were also recorded on the following days.

Amid the heatwave, the combination of high temperatures and a historic drought triggered forest fires in areas such as the Costanera Sur Ecological Reserve and the Iberá Wetlands, which affected agriculture in Argentina's weakened economy and caused a considerable increase in the price of various agricultural products such as eggs or vegetables. Soybean and corn crops, the country's main harvests, are suffering the impact of extreme heat. The period of extremely high temperatures and the absence of rain allowed the proliferation of Thysanoptera, tiny insects that invaded the province.

In 2023, a heatwave is occurring in Bengal, with an intense heatwave flowing in Bengal and mild heatwaves affecting parts of Bihar, Odisha, and Tripura-Meghalaya. The heatwave began in early April, marking the highest in nearly half a century in the region's history, with the highest temperature of 42.2 degrees recorded in Chuadanga district of Bangladesh on April 15. Due to the heatwave, health warnings were issued, school and office hours were disrupted, power outages occurred, and there was an unusual disruption in normal daily life.

A May study by World Weather Attribution found that climate change made heatwaves at least 30 times more likely in India and Bangladesh, and climate change increased April temperatures by about 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit).

Bangladesh experiences mild heatwaves in some areas and severe heatwaves in others. With the rise in temperature, the humidity in the air also decreased. On April 16, the capital of Bangladesh, Dhaka, witnessed another severe heatwave after 58 years, recording a temperature of 40.4 degrees Celsius. On the same day, Bangladesh's Environment Minister Md. Shahab Uddin informed the media that a 'temperature-related emergency' might be declared to address the severe heatwave crisis.

In early April, a mild heatwave was observed in West Bengal. On April 13, a temperature of 39.6 degrees was recorded in Kolkata. The India Meteorological Department issued a heatwave warning for West Bengal, and the state government declared the closure of all educational institutions in the state due to the heatwave.

Throughout the month of May, temperatures fluctuated, with storms and rain in some areas and mild to severe heatwaves in others. On May 9, the weather forecast indicated severe heatwaves in five districts of the country and mild heatwaves in several others. On May 8 and 9, a temperature of 41 degrees Celsius was recorded in Chuadanga, while 40.5 degrees Celsius was recorded in Kumarkhali and Netrokona, and 40.3 degrees Celsius in Rajshahi, according to the Meteorological Department. On May 21, a press release from the Bangladesh Meteorological Department stated that mild heatwaves were sweeping over the districts of Rajshahi, Pabna, Jessore, and Chuadanga and might continue. Towards the end of the month, temperatures began to rise, and on May 31, the Meteorological Department forecasted that mild to moderate heatwaves were sweeping across the country and would persist.
A heatwave warning was issued in West Bengal on May 27. The Indian Meteorological Department fears that by the end of May and in June, the temperature may exceed 40 degrees Celsius.

At the beginning of June, the temperature rises, and on June 2, an intense heatwave swept over the districts of Rangpur, Dinajpur, Rajshahi, and Syedpur in Bangladesh, while a mild heatwave began to affect parts of Sylhet, Patuakhali, Bhola, Barisal, Chandpur, Noakhali, and Feni districts, as well as parts of Dhaka, Mymensingh, Khulna, Rangpur, and Rajshahi divisions. During this time, the highest recorded temperature in the country was 41 degrees Celsius. [14]
The Indian Meteorological Department's press release states that mild to severe heatwaves are ongoing in several districts of West Bengal, including Kolkata, and may continue until June 7.

Article_Name: Tonn teasa in Éirinn agus sa Bhreatain, 2023 - Vicipéid

Whole_Text.content: The highest temperature ever recorded in Ireland during the month of June was 28.8C on June 13, 2023, at Oak Park Station in County Carlow.

The average temperature in June 2023 was 16 degrees Celsius. The average temperature had never been so high during the month of June in Ireland since 1940. According to Met Éireann, June 2023 was the hottest June ever in Ireland up to that point. The Weather Office stated at the time that higher temperatures and more thunderstorms are expected due to climate change. During June 2023, the sea on Ireland's west coast was 5 degrees Celsius warmer than usual, a major concern for scientists. In August 2023, the Killybegs Fishermen's Federation expressed concern about the impact of climate change on white fish stocks such as cod, and the risk that with a significant change in sea temperature off the Donegal coast, fish such as cod, haddock, and herring would move to cooler northern waters. It was warm in Ireland during September. The people of the Corca Dhuibhne Gaeltacht were surprised when drops of Saharan dust fell on them from the sky.
The highest temperature ever recorded in England was during June 2023, exceeding 30C.[11]
The World Meteorological Organization issued a warning in 2023 that the continent of Europe is warming twice as fast as other continents.
