Article_Name: Ola de calor en Europa de junio de 2022, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heatwave in Europe in June 2022 was an unusually early episode of extreme heat that affected Portugal, Spain, France, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. In Spain and France, countries affected by drought, high temperatures favored the outbreak of wildfires.

The heatwave was due to an interaction between high pressures that generate atmospheric stability and Cyclone Álex, the strong insolation of the boreal summer, and a mass of air coming from North Africa, which entered the Iberian Peninsula loaded with suspended dust and caused haze in the central and southern parts of the peninsula.

The special warning for high temperatures was activated by Aemet on June 10, but only for 12 provinces, with yellow alerts in Aragón, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, Extremadura, and Madrid, and orange alerts in Andalusia. In this initial stage, the unusual heat did not affect the Canary Islands, Galicia, the western Cantabrian coast, and parts of the Mediterranean peninsular coast. Initially, Aemet forecasted that the heatwave would last until Wednesday, June 15, without ruling out the possibility of it continuing for the rest of the week. On June 11, high temperatures were already recorded in the southwest of the peninsula, with 41°C in Seville. Alerts remained active for Aragón, Castilla y León, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, and Madrid at the yellow level, and orange for Extremadura and Andalusia. However, the meteorological conditions did not meet the official criteria to declare the start of the heatwave. On June 12, thermometers recorded 43.2°C in Almadén (Ciudad Real), the highest value on the official start day of the heatwave. Temperatures above 40°C were also recorded at 47 Aemet network stations. Additionally, the agency issued special notice number 3/2022 with information about the phenomenon, its forecast, and announced the start of the national plan for preventive actions against the effects of excessive temperatures on health, including a level assignment map. In the province of Almería, a 62-year-old man died after collapsing and showing symptoms of dehydration while hiking on the Antenas trail near the Totem of Aguadulce. On June 13, Aemet announced in its official report a possible end date for the heatwave on Thursday, June 16, while noting that "due to the behavior of a DANA (isolated depression at high levels) located in Madeira, whose evolution cannot be precisely determined." On June 14, the heatwave extended to southern Galicia and the interior of the Cantabrian region. Tropical nights also continued, with thermometers not dropping below 20°C in many provinces, particularly in Jaén, where a minimum of 27°C was expected. Furthermore, it was forecasted that the peak of the heatwave would be reached on Friday, June 17, breaking some temperature records in cities like Zaragoza, Lleida, and Córdoba. The only areas in Spain that had so far escaped the heatwave were Asturias, the Canary Islands, and the autonomous cities of Ceuta and Melilla. In its daily report, Aemet forecasted the end of the meteorological episode for Saturday, as the DANA in the Atlantic, which injects hot African air, approached the peninsula, causing instability and a drop in temperatures. In Vega de Valcarce, a 69-year-old German pilgrim possibly died from heatstroke while walking the Villafranca del Bierzo stage of the Camino de Santiago. Rubén del Campo, Aemet spokesperson, stated that it was the "most intense heatwave for mid-June in at least the last 20 years." On June 15, the "Iberian exception" was applied for the first time, whereby the regulated price of electricity is calculated with a cap on gas for its generation. The PVPC (Voluntary Price for Small Consumers) means higher electricity bills due to compensation for thermal power plants and increased use of gas and coal during the heatwave. Once this unusual heatwave subsides, it will be seen if PVPC-referenced bills decrease when all air conditioners are no longer running simultaneously. On June 18, the extraordinary heatwave that affected Spain between June 11-12 and June 18 came to an end, being described as "intense, extensive, and extraordinary" by the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), which also highlighted that this spring heat episode was one of the earliest recorded in the country. On June 20, Monday until 12 p.m., the Zaragoza City Council extended the orange alert of the Civil Protection Emergency Plan for the heatwave, which had been activated on Tuesday, June 14, due to the high temperatures affecting the city, exceeding 40°C on several days and not dropping below 25°C on some nights. On July 6, the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) published a report detailing the month of June, highlighting the intense heat episode that extended from the first day of the month until June 19, with both maximum and minimum temperatures well above normal, particularly high during the central days of the month, due to an invasion of warm air from North Africa. The heatwave in the Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands between June 11 and 18, 2022, was the earliest occurrence in the series, matching records with the one that occurred on June 11, 1981.

On June 16, Météo-France activated a red alert in 12 departments and an orange alert in another 25 due to a heatwave. The departments under red alert are mainly located in the southwest, along the Atlantic coast, and the south, while the severity is generally lower the further north and east. This is the earliest heatwave on record and the fourth time a red alert for heat has been issued since the protocol was established following the 2003 heatwave. On June 17, the red alert was activated in 14 departments, with the Hautes-Pyrénées and Pyrénées-Atlantiques added to the twelve from the previous day. Additionally, an orange alert was activated in 56 departments.

On June 14, in response to the Met Office's forecast of high temperatures, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issued level 2 health alerts in several regions for the period between midnight on Thursday the 16th and midnight on Saturday the 18th. The affected regions were London, the East Midlands, London and the East, Southeast, and Southwest of England. On June 15, the UKHSA issued level 3 alerts for London, the East, and the Southeast of England, maintaining level 2 alerts for the East Midlands and the Southwest of England. According to the Met Office forecasts, the heat peak would arrive on Friday, reaching the threshold necessary for the consideration of a heatwave, before temperatures dropped significantly on Saturday the 18th. On June 17, London exceeded 32°C on the hottest day of the year so far. According to Stephen Dixon, a Met Office spokesperson, temperatures above 30 degrees "are not unusual, but it is uncommon to see such high temperatures so early in the year." Dixon added that the temperatures on that same day would be the highest since the summer of 2020.

On Wednesday the 15th, a heat wave alert was activated in the Italian-speaking canton of Ticino. The following day, Thursday, June 16, the French-speaking cantons of Geneva and Vaud issued their own alerts. On the 16th, the Federal Office of Meteorology and Climatology (MeteoSwiss) reported that temperatures between 31 and 33 °C had been recorded in the southern Alps, central Valais, and the Lake Geneva region, but the threshold to be considered a heat wave (average temperature of 25 °C throughout the day) had only been exceeded locally. On Friday, June 17, MeteoSwiss activated orange and yellow heat wave alerts for most of the country. Maximum temperatures between 32 and 37 °C were expected from that same day until the following Tuesday in low-altitude areas of Valais and French-speaking Switzerland, and between Saturday and Tuesday in the Basel region.

In Spain, after the heatwave of 1981, it is the earliest heatwave on record. The episode began on Sunday, June 12, 2022, when temperatures above 40°C were recorded at 47 stations of the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet) network, located in Andalusia, Extremadura, and Castilla-La Mancha. This heatwave follows two other related climatic episodes in Spain in 2022: the widespread drought in the winter of 2021-2022 and the hottest May of the 21st century. The heat caused hundreds of swift chicks to prematurely leave their nests, falling to the ground as they did not know how to fly. The Seville-based NGO Ecourbe, dedicated to biodiversity conservation, reported that up to one hundred chicks were collected from the ground in a single day in Córdoba and Seville. Comisiones Obreras of Extremadura demanded that the reduction of the workday by one hour for construction workers be brought forward, as this reduction is applied from July 15 to mid-August. On June 15, the Madrid City Council activated the red alert protocol for meteorology, given the forecast of a combination of temperatures above 35°C and wind gusts of more than 55 km/h, and consequently closed nine parks in the Spanish capital. The high temperatures, along with the drought, created conditions of extreme risk for forest fires throughout peninsular Spain, except for Galicia, most of the border with Portugal, and isolated points along the coast. A fire in the Sierra de la Culebra (Zamora) forced the evacuation of eight municipalities, while another fire in the province of Toledo led to the evacuation of 3,200 people from the Puy du Fou España theme park. High temperatures in schools caused an increase in dizziness and fainting among children. Families, teachers, and experts called for a plan to adapt schools to future heatwaves, which they will face if no action is taken for the next school year. Air conditioning should be the last resort to lower temperatures in schools, as it accelerates climate change, which in the coming years will cause more frequent and extreme heatwaves. The Community of Madrid manages four public swimming pools in the capital. Until Thursday, June 16, the intention was to keep them closed until the end of June. Swimming in pools alleviates the unpleasant thermal sensation caused by extreme heat, so public complaints led the Sports Councilor, Marta Rivera de La Cruz, to change the plan for opening these public pools. She apologized to the people of Madrid: "It is true that the heatwave should have brought forward that opening." She announced that next year they will open at the beginning of the month, as was historically done until 2019. On Monday, June 20, hospitals in Zaragoza recorded an "unusual peak" in emergencies due to the heatwave. Some patients had to wait more than 60 hours to be admitted due to a lack of beds, with conditions caused in elderly and chronically ill people by the prolonged heatwave of the previous week. This new workload due to the heatwave adds to the burden that hospital emergency staff have been enduring for more than two years.

In the twelve French departments on red alert due to the heatwave, the Ministry of National Education and Youth established several preventive measures. Among them, it allowed primary and secondary school students not to attend classes on Friday, June 17, if parents so wished. Likewise, several departments have implemented restrictions on outdoor physical activity. The Gers prefecture recommended canceling any outdoor physical or sports activity. The Gironde prefecture urged its residents not to exercise outdoors and banned any public events outdoors or in non-air-conditioned venues. In Tarn, the broadcast of the Top 14 rugby championship semifinal between Castres Olympique and Stade Toulousain on a giant screen was prohibited. Finally, several departments, even without being on red or orange alert, have recommended that drivers reduce their speed on the road.
Northern Italy experienced the worst drought in the last 70 years. The flow levels of the Po and Tiber rivers recorded very low levels for this time of year, with the Po reaching critical levels.

The Royal Ascot equestrian event took the unprecedented step of relaxing its dress code, allowing men to remove their hats and jackets after the royal procession. It also allowed spectators to enter the enclosure with drinks.

Article_Name: Ciclone de 1941 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content:
Edit - edit source code - edit Wikidata  
The 1941 cyclone (also known as the 1941 winter storm[1]) was a strong winter storm that originated from a vast depression centered west of Ireland but extending its influence to Western Europe and the Iberian Peninsula. A few hours later, it generated a strong winter storm,[1] which affected a vast area of Portugal and half of the Northwest of the Iberian Peninsula.[2] The result of local situations, with short spatial and temporal dimensions, was associated with strong vertical instability of the troposphere and the consequent cloud cells with significant vertical development (such as tornadoes and downbursts, or generalized to a larger area, lasting several hours.[1]

The storm originated on February 14, 1941, in a vast depression with 980 hPa at its center (at the surface) located west of Ireland but extending its influence to Western Europe and the Iberian Peninsula, in the form of a disturbed westerly current under a vertical circulation regime. The jet stream, in the upper troposphere (300 hPa), exhibited the highest speeds of 230-240 km/h, between 35º and 40º North latitude, over the Azores.

A few hours later, at 00h on the 15th, the low-pressure area underwent an amplification of a cyclonic wave in the altitude flow (geopotential at 500 hPa), generating a baroclinic wave between the Azores and the Iberian Peninsula. This, due to the strong dynamism of polar air (of Greenlandic origin) on the western flank of the trough and the intensification of convergence in the lower and middle levels of the troposphere on the eastern flank of the trough (due to increased cyclonic vorticity), triggered a process of strong cyclogenesis in the Atlantic west of mainland Portugal. By early afternoon (12h UTC) on the 15th, there was an increase in vertical wave amplitude, intensifying strongly over mainland Portugal and the adjacent Atlantic, resulting in cyclogenesis, which took on characteristics of explosive cyclogenesis. By definition, a cyclogenesis situation is termed explosive when atmospheric pressure drops by at least 1 hPa per hour over a 24-hour period (for a latitude of 60º, the pressure drop value may be slightly lower for 40º latitude). The stormy wind speeds (from the east) observed are due to the combination of strong cyclogenic activity with the approach and passage of a very active cold frontal surface. Throughout the afternoon, the center of the frontal disturbance, on its northeastward path and still in the deepening phase, was located at 18h UTC over northwest Portugal and Galicia, with a minimum surface pressure of 950 hPa. However, just a few hours later, during the rapid filling phase, at 00h UTC on February 16, the center of the disturbance was already near Brittany and significantly less deep (975 hPa at the surface) and filled, becoming part of a vast complex Atlantic depression, a normal and frequent situation at this time of year at these latitudes.

In Portugal, the high number of fatalities, exceeding a hundred, and the undefined number of injured individuals stand out. Many of the fatalities, especially in Lisbon, Alhandra, Sesimbra, and Alhos Vedros, were likely due to drowning caused by floods that occurred in the riverside areas. These floods are believed to have resulted from the combination of multiple factors, among which the sea level rise or storm surge stands out. This rise refers to the temporary increase in sea level caused by abnormal meteorological conditions, particularly variations in atmospheric pressure and/or the action of strong and prolonged winds. Several railway disruptions were also reported, caused by accidents, some of which resulted in fatalities (e.g., Lamarosa/Coimbra: train collision with 2 fatalities; between Travagem and Leandro/Minho, due to a fallen tree, 3 deaths). The road and electrical networks were also affected, mainly due to fallen trees. Hundreds of boats are believed to have sunk, and the damage to forests amounted to hundreds of thousands of uprooted trees. In popular culture, it became known as the year of forty-one, the day the wind swept everything away, leaving no roof untouched by its force. From the perspective of the regime's response to this natural disaster, it was carried out through the Subsecretariat of State for Social Assistance, which presided over the National Relief Commission for Cyclone Victims. This commission was formed by government initiative, aiming to address the needs of small family economies ruined by the catastrophe, particularly concerning the need for food, the recovery of their homes, and work tools. To raise funds, a propaganda campaign was designed by the Estado Novo through the National Broadcaster and some newspapers, such as Diário de Notícias. This was one of the first contributions of the then newly created Subsecretariat of State for Social Assistance as the coordinator of the Estado Novo's social policy.

The storm of July 14, 2010, was a storm that passed over Belgium, Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and Switzerland on Wednesday, July 14, 2010. The storm was accompanied by downbursts and gustnadoes. Several tornadoes also formed, including in Friesland.

A few days ago, there was warm air over Europe with temperatures exceeding 30°C. On July 14, there was a low-pressure area southwest of Ireland. Over Eastern Europe, there was a strong high-pressure area. This caused a southern flow that brought cooler air over the continent. The temperature differences caused a severe weather system over France that produced heavy thunderstorms. The air pressure at Reims first dropped by 7 hPa every three hours and then rose by 6 hPa every three hours. During the afternoon, the depression quickly moved over Belgium and the Netherlands.
In Belgium, a gust of wind of 137 km/h was recorded. The temperature in Diepenbeek dropped from 31.0 to 18.8 °C within an hour. Downbursts caused significant damage around Ciney.

On Monday, July 12, a severe storm already swept over North Rhine-Westphalia. Two days later, the storm was less intense. Nevertheless, eight people were injured in Aachen. Düsseldorf Airport had to be temporarily closed. The city of Goch was hit by a tornado, as was Hervest. The Dorsten Lock was damaged, reportedly by a tornado according to eyewitnesses.

In the Netherlands, wind speeds of up to 125 km/h were recorded. The village of Neerkant was hit by a vortex. Shortly thereafter, a campsite in Vethuizen was struck by a downburst. This resulted in one death and nine injuries, one of whom later passed away. The KNMI launched an investigation to determine the cause and extent of the high wind speeds.
In the Surb Valley, strong winds blew at speeds of up to 109 km/h.

Article_Name: Tempesta de novembre del 2001 a Mallorca - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The November 2001 storm in Mallorca was a very violent storm that struck the entire island of Mallorca on November 10 and 11, 2001. The wind and water were the main causes of the damage, which resulted in deaths, power outages, fallen trees, and blocked roads. The storm, which also affected the Valencian Community and Catalonia, reached Mallorca on November 10 from the Arctic and was the most significant in the western Mediterranean in fifty years. There were four fatalities, more than 150,000 trees fell, causing a significant deforestation impact, 65% of the road network was blocked, more than 175,000 families were left without electricity at home, and classes were suspended for the entire week. During the storm, up to 250 liters per square meter of rain fell in certain areas, and winds reached 150 km/h. The most violent part of the storm subsided on the evening of November 12, but bad weather continued until November 15. The storm affected the entire island. In Palma and Calvià, there were two fatalities, and another in Alcúdia; in Sóller, the most rain fell, while the entire Llevant coast and the Bay of Alcúdia experienced strong winds and gusts. The most affected municipality was Pollença. However, snow only fell above 900 meters and was scarce. All ports in the Balearic Islands and the Llevant coast were closed during the most intense days of the storm. The losses were in the millions, valued at 37 million euros, mainly affecting the primary sector as the storm devastated farmland. The storm also caused damage to heritage sites, with the necropolises of Son Real and Illot dels Porros and the Talayotic sanctuary of Punta del Patró in Son Real suffering significant damage. The sanctuary, excavated that same summer, was almost completely destroyed, while at the necropolis of Illot, several slabs were displaced, and at Punta dels Fenicis, the bones from tombs that had not yet been excavated were exposed.

Article_Name: Tempesta del 29 d'agost de 2020 a Mallorca - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The storm of August 29, 2020, in Mallorca was a storm that affected the entire island but was particularly violent in the central area of the Serra de Tramuntana. It caused numerous material damages and spectacularly devastated large forest areas, but there were no serious injuries. Meteorologically, it was a squall accompanied by a downburst and one or two waterspouts, with heavy rain and hailstones of considerable diameter. The most affected areas were the municipalities of Banyalbufar and Esporles and, to a lesser extent, Valldemossa; specifically, the storm hit the area between the road connecting Banyalbufar with Esporles and the sea, particularly the Port del Canonge area, as well as the vicinity of Son Cabaspre. Both the Banyalbufar road and the Port del Canonge road remained closed, the latter for two days, and both localities were without telecommunications or electricity until a generator was brought in. Regarding people, a family and a group of workers had to be rescued, but there were no serious injuries. Among the damages caused, in addition to disruptions to the electrical and telephone networks and roads, there were numerous rockfalls, collapsed walls, broken tiles and windows, damage to buildings of great heritage value (such as the church of Banyalbufar, the Baronia, and the houses of Son Bunyola and Son Coll), and widespread flooding that ruined crops not only in the most impacted area but also in corners across the island. Specifically, a large part of the season's vineyard and olive production was lost, and many greenhouses were damaged. In the Banyalbufar area, depending on the property, crop losses were estimated between 50% and 90%. The Banyalbufar City Council requested the declaration of a disaster area, but it was ultimately not granted.

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub concerning Europe and meteorology or climatology. edit - edit code - edit Wikidata The storm of November 26, 1954, is a violent meteorological event that affected northwestern Europe in November 1954[1].

This storm is centered over northwestern Europe between Ireland and Sweden. Wind gusts are recorded at 140 km/h in Cherbourg. Atmospheric pressure drops to 729 mmHg (the average atmospheric pressure at sea level is 1,013 hPa or 760 mmHg). This storm is rated at force 12 on the Beaufort scale.

The damage is significant. On the southeast tip of Great Britain, the lightship indicating the Goodwin Sands runs aground. In France, this storm affects fishermen at sea. Thus, the ports of Finistère are particularly bereaved, with 64 fishermen missing in the southern part of the department. The fishing port of Concarneau is particularly affected: five boats disappear, and the neighboring town of Névez counts 17 missing. On December 16, 1954, a ceremony is held in the church of Concarneau, bringing together 7,000 people.

Storm Darcy (in Germany storm Tristan) was a storm that affected parts of Western Europe from February 6, 2021. In the Netherlands, Belgium, the east of the United Kingdom, and parts of northern and western Germany, the strong wind was accompanied by drifting snow, creating snowdrifts.

Whole_Text.header: Consequences in the Netherlands and Belgium
Whole_Text.content: On February 6, the KNMI issued a weather warning for slipperiness, after which the GGD announced that all COVID-19 testing locations would close on February 7. On Sunday, February 7, the NS did not run any trains. In Belgium, the KMI declared code orange. The consequences remained limited.

Whole_Text.header: Consequences for the rest of Europe
Whole_Text.content: In areas of Germany, 25 to 40 centimeters of snow fell. Train traffic there was also largely brought to a halt. In the north of England, flooding occurred, caused by both snow and rain. Furthermore, many trains were canceled, and people were advised not to take the train.

The downburst in Stebno was the most destructive manifestation of an extreme storm that caused significant damage as it passed through the western part of the Czech Republic on Thursday, June 24, 2021, particularly in the village of Stebno in the southern Ústí nad Labem Region. The estimated amount of damage ranks the storm among the worst natural disasters in the Podbořany area. Meteorologists initially believed that the damage in Stebno and its surroundings was caused by a weaker tornado, but after several days, they determined the cause to be a strong downburst, a descending current of cold air. The occurrence of a strong downburst and significant material damage to property remained overshadowed in the media by the extreme tornado in the Břeclav and Hodonín regions and the extensive damage it caused.

A storm with a downburst occurred after a week of high frequency of extreme meteorological phenomena in Central and Western Europe. On Thursday, June 24, meteorological conditions, for example, north of the eastern edge of the Alps, were very favorable for the formation of supercell storms, as there was very high convective available potential energy (CAPE) in the atmosphere and at the same time a significant wind shear. The Czech Hydrometeorological Institute issued a warning about the occurrence of very strong storms with torrential rainfall.

A strong supercell, or supercell storm, formed in northern Bavaria, subsequently entered the Czech Republic, moved northeast through Mariánské Lázně towards the Podbořany region, and began to dissipate and vanish over the Central Bohemian Region. According to Meteopress, the storm lasted 4 hours, while Jan Sulan from the Plzeň station of the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute (ČHMÚ) estimated its duration at approximately seven hours. The storm originated around 2 p.m., approximately 80 km northeast of Nuremberg. This extremely powerful storm entered the Czech Republic after 3 p.m. in the area between Dylení and Cheb, over the Český les nature park. The storm maintained a northeast direction and moved at a speed of approximately 70 km/h. It was accompanied by heavy hailstorms; for example, in the vicinity of Dolní Žandov, large accumulations of hail were left on the meadows after its passage. The storm passed through Mariánské Lázně around 4 p.m. with torrential rain and hailstorms, with some hailstones exceeding two centimeters in size. Rainfall on the slopes of the Úšovický stream valley, where the spa town is located, soon caused a local flood on the Main Street. Water mixed with hail rose on the streets to a height of several tens of centimeters. The hailstorm lasted approximately 10 minutes. The storm continued through Toužim, passed through Lubenec, where 17 mm of rainfall was recorded in ten minutes. In the Podbořany region, the storm with very strong gusty winds passed between 4:30 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. from the forest above Blatno, through Blatno itself, and continued through the Podvinecký stream valley in a northeast direction towards Stebno. In Blatno, the storm caused a whiteout that lasted approximately 15 minutes. The storm's passage through Stebno, according to residents, lasted only a few minutes, during which everything was enveloped in a white fog caused by the ongoing downburst. Residents reported that everything happened so quickly that they didn’t even have time to close their doors. The strong wind carried hail, roof tiles, and bricks against windows, breaking them and sending debris inside. The storm left behind a layer of hail up to 20 cm thick in the Stebno area. The storm, with a persistent downburst, continued towards nearby Petrohrad. Meteorologists estimated wind speeds of up to 200 km/h based on the recorded damage, corresponding to hurricane-force winds on the Beaufort scale. In the village of Lubenec, 17 mm of rainfall was measured within 10 minutes. The storm partially affected the Děčín region as well. The storm began to dissipate in the area behind Rakovník and vanished around 6 p.m. in the region of the Ústí nad Labem and Central Bohemian Region borders, with various sources reporting its dissipation near Štětí, beyond Kralupy nad Vltavou, or before Mladá Boleslav.

Several meteorologists from the branch of the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute (ČHMÚ) in Ústí nad Labem gradually commented on the events in the Podbořany region. According to Jana Ehertová's statement the day after the storm, everything in Stebno indicated the passage of a smaller tornado, and based on information from residents, her colleague Radek Tomšů also considered the possibility of a tornado, but field investigation was necessary to confirm it. Meteorologists estimated the tornado's strength at level three, later revising it to the first or second level of the enhanced Fujita scale. Even before conducting a field survey, meteorologist Martin Novák noted the rarity of tornadoes in the Ústí region according to statistics, as tornadoes are more likely to form and persist over smooth and flat terrain, whereas the Ústí region is predominantly hilly. Meteorologist Radek Tomšů conducted a local investigation on Friday, June 25, during which he leaned towards an extremely strong storm with hail. On Saturday, June 26, he confirmed obtaining photographs and announced a planned investigation using the Doppler radar. On Monday, June 28, Tomšů identified a strong downburst, the fall of cold air from the rear side of a storm cloud, as the most likely cause of the damage in Stebno and surrounding villages. Since it was a storm with a large amount of precipitation, it was classified as a wet downburst. The day after the downburst determination, TV Nova reported a funnel cloud as the cause of the damage in Stebno. Damage caused by a strong downburst resembles tornado damage and is similarly intense, but the two phenomena behave differently. While in a tornado, air spirals around the vortex funnel and moves inward and upward, in a downburst, strong winds caused by the descent of heavy air originate from a point source above the ground, rush sharply downward to the surface, and upon contact with the terrain, spread radially, i.e., straight in all directions from the point of contact, with the main impact directed in the direction of the storm's movement ahead of the storm cloud. The point source is the storm, in which heavy cold air accumulates. The air descent is often accompanied by heavy precipitation, hail, and noticeable wind gusts.
As a result of the storm with a downburst, no one was injured or killed.

Hail completely destroyed annual plantings in parks worth half a million crowns, trees and public lighting lamps on the colonnade were damaged. According to insurance companies, approximately 60 vehicle damages caused by hail were reported. In forests managed by the state enterprise Lesy České republiky north of the city in the cadastral areas of Mariánské Lázně, Rájov u Mariánských Lázní, and Sítiny, a storm caused a calamity in spruce stands, with the volume of broken or uprooted trees estimated at 5000 m³.

The storm significantly devastated: all houses in the path of the downburst were damaged, several houses lost their roofs – a total of approximately 40 residential houses were damaged. The most damaged was a new building on the edge of the village, which was expected to be demolished, but even for it, the structural engineer allowed repairs, and none of the damaged residential houses will be demolished. Through damaged roofs and windows broken by hail, water and hailstones entered the houses, together destroying or damaging the structures of the houses (thermal insulation, plasterboards, ceilings, floors, plaster) and their interior equipment. Dozens of farm buildings were variously damaged, sixteen barns collapsed, some buildings had walls knocked down by the wind, garages were damaged or roofless, and cars and tractors were damaged or buried. Probably the greatest damage, estimated at 15 million crowns, was suffered by Mr. Opat on his farm, as the broken walls will likely require the entire structure to be demolished. The electrical grid was damaged, with some poles falling. Rainwater on the surrounding fields flowed with topsoil into gardens, many of which are destroyed. Some of the damages are not covered by insurance or state aid, including damaged barns, equipment, tools buried under collapsed walls or roofs, and destroyed greenhouses. Some properties are not insured for replacement value. Repairs to partially damaged special roofing materials, which are no longer manufactured, are also complicated. The storm damaged the roof of the Church of St. John the Baptist, with most of the windows missing after the storm. Damage to the church, which was already in poor condition before the storm, is estimated at several million. The old park on the village square, considered a pride of the locals, was destroyed, including the pergola. All the trees in the park are damaged, many mature trees were broken and fallen. For example, the spruce alley and others around the church did not withstand the storm; according to a witness, the square was covered by trees lying on top of each other, with only lower trees and shrubs surviving. A wall in the cemetery collapsed, and some of the monuments fell. The property of the town of Kryry was insured, but the insurance did not cover public roads and greenery; the mayor, Brda, estimated the damage to municipal property a month after the storm at 28 million crowns. The need to repair the damage caused by the downburst will lead to changes in plans for the construction of a children's playground. The village was cut off from the world after the storm, with fallen trees on all access roads, and similarly, the recreational area was cut off. The forest on Baba Hill on the eastern edge of the village was cut down, but the damage was limited to the strip of the storm's path. The red-marked tourist trail was buried under fallen trees. Trees around Prošek's mill, called Na Nouzi, south of Stebno, were heavily damaged by the storm, some broken and twisted, others snapped by the strong wind; about twenty alders fell into the pond – according to the forester, 200–300 m³ of wood was damaged. The day after the storm, the mayor of Kryry, Miroslav Brda, reported preliminary damage of 100 million crowns, which is more than the annual budget of the entire town of Kryry. He anticipated that the consequences of the storm would take months to repair. By the end of August 2021, the total damage amounted to 150 million crowns.

Blatno: The storm damaged more than ten roofs, three of which were on municipal properties, the roof of the local woodworking company was damaged, the roof of a building owned by the State Land Office was blown off, and many fences and chimneys were damaged. One barn collapsed, the children's playground was completely demolished, but no houses needed to be torn down. Many trees fell, some onto roads, and the downburst also broke trees in the forest above Blatno. Crops in gardens were destroyed. After the storm passed, hail was everywhere, with some places having a layer up to 20 centimeters thick. Due to the rainfall, the Tisový stream flooded. In the vicinity of Blatno and Stebno, power lines were destroyed. Due to the power outage, the Vodafone transmitter located by the road between Černčice and Stebno and the T-Mobile transmitter between Blatno and Stebno were not functioning. Petrohrad: The village was damaged by the storm, but the extent of the damage was less than in Stebno, and no houses required demolition. Volunteer firefighters from Vroutek went to the village to pump out interiors flooded by the torrential rain. Kryry: Water flooded yards, garages, and houses in streets around the Blšanka stream, such as Vodní or 5th May Street, and mud flowed down the road from construction plots on the outskirts of the town in Pivovarská Street. Malá Černoc: Gardens at the confluence of the Černocký and Vlkovský streams were flooded. Bílenec: Trees fell in the village. Due to the aftermath of the storm, a large cultural event scheduled for Saturday, June 26, was canceled. Oráčov: The windstorm damaged several trees, one of which fell on the roof of a car, trapping two passengers inside who could not get out. Firefighters cut their way to the passengers and rescued them without injury. Děkov: Some cellars in the village were flooded with water, which was subsequently pumped out by firefighters. Dolní Žandov: A tree partially fell on a family house, and another fell in the cemetery. Drmoul: A tree fell on a parked car. Trees fell in many other places in the Karlovy Vary region, such as near Dolní Žandov, Lázně Kynžvart, around Mariánské Lázně, near Teplá, Otročín, or Žlutice.

The storm caused disruptions on several sections of railway lines due to fallen trees. Traffic was interrupted on line 149 between Teplá and Poutnov, on line 160 between Žihle and Petrohrad, and on line 161 from Blatno u Jesenice to Pšovlky. The Railway Administration restored traffic on all the mentioned lines on June 24.

In addition to the damaged forests around Mariánské Lázně, forest stands around Blatno and Stebno were also affected. Hailstorms destroyed crops in the fields around the mentioned villages. For example, the Petrohrad company had 150 hectares of wheat, 50 hectares of rapeseed, and 30 hectares of corn damaged by 85 to 100 percent. Private farmer Roman Opat farms on 214 hectares, and half of the fields were completely destroyed; the damaged crops were suitable for plowing under. According to the district agrarian chamber of Louny, over 100 hectares of hop fields were damaged in the path of the downburst in the Louny district. According to the Union of Hop Growers of the Czech Republic, the storm, along with others in June and July, almost completely destroyed the hop harvest on approximately 300 hectares of hop fields, with a total of 900 hectares of hop fields damaged. Hailstorms with hailstones several centimeters in diameter battered the plants, leaving bare stems without leaves. The damages are estimated in the tens of millions of crowns. In addition to the areas around Stebno and Petrohrad, damages to hop fields also occurred in the Rakovník and Litoměřice regions. The damages to the harvest should not affect the supply of hops to breweries, production, or the price of beer.

Immediately after the storm, the operations center of the Fire Rescue Service of the Ústí Region dispatched all professional and volunteer firefighter units from the surrounding area to the affected villages of Blatno, Stebno, and Petrohrad. Dozens of firefighters were deployed almost continuously for several days. Firefighters first had to cut paths into the villages through barriers of fallen trees. The coordination of the cleanup efforts was taken over by the commanding officer of the firefighters, Karel Spurný, the commander of the Kryry Volunteer Fire Department. In addition to firefighters, city employees from Kryry and energy workers participated in the damage removal in Stebno, working even during heavy rains. One ČEZ worker was struck by an electric current the day after the storm and was taken to the hospital, his life saved by volunteer firefighter Karel Spurný Jr. One of the priorities was clearing roads to allow ambulances to pass if needed. On the night from Thursday to Friday, a hundred firefighters from dozens of fire units worked on damage removal, responding to about thirty incidents, but according to the firefighters' own assessment, even this level of assistance was insufficient. Residents tried to secure residential houses against rain and clear debris from collapsed buildings, assisted by relatives. Repairs or demolitions of farm buildings are still pending. According to Miroslav Brda, the mayor of Kryry, people from the surrounding area came to the village, hindering rescuers. On Friday, June 25, over 120 firefighters were helping in Stebno, and a structural engineer inspected the damaged houses. Energy workers were working to restore electricity supplies but anticipated that the village would remain without power even on the night of Saturday. Volunteer firefighters cleared the only access road to the recreational area near Stebno, several hundred meters long, which was also blocked by fallen trees, and removed fallen trees in the forests around Stebno. On Saturday, June 26, the number of firefighters decreased to about 70 from 10 volunteer fire units, 4 units of the Fire Rescue Service of the Ústí Region, 3 units of the Fire Rescue Service of the Plzeň Region, and the Rescue Unit of Zbiroh. The removal of fallen trees, metal sheets, and parts of roofs from torn-off structures continued. On Saturday, the Kryry Volunteer Fire Department declared Stebno sufficiently safe for volunteers to join the assistance on-site and invited them for Sunday. On Sunday, June 27, firefighters from 27 fire protection units cleared debris, covered roofs, and cut damaged trees; due to the high number of firefighter units, a special fire alarm level was declared. The village was monitored by the Czech Police, who ensured order and secured properties in the absence of functional public lighting. On Monday, June 28, 70 people, including volunteer firefighters, members of the Ústí municipal police, residents of correctional facilities, and 30 city employees from Kryry, participated in the cleanup, with the total number of people involved in damage removal since the beginning estimated by Mayor Brda at around 600. According to the affected residents, there were still too few volunteers helping on Monday. On Tuesday, June 29, students and teachers from the Žatec Gymnasium joined the cleanup efforts in Stebno, and a large part of the village was cleaned up on the same day. From the end of June, 10 convicted women from the Drahonice prison participated in the volunteer cleanup, commuting to Stebno for a month to perform tasks such as sorting and cleaning bricks, cleaning, and loading branches. After completing rescue and cleanup operations, the Fire Rescue Service of the Ústí Region concluded its activities in Stebno on the evening of July 2. On Saturday, July 3, several dozen volunteers helped with the cleanup. Volunteers finished assisting the people and the village on July 9, as public spaces were cleaned, destroyed trees were cut and removed, and debris and waste were cleared. Any further volunteer assistance should only be provided with prior agreement. Mining rescuers from the Mine Rescue Station in Kladno–Libušín cleared a path to Proškov Mill on the Podvinecký Stream south of Stebno. They subsequently processed broken and fallen trees around the mill and removed trees that had fallen into the pond. Over 1,000 volunteers participated in the cleanup and other assistance. The cleared debris and waste are estimated at 15,000 tons, with not all collapsed barns removed as of July 11. The city of Kryry did not request assistance from the Czech Army, believing it could handle the storm's aftermath on its own, but later reports mentioned soldiers from the Czech Army removing debris with heavy equipment. At the end of September 2021, Mayor Miroslav Brda stated that funds from a public collection were used to clean up a massive waste dump, with the cleanup costing two million crowns. In October 2021, the demolition of irreparable parts of barns was still ongoing. During the ongoing removal of windthrows around Stebno and Blatno, some of the damaged wood was chipped, but there was no market for the resulting piles of wood chips.

In Blatná, many volunteers participated in clearing the damage, and fallen trees from public roads were removed by the Road Maintenance Administration. By Monday, June 28, most of the damage had already been cleared, and the municipality began transporting fallen and damaged trees.
Prisoners from the men's prison in Oráčov participated in cleaning up the municipality of Oráčov and removing fallen trees on June 25.

Mayor Martin Kalina immediately after the storm had all available city technical service personnel moved to clean up public spaces, [14] the cleaning of sidewalks, streets, and parks continued the following day. [38] Firefighters cleared the drainage channel to allow water to flow off the streets, [71] and in several places, they pumped out water. [38]

Whole_Text.header: Psychological help and mental state of the affected
Whole_Text.content: Experts state that people affected by a disaster initially experience a heroic phase. Adrenaline associated with rescue efforts, securing property, meeting basic needs, and general activity in the village affects the affected individuals. People have enough energy and determination to handle the adverse situation. This phase lasts one to two weeks and usually ends with the departure of rescuers, damage mitigators, and volunteers, when the disaster area calms down. Then, fatigue and anxiety begin to weigh on the affected individuals, and they start to fully realize the impacts of the disaster. Fear for life during the disaster can lead to the later development of post-traumatic stress disorder. Psychological help was offered to the residents of Stebno by the firefighters already on the scene. On Thursday, July 1, a post-traumatic team from the Fire Rescue Service of the Ústí Region arrived in Stebno, Blatno, and Petrohrad to provide psychosocial assistance. Subsequently, this assistance was ensured by the Spirála association, which will remain in contact with selected families for up to one year after the event. The Spirála association provided more intensive assistance in Stebno during July, but its activities were already reduced in August. In the third week of July, volunteers from several organizations, such as the Czech Red Cross, helped local people cope with the trauma. According to volunteers, the affected individuals sometimes hesitated to ask for help due to the feeling that others were worse off—volunteers therefore identified those in need directly in the field. When introducing workers at damaged homes, mentions of psychological help were omitted due to the negative stigma of psychological assistance in the Czech Republic. The people of Stebno experienced shock and fear for their lives during the storm itself, as the downburst struck completely unexpectedly (unlike, for example, floods); some perceived it as the end of the world or expected their death. The aftermath of the storm undermined the mental health of the residents, with local elderly women coping poorly with the event. According to Mayor M. Brda, depression from the shock and damage began to affect the residents of Stebno as early as Saturday, June 26. Two weeks after the storm, locals were physically exhausted, and their mental health deteriorated, partly due to fears of uncertainty about the coming days. Adults experienced bouts of sorrow and cried, breakdowns occurred, children were afraid to sleep alone in their rooms, and teenagers were scared during storms. People across age groups had trouble falling asleep and sleeping; for example, one affected resident had recurring memories of the storm and therefore slept poorly. Spirála workers also worked with a five-year-old child who began wetting themselves after the storm.

After the cleanup, which primarily took place until Sunday, June 27, residents began undertaking more extensive repairs to their properties. By mid-July, residents had usually completed work on damaged houses that they could carry out themselves or with the help of firefighters and volunteers. A persistent problem for further restoration was the unavailability of craftsmen, such as roofers, carpenters, glaziers, and building materials for roofs. For example, a roofing company from Vroutek repaired three roofs in the village but then returned to previously agreed-upon contracts. Many damaged roofs remained temporarily covered with tarps by mid-July, and residents hoped to complete roof repairs before the onset of winter. The execution of construction work was complicated by almost daily rains until mid-July. According to Eliška Ratiborská, coordinator of People in Need, a month after the storm, most owners of damaged roofs had secured materials for their repair. At the same time, one of the affected residents stated that she was still drying soaked walls in her house and waiting for a craftsman to repair the roof. The last of the damaged residential houses in Stebno was roofed on September 5, 2021, with the speed of work affected by the absence of consistent sunny weather without rain. Smaller interior repairs may continue. According to Tomáš Ratiborský, chairman of the STEBNO 2020 Beautification Association, Stebno should take advantage of the necessary restoration and propose comprehensive modifications with experts in architecture, urban planning, and dendrology. If sufficient funds were available for the restoration of the village's public space, Ratiborský suggested that residents should avoid self-help and amateur creativity. At the Kryry city council meeting held at the end of August 2021, an architect presented a possible design for Stebno's village square and grant programs suitable for financing the restoration. The city of Kryry plans to restore the square at a cost of 5.5 million crowns, divided into three phases, with part of the expenses to be covered by donations raised in a public collection, and it also hopes to receive contributions from foundations. On Saturday, September 25, a new children's playground was opened on the square, replacing the one destroyed during the storm. The playground, worth half a million crowns, was 80% funded by a grant from the Ministry for Regional Development and the city of Kryry's resources. During the ceremonial opening, two studies for the restoration of Stebno were presented. A study of the Green Square around the church was prepared by landscape architects. They propose planting new horse chestnuts and linden trees, with the first trees expected to be planted in the fall of 2021. A gazebo for residents' gatherings is to be rebuilt, the existing fire reservoir is to be converted into an ornamental pond, and the streambed running through the square is to be reconstructed. A memorial in the form of a small bell tower is also planned to commemorate the natural disaster. The repair of the damaged cemetery wall is scheduled for spring 2022.

The state was ready on June 25, the day after the storm, through the Labor Office in Louny to provide extraordinary financial assistance of up to nearly 58,000 CZK. According to the Minister of Labor and Social Affairs Jana Maláčová, 22 applications for extraordinary assistance were processed within a few days, and nearly 614,000 CZK were paid out. The State Land Office released 100 million CZK from the budget for land adjustments on June 25 for quick assistance to people and municipalities, intended for the restoration of infrastructure such as water and sewage systems. The company Lesy České republiky promised assistance to people from municipalities affected by the tornado, providing up to 50 m³ of timber for a new roof, including transportation to the nearest sawmill, or a donation of 100,000 CZK, and also offering each affected household 20 m³ of firewood. Lesy ČR estimates the cost of assistance at 150–200 million CZK. On the invitation of MP Pavel Růžička, Prime Minister Andrej Babiš visited Stebno on Saturday, June 26. The Prime Minister wished the residents strength and thanked the firefighters for their efforts. He confirmed material assistance from Lesy ČR for Stebno and other state aid, similar to that for affected municipalities in the Hodonín region. The mayor of Kryry, Miroslav Brda, welcomed the promise of assistance but will wait for its real form. According to MP Růžička, the Prime Minister's visit showed donors that help is needed not only in Moravia. The Prime Minister announced a visit by the Minister for Regional Development Klára Dostálová and the Minister of Agriculture Miroslav Toman on Wednesday, June 30. The Ministry of Agriculture prepared support for farmers, foresters, water managers, and food producers by launching the Framework Program for Risk and Crisis Management in Agriculture. It will compensate for damages caused to fields, orchards, vineyards, hop gardens, forest stands, animals, agricultural machinery, farm buildings, and equipment. Compensation will be provided up to 100% of the incurred damages, with state compensation reduced by insurance payments made by insurers. The extent of damage to agricultural property caused by the downburst and tornado in South Moravia was estimated at 1.5 billion CZK, the same amount was prepared within the mentioned program. The government approved the program on Monday, June 28, and farmers operating in the villages of Bílenec, Blatno, Černčice, Krty, Malměřice, Petrohrad, and Stebno could submit applications to SZIF from July 12 to August 17, 2021. Compensation for damages amounting to 627 million CZK will be distributed among 81 applicants, with 73 applications concerning damages in South Moravia. The Ministry for Regional Development will provide support to residents affected by the storms from the Živel SFPI program, created to help people affected by the tornado in Moravia and the downburst in Bohemia. From this program, they can receive a non-repayable grant of up to 2 million CZK for home restoration and borrow an additional 3 million CZK in the form of a favorable loan. For demolition or project preparation, residents could receive an advance of half a million CZK within 7 days, even before signing the grant agreement. Minister Dostálová anticipated that a two-million CZK grant would suffice for all affected residents to reconstruct their homes. On Saturday, July 3, fund officials helped residents in the village directly with filling out grant applications and recording damages, completing 39 applications on-site. Residents of Stebno pointed out the problem of destroyed uninhabitable buildings, which they needed to repair or rebuild to have space for storing equipment used for business or garden care. By early August, SFPI received 26 applications from Stebno, but none included the necessary cost estimate for property repairs (which can only be prepared by experts). In mid-September, MPs voted to increase the budget of the State Investment Support Fund by 1.8 billion to 5.24 billion CZK. Controversy arose over the government's decision to reduce state support by insurance payments and donations from public collections. On June 30 in Stebno, Minister Dostálová stated that the grant would be reduced by insurance payments made by insurers and that uninsured citizens, given the exceptional nature of the meteorological event, would receive the full amount of damages. Finance Minister Alena Schillerová explained the reduction of grants by insurance as the impossibility of double compensation for damages, later announcing the same level of support for everyone, only for the government to approve grant conditions the next day with deductions for donations and insurance. The reduction by donations and insurance payments was criticized by the public and the opposition. On July 7, Minister Dostálová proposed to the government to exclude donations from deductions but not insurance payments; the government excluded donations from deductions and decided to deduct 70% of insurance payments from the grant. Criticism was also directed at the provision of grants only for completed and approved buildings, prompting the government to change the conditions of the Živel grant program on July 19, allowing funds to be drawn for unfinished buildings. The state's approach was also criticized for offering interest-free loans to entrepreneurs while offering interest-bearing loans to citizens. The Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs prepared the Tornado program, intended for approximately 200 companies and employees affected by the downburst and tornado, with a volume of up to 280 million CZK per month. It was a variation of the Antivirus program, which was part of state support during the COVID-19 pandemic in the Czech Republic. In cases where obstacles arose on the part of the employer or employee due to the disaster, the employer could receive 100% of the actual wage costs incurred. Entrepreneurs and companies in affected municipalities were given the option to defer social insurance payments for June to November, but they must pay the insurance in 2021. Similarly, the Ministry of Finance waived penalties for affected business entities. The Ministry of Industry and Trade (MPO) prepared an investment program called Properties within the Operational Program Enterprise and Innovation for Competitiveness, amounting to 500 million CZK. Small and medium-sized entrepreneurs can apply for a grant of up to 35 million CZK for the restoration or expansion of operations. MPO is preparing another investment title for large companies and entrepreneurs in tourism. The Ministry for Regional Development prepared a program for the restoration of municipal and regional property damaged by the June storms, allocating 420 million CZK, with municipalities able to receive grants of up to 90%, exceptionally up to 100%, and regions up to 50%. On July 1, the government approved the deployment of up to 1,000 soldiers with necessary equipment to deal with damages upon the request of the region or the Integrated Rescue System.

Whole_Text.header: Neglect of Stebno by the state
Whole_Text.content: According to Pirate Party politicians Lukáš Blažej and Mikuláš Peksa, Stebno's position on the periphery of the Czech government's attention was also reflected in the governmental support after the downburst. Stebno was only added later to some programs aimed at supporting South Moravian regions affected by the tornado, and some programs were prepared exclusively for the South Moravian region. An example is the Ministry of Industry and Trade's (MPO) Tornado Assistance program with a subsidy of 200 million CZK, from which entrepreneurs could receive a subsidy of up to 1 million CZK for the restoration or acquisition of new property replacing destroyed assets or obtain support of 50,000 CZK for damage cleanup. Similarly, the Czech-Moravian Guarantee and Development Bank provided interest-free loans of up to 45 million CZK from the Expansion – Loans program only to entrepreneurs affected in South Moravia.

The city of Kryry immediately offered substitute accommodation to the citizens of Stebno after the storm, which no one used, and delivered basic food supplies. The day after the storm, the city of Kryry intended to pay for all necessary work from the municipal budget and did not announce a public collection. The city leadership was subsequently criticized for not having a known account for sending money for aid or for not informing the affected about a discounted offer for building materials. Financial resources could be sent to the city of Kryry's account from the end of June, and the city plans to use them for repairing public places in Stebno. At the beginning of July, the city council of Kryry decided to donate 20,000 CZK to each damaged property number in Stebno, and by July 8, they had paid out 1.42 million CZK to the citizens of Stebno. The city announced a public collection from July 9 until the end of the year. At the end of August 2021, the city council of Kryry decided to allocate 21 million CZK collected through the public collection, with 30% (7 to 7.5 million CZK) to be used for direct aid to affected citizens. The remaining approximately 14 million CZK will be used for repairing damaged public infrastructure and greenery, waste disposal, repairing municipal equipment damaged during cleanup, and for associations and organizations. Funds will be distributed to residents based on the extent of the damage and against documented repair costs. Residents with permanent residence in Stebno will receive a 100% subsidy ranging from 30,000 to 200,000 CZK, while cottage and chalet owners will receive half the subsidy. Opposition councilors criticized the approved system of fund distribution and proposed a fairer one. If grants for the restoration of public property are obtained, it is possible that citizens with damages exceeding one million CZK could receive additional aid from the public collection. The governor of the Ústí nad Labem Region, Jan Schiller, visited on June 25 to assess the extent of the damage and discuss whether some families needed further assistance, promising aid to affected municipalities in the region amounting to 1 million CZK. The councilors of the Karlovy Vary Region decided on June 28 to donate half a million CZK to the affected municipalities of the Ústí nad Labem Region and to announce a public financial collection to help all significantly affected municipalities. The Ústí nad Labem Region provided 50 dehumidifiers from the central humanitarian aid warehouse to people in the affected municipalities on July 3. The councilors of the Ústí nad Labem Region decided on July 12 to donate 2 million CZK to the city of Kryry and 200,000 CZK to the municipality of Blatno. On Wednesday, July 7, the councilors of the Plzeň Region decided to donate half a million CZK to the Ústí nad Labem Region to help Stebno, Blatno, and Petrohrad, while the councilors of the Liberec Region decided on the same day to donate half a million CZK to Stebno. The city of Louny donated just under 19,000 CZK each to the city of Kryry, the Stebno 2020 Beautification Association, the Lubenec parish, and the municipality of Blatno; the donated amount corresponds to the city's population. The city of Ústí nad Labem donated 1.5 million CZK jointly to Moravian municipalities and Stebno, and the city of Roudnice nad Labem similarly distributed one million CZK. The city of Kladno donated 1 million CZK to Stebno, Litoměřice half a million CZK, the city of Teplice 400,000 CZK, the city of Aš and the town of Nepomyšl each 300,000 CZK, the cities of Lovosice, Tanvald, and Bílina each 250,000 CZK, the Plzeň 3 municipal district 200,000 CZK, and Frýdlant 150,000 CZK. The voluntary association of municipalities Chomutovsko donated 170,000 CZK to Stebno. The city of Postoloprty donated 220,000 CZK to Stebno and 30,000 CZK to Blatno, while the city of Česká Lípa similarly donated 150,000 CZK to Stebno and 50,000 CZK to Blatno. The city of Frýdek-Místek donated 20,000 CZK to both, and the Prague 7 municipal district donated 10,000 CZK to both. The city of Příbram and the Prague 6 municipal district each donated 100,000 CZK, while smaller amounts were donated to Stebno by, for example, Mladá Boleslav, Děčín, Žatec, Lysá nad Labem, Žižice, Hostomice, Veltrusy, Týnec nad Sázavou, Zbečno, and the Prague 9, Prague 11, Prague 14, and Prague 17 municipal districts. The city of Krupka provided material aid to Stebno worth 150,000 CZK. The regional association of the National Network of Local Action Groups of the Czech Republic in the Ústí nad Labem Region donated 100,000 CZK to the municipality of Stebno, which is a member of MAS Vladař.

The Beautification Association STEBNO 2020, founded by locals in 2017 with the aim of restoring small monuments, collected financial resources in its account. The collected money was intended to be distributed among people affected by the storm or possibly for the revitalization of the village. Later, it joined an agreement of nine non-governmental organizations, foundations, and endowment funds on the transparent distribution of funds according to established rules. By September 20, 2021, the collection had gathered 5.022 million Czech crowns. The association also organizes material assistance, with companies and individuals offering various items such as roof tiles, building materials, as well as chickens, chicks, new trees, dog food, or expressing a desire to purchase specific items. On Friday, October 15, the material assistance warehouse ceased operations.

Coordinated assistance to people affected by extreme weather is planned to be provided by nine Czech non-governmental organizations, foundations, and endowment funds. The selected financial resources are intended to be fairly distributed among affected households, including those in Stebno. The humanitarian organization People in Need assessed the material damages in the Louny region as smaller than those caused by the tornado in the Břeclav and Hodonín regions but decided to help because some of the affected households were in significantly worse social situations. On June 30, the organization concluded 22 donation agreements with the affected individuals, amounting to a total of 3.1 million Czech crowns. Since many of the affected are seniors for whom organizing repairs is difficult, People in Need hired a local coordinator, Eliška Ratiborská, who will work together with the Beautification Association STEBNO 2020 to assist with restoration until the end of the year. At the same time, the organization will provide material assistance in the form of building materials, for example, securing 4 truckloads of roofing materials on June 30, and is collecting financial resources for the Louny region in the SOS Morava account, from which at least 5 million crowns will go to the area. People in Need has become the main coordinator for ensuring financial and material assistance. The Ústí-based Volunteer Center ensured the coordination of volunteers offering help to municipalities. Branches of the Czech Red Cross (ČČK) organized material collections, for example, the branch in Semily collected 6 tons of items such as generators, cookers, and tools for Stebno and damaged municipalities in Moravia, while the branch in Jablonec nad Nisou later collected only requested items. The local group ČČK Unhošť, in cooperation with the Regional Association ČČK Kladno, collected and purchased tools, building materials, and work equipment. At the beginning of July, ČČK released 2 million crowns for building materials for Stebno. The Diocesan Charity of Plzeň collected money to help the residents of Stebno, raising nearly half a million crowns by mid-July, and by early August, the amount exceeded 680,000 crowns. The charity also sent its Field Crisis Service team to Stebno, offering people crisis psychological support and immediate humanitarian aid. The Diocesan Charity distributed 631,000 crowns among eight families and established a crisis assistance fund for future extraordinary events with the remaining funds. Contributions for the restoration of the Church of St. John the Baptist could be made through the Dominanty Endowment Fund. The Czech Radio Endowment Fund launched the "Help Moravia with Us" collection, and residents of affected municipalities, including Stebno, could apply for financial support from this collection of up to 100,000 crowns starting June 27.

The public organized material collections, and from Saturday, June 25, a tent was set up in Stebno to store the collected materials, but due to the large quantity, the town of Kryry stopped accepting additional items on Monday, June 28. The residents of Stebno were grateful for any help but preferred assistance arranged in advance, as donations of clothing or hygiene, cleaning, and disinfecting supplies were unnecessary by early July. The Podbořansko municipal association announced a public financial collection to help the town of Kryry and the villages of Blatno and Petrohrad. The Ústí Community Foundation also launched a collection, intending to distribute the funds among affected citizens and the municipalities themselves, raising over 366,000 crowns by August 8. The Žluticko association collected 317,000 crowns for Stebno through a campaign on the znesnáze21.cz platform. Another collection for the affected villages is ongoing on the Donio platform. In the first days after the disaster, the Central Most department store organized material aid focused on cleaning supplies and toiletries, later placing a box for financial donations, which was subsequently stolen. Interestingly, the material collection "Help for Moravia," held in Rožmitál pod Třemšínem, ended up in Stebno after being rejected in southern Moravia. At a cultural event held on June 26, residents and visitors of the Krušnohorská village of Blatno raised 46,000 crowns to help the affected Blatno. Similarly, money for Stebno and Blatno was collected at a football match between FK Baník Most-Souš and the German Chemnitzer. The music group BengaBand organized a benefit concert on Saturday, July 10, in Mutěnín in the Domažlice region, raising 37,000 crowns, to which a local enthusiasts' association added over 7,000 crowns, and the municipality of Mutěnín contributed 50,000 crowns; a total of 94,000 crowns was sent to support the village of Stebno. On August 14, a benefit cultural event was held in Stebno to support and restore the village, with proceeds of nearly 110,000 crowns handed over to the town of Kryry. The event was not well-received by some residents of Stebno, as they did not consider a celebration in front of the ruins of still-unrepaired houses appropriate and did not want the damaged houses to be displayed. The Rotary Club Most collected 55,000 crowns for Stebno, including at a golf tournament in Bítozeves. The BigMat Foundation organized a benefit "Evening for Stebno" on August 7, 2021, in Václav Havel Park in Litoměřice to help the Bali family.

During the storm, Lukáš Přibík was in Litvínov, and upon his return, he experienced a shock when he found the family farm 80% demolished, with only the house remaining, albeit with a damaged roof, as all the farm's barns had collapsed, and roof tiles had damaged the car. The extent of the damage was likely influenced by the farm's location on the very edge of the village near the fields. His mother, Božena Přibíková, experienced the storm in Stebno, enduring shattered windows, torrents of water, and hail. The Přibík family received a donation from Vladimír Wűrtherle, a disabled man from Tymákov, who gave them 50,000 crowns he had saved for an electric leg prosthesis. The Přibíks will use the donation to purchase materials to repair the house. Josef Holák, the owner of a sheltered workshop in Jirkov, along with friends, provided the Přibík family with materials for roof repairs and window replacements worth approximately 300,000 crowns.

The Petráň brothers were born and live with their families in Stebno.[54] Jaroslav was in the yard at the beginning of the storm and took shelter in the workshop, from where he saw the barn collapse onto a car.[2] As a result of the storm, part of the gable collapsed, and the facade of Jaroslav's newly renovated house peeled off; water leaked through the damaged roof into the interiors, damaging drywall and insulation.[3][43][49][54] The family shoveled hail from the attic with shovels.[2] The barn roof collapsed, and falling masonry, the ceiling, and beams damaged the tractor, stored equipment, and tools inside, while outside, three cars were damaged.[3][54][235] Milan, the brother, also has damaged farm buildings, significant damage in their forests, and all the trees in their devastated garden are damaged.[3][54] On the last weekend of June, many people helped J. Petráň's family with cleanup,[236] and roof repairs are expected to follow.[49] Jaroslav Petráň believes that the insurance company will cover the damages to the insured property,[3] and he also inquired about a state grant from the Živel program.[125] Both brothers work as firefighters at Karlovy Vary airport, which means lower pay, and they cannot afford unexpected expenses.[54] A fundraiser for the Petráň families was launched on the Donio platform, raising over 30,000 crowns by the end of August.[237]

Shortly before the storm, they completed the reconstruction of the house they had bought in Stebno a few years earlier. When they were returning home, the storm caught them in their car in the yard of the house. They stayed in the car, which was hit by the roof of a wooden gazebo, an electric pole, and a tree. They escaped uninjured, with Mrs. Bali in her ninth month of pregnancy. The storm damaged the roof, and subsequently, water destroyed the floors, ceilings, and plaster, flooding the basement. It rained for the next two days, and the tarp covering the damaged roof could not prevent further water seepage into the house. The salvaged belongings were placed in an emergency shelter in the yard, and they began a second reconstruction. After removing the destroyed interior elements and insulation, only the outer walls and the bathroom remained of the house, with a blue tarp covering it instead of a roof. After clearing the debris and damaged parts, it was time to gather materials so that craftsmen could repair the roof. On July 8, their son Mathias, nicknamed Tornado, was born, and he stayed with his mother in Podbořany for several weeks because the house restoration was still ongoing. Michal Bali aimed to complete the house repairs in August and praised the speed at which the restoration progressed thanks to the help of friends and strangers. A financial collection for the Bali family was organized by the Litoměřice branch of the construction company BigMat, and another was organized on the darujme.cz platform by the handball club Lovci Lovosice.

The co-founder and chairman of the Stebno 2020 Beautification Association settled permanently in Stebno in 2005 when he completed the construction of a family house. This house was among the most damaged by the storm, which rendered it uninhabitable. During the storm, Mr. Ratiborský was approaching Stebno by car and eventually reached it via a field road. His wife endured the storm hiding in the garage with their dog and was in shock upon his return. The storm deprived T. Ratiborský of his roof, including skylights, and the photovoltaic panels ended up in a field. After the storm, his living room was covered with a layer of hail, and the ceilings, insulation, walls, and floors were soaked. The kitchen unit, including appliances, and the doors with their frames were damaged. The downburst also destroyed the garden, including trees. After clearing out, the house was in a rough construction phase. He was assisted in clearing the damage and removing the damaged equipment by mining rescuers from the Mining Rescue Station in Kladno–Libušín and many others. His granddaughter, Eliška Ratiborská, who initially came only to help her grandparents, eventually became the coordinator of People in Need's assistance.
