Whole_Text.content: The severe weather of June 18, 2021, consisted of heavy thunderstorms that passed over the Netherlands on June 18, 2021. Significant storm damage occurred particularly in Leersum and Tiel. Research by the KNMI revealed that this involved a downburst. Damage to high-voltage pylons in the municipality of Oldebroek was also caused by a downburst. The severe weather was part of a larger weather system that, from June 17 to June 20, affected the western European mainland with strong winds and large amounts of precipitation. On June 17, wind speeds of 100 km/h were reported in the southwest of France, and a small tornado was observed. In the vicinity of Reims, there were severe floods on June 19. The Belgian town of Beauraing was hit by a small tornado later that day.

On June 16, a temperature above 30.0 °C was measured in the Netherlands for the first time in 2021. This marked the first local tropical day of the year. A day later, the first official tropical temperature was recorded as the mercury in De Bilt rose to 30.8 °C. Wind from the west brought humid air from the North Sea to the Netherlands. During the night of June 17 to 18, more humid air arrived from France. By the morning of June 18, some showers had already occurred, with rainfall amounts between 10 and 20 mm. The forecast for the rest of the day was that wind at higher altitudes would increase. Due to a low-pressure area approaching from the south, vertical wind shear with wind speeds up to 40 kts was also expected. CAPE values were predicted to rise to between 2,000 and 2,500 J/kg. During the day, the first regional heatwave occurred as temperatures above 25.0 °C were recorded for five consecutive days in various locations. Due to significant temperature differences between the air layers, the warm air near the ground could rise quickly. Because of this and the high humidity, there was significant cloud formation, and hailstones could develop at higher altitudes. According to meteorologist Michiel Severin from Weerplaza, all the ingredients for extreme showers were present due to the "[tropical heat], very humid air, great instability, a wind that shifts with altitude, and also a weak low-pressure area." Marco Verhoef described the situation as "explosive." The KNMI considered the possibility of a supercell forming, and a local tornado was not ruled out. From midnight, a yellow code warning was issued, which was upgraded to an orange code warning for much of the country by the evening of June 18.

The description of the course of the severe weather is based on the live blogs of Johnny Willemsen from Weeronline and Diana Woei from Weerplaza.[17][18] Early in the afternoon, it reached 30°C in Maastricht. It also became tropically warm in Arcen, Eindhoven, and Ell. Around 2:00 PM, the first intense thunderstorm developed near Bruges, moving towards the North Sea. Forty-five minutes later, the first storm hit the Netherlands, in the western part of Zeeland. In several places in North Brabant, tropical temperatures were also recorded. In the north, it remained cooler, with temperatures between 21 to 25°C and below 20°C on the Wadden Islands. Around 3:30 PM, more thunderstorms occurred near Eindhoven, west of Zeeland, and in western Belgium. Just after 4:00 PM, more thunderstorms developed near Rotterdam, The Hague, the Rivierengebied, and the southern part of the province of Utrecht. At 5:04 PM, code orange was issued for North and South Holland. The thunderstorms increased in number and intensity. At 5:27 PM, the code orange was extended to all provinces except Zeeland, North Brabant, and Limburg. About an hour later, a severe thunderstorm developed near Amersfoort with hailstones about ~3 cm in size. At 6:05 PM, storm damage was reported in Leersum. Around 5:30 PM, a gantry crane fell in Tiel, injuring one person.[19] At 6:56 PM, the code orange was downgraded. The three southern provinces received code green, and South Holland, Utrecht, and Gelderland received code yellow. Fallen trees caused a 9 km traffic jam on the A1 from Amersfoort to Apeldoorn near Hoenderloo. In the south, a few thunderstorms still occurred, but in the north and northwest, the storms remained more intense as the severe weather moved northward. In Bergen in North Holland, 114 mm of rainfall was recorded. Shortly before 8:00 PM, a downburst caused damage in the municipality of Oldebroek, where four high-voltage pylons were blown over. In the Drenthe town of Hollandscheveld, large hailstones fell. By 9:00 PM, the thunderstorms moved northeastward. Only the provinces of Friesland, Groningen, Drenthe, and Overijssel still had code orange. The damage in Leersum was so severe that the village was closed off, and emergency services escalated to GRIP 2. At 9:58 PM, only Groningen still had code orange.

The Dutch Association of Insurers called the storm "exceptional and localized." As a result, the extent of the damage could not be immediately determined. On July 1, nearly two weeks after the storm, the damage in Leersum was estimated at €7.3 million. At least six houses were declared uninhabitable. Nine people were injured in Leersum. In Tiel, a total of two people were injured. In addition to the person injured by the collapsed gantry crane, a second person was injured when a roof of an apartment building blew off. Twenty homes had to be evacuated. The total damage across the Netherlands was estimated at around €37 million. For comparison, that is about 13% of the amount insurers have paid out annually since 2007 for damage to cars and buildings caused by weather. The damage mainly involved leaks caused by fallen trees landing on houses, clogged sewers, and blown-off roofs. The forests near Leersum were heavily affected by the downburst. In the Lombok Forest, thousands of trees were blown down, and entire plots of production forest were lost. An area of 750 hectares was temporarily closed to the public for safety reasons. On July 2, 350 hectares were reopened. In 2023, the destruction was found to have positive effects on biodiversity. Between the fallen Scots pines, deciduous trees and other vegetation spontaneously appeared. Because human accessibility was greatly reduced, more animals such as deer and badgers appeared. Enthusiasts of dead wood, such as black woodpeckers, lizards, and various insects, also increased. Utrechts Landschap decided to improve accessibility again and created a special "storm path." In the Breeveen area, about 35 hectares were designated as a "storm reserve," where all dead wood remains in place. In the municipality of Oldebroek, four high-voltage pylons fell due to a downburst. According to transmission system operator TenneT, such a calamity caused by gusts of wind last occurred in 2008. The high-voltage pylons each weighed 16 tons, and the construction was designed to withstand wind gusts of up to 180 km/h. During the incident, the cables landed on a farm. No injuries were reported. Temporary replacement pylons were installed in the fall. Due to the coronavirus crisis, TenneT faced a material shortage, and the definitive pylons were only installed a year later. In 2022, the province of Utrecht allocated €1.5 million to restore tree planting along roads within built-up areas and in nature reserves around Leersum, Valkenheide, and Maarsbergen. The national government also provided financial support.
The storm in Gambia in 2021 was a storm that devastated Gambia from early to mid-July 2021.

The storm raged between July 2 and July 12, 2021. 16,849 people in more than 100 communities across all seven regions were affected. Villages, houses, schools, health centers, and communal seed storage facilities were destroyed. The storm led to internal displacement and homelessness, and 100 serious injuries caused by fallen walls and trees were recorded. On July 7 and 8, 2021, the storm reached the capital Banjul and the surrounding areas. According to the meteorological office, the wind speed was 85 km/h, making it the highest speed recorded in five years. Several areas in the western part of the country were without electricity and running water. Local authorities reported that at least ten people lost their lives.

The European Union is providing 200,000 euros in humanitarian aid following the storm in Gambia. The World Bank's country director in Gambia, Nathan Belete, had pledged support to the storm victims. The Gambia-Hilfe Freiburg e. V. received 41 hospital beds and about 200 bags of work clothing and other useful items as donations and sent them in an overseas container to Gambia for people in need. Additionally, 3,000 euros were collected in the first week of donations and forwarded.

The Vaia storm was an extreme meteorological event that affected northeastern Italy (particularly the mountainous area of the Dolomites and the Venetian Prealps) from October 26 to 30, 2018. The event originated from an Atlantic disturbance which, in the context of a severe wave of bad weather over Italy (also affecting the neighboring regions of Switzerland, Austria, and Slovenia), brought extremely strong winds and persistent rains to the region. The event is erroneously referred to as a "storm" (grade 10 on the Beaufort scale), but the winds reached "hurricane" speeds (grade 12), winds that typically originate only over tropical or subtropical waters of the planet. The extremely strong warm sirocco wind, blowing between 100 and 200 km/h for several hours, caused the fall of millions of trees, resulting in the destruction of tens of thousands of hectares of alpine conifer forests, thus constituting a true natural disaster: the crisis unit activated by the Veneto Region classified the event as worse than the Venice flood of November 4, 1966 (which nonetheless affected the entire region), the Veneto flood of 2010, and other previous meteorological events recorded in the area.

At 2:00 PM on October 26, the civil protection of the Veneto Region had decided to issue a red alert for part of the regional hydrogeological network. In particular, there was concern about the situation in the Taibon area, where a large fire (the most significant recorded in Veneto in recent decades), which broke out on October 24, had burned about 650 hectares of forests, compromising the stability of the terrain. Then, on October 28, following weather updates, the red alert for high hydraulic and hydrogeological risk was extended to almost the entire Veneto region.

They fell to the ground in just three days (October 27, 28, and 29) in the mountainous areas of Veneto and Trentino, with up to 715.8 mm of rain recorded at the Soffranco (Longarone) monitoring station, surpassing the data from 1966, and as much as 870 mm in Forni di Sotto in the Carnic Prealps in Friuli. For several stations in the Belluno area, the amount of rain that fell during the event set an absolute record since the Regional Agency for Environmental Protection began rainfall monitoring in the territory (since 1992). The flood affected some municipalities in Veneto, Trentino, and Friuli, as well as Lombardy. The most affected areas were Agordino, Cadore, Feltrino, Comelico, Carnia, Val di Fassa, and Val di Fiemme. The heavy and abundant rains caused the Piave and Brenta rivers to overflow, while to prevent the Adige River from overflowing, the Adige-Garda tunnel was opened. In the mountainous environment, several streams overflowed, and there were numerous landslides. The Alleghe Lake also overflowed.

The sirocco wind reached gusts of 192.24 km/h in Veneto on October 29 (instantaneous value reported at 10 m above ground) recorded by the Arpa station on Mount Cesen and 166.68 km/h by the homologous station on Mount Verena, while in Carnia gusts reached 200 km/h and 170 km/h respectively at the Osmer stations of Cima Rest and Col Gallina (Polcenigo). In Trentino, at Passo Rolle, the wind reached 217.3 km/h. The extremely strong gusts, comparable according to mountaineer Reinhold Messner to winds recorded on Mount Everest (with very intense average winds often exceeding the highest values of the Beaufort scale, between "violent storm" and "hurricane"), caused the destruction of numerous trees and, in several cases, the felling of entire forests. The areas most affected by the wind were the Altopiano dei Sette Comuni (especially Val d'Assa and Piana di Marcesina), Val Visdende, Agordino (Alleghe, Canale d'Agordo with Valle di Gares, Colle Santa Lucia, Falcade with Valle del Biois, Rocca Pietore, and the entire Valle di San Lucano in Taibon Agordino), the area surrounding Lake Carezza, the Valli di Fassa and Fiemme (particularly Paneveggio), and the Altopiano di Piné, as well as various areas of the Lagorai mountain range. Part of the Lombardy region (especially Valcamonica) was also affected by the events, with the most impacted areas being Passo Crocedomini in the municipality of Bienno and the municipalities of Paspardo and Cimbergo, as well as several areas in the municipalities of Sonico and Ponte di Legno. In particular, due to the uprooting of numerous trees along power lines and the collapse of pylons, there were severe disruptions to the electricity distribution across the mountainous areas of Triveneto. By October 30, Terna, Enel, and SET Distribuzione had managed with difficulty to restore power to 200,000 users in Veneto and Friuli, but by October 31, there were still 10,000 users without electricity in Carnia, 3,000 in eastern Trentino (Val di Fiemme and Val di Fassa), and 8,600 in the Vicenza area (particularly on the Altopiano dei Sette Comuni).

Still in the context of this storm, on October 29, two exceptional high tide events occurred that affected the historic center of Venice: the first peaked at 156 cm at 2:40 PM[23][24], while the second, caused by a thunderstorm accompanied by strong winds, peaked at 148 cm at 8:25 PM.[24] The maximum meteorological contribution (or residual) reached values comparable to or slightly lower than the extraordinary event of 1966, measuring almost 160 cm of residual. The minimum tide turned out to be the highest in Venetian history at +119 cm.

The final estimate of damages in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, according to the regional civil protection, amounts to 615 million euros. In Veneto (the most affected region), damages were estimated at 1.769 billion euros, while estimates for Trentino are around 250-300 million euros and 85.4 million in Alto Adige. In Lombardy, estimates are around 40 million euros in damages. Regarding forests, due to the wind, it is estimated that 14 million trees were felled (a figure never recorded in recent times in Italy) over an area of 41,000 hectares. In Lombardy, the damaged forest areas were identified by the Region through photo interpretation of images from the European Union's Sentinel satellite and are viewable on the Geoportal of Lombardy.

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The storm from November 6 to 8, 1982, is a meteorological event that affected part of Europe in November 1982. It caused violent winds of over 100 km/h, exceptional rainfall, and significant swells in the Gulf of Lion and the Provençal coast. In addition to numerous damages, the storm resulted in a total of 41 deaths. Due to its magnitude, it is the most violent and destructive storm in southern France in a century[1],[2],[3].

A depression forms off the coast of Europe, in the North Atlantic Ocean, on November 6, 1982, reaching an atmospheric pressure of 960 HPa, making it an Atlantic storm of the Ss type (Dreveton classification)[1]. It moves southeast and makes landfall at Cape Finisterre, Spain, the next day at 7 PM[1]. At the same time, high pressure systems stagnate over Eastern Europe, trapping cold air at ground level, particularly in the Po Valley: it is −1°C in Venice at 7 AM on November 7[1]. Changing direction, the storm moves northeast and reaches Brittany during the night of November 7 to 8 while weakening, eventually dissipating the following day over the British Isles[1]. The storm reaches its peak on November 7 while over France[2].

During its passage over France, east and south winds swept across the country, particularly in its southern half. Except for a few regions (Corsica, Alpes-Maritimes, Landes, Alsace, and Nord-Pas-de-Calais), the entire country experienced winds exceeding 100 km/h. Some exceptional values were recorded, such as 216 km/h at Mont Aigoual, but in plains and mid-altitude mountains, speeds over 130 km/h were measured, such as in Sète (166 km/h), Bouches-du-Rhône (162 km/h), Millau (155 km/h), Saône-et-Loire (151 km/h), and Pyrénées-Orientales (144 km/h). In the wake of strong winds at sea, swells intensified in the western Mediterranean, with wave heights of 9 to 14 meters or more off the coast of Languedoc, 6 to 9 meters in Camargue, 4 to 6 meters in Roussillon and Provence, and 2.5 to 4 meters on the Côte d'Azur. Heavy rains accompanied the winds, with a maximum three-day accumulation of 610 millimeters in Py in the Pyrénées-Orientales. The rest of the Pyrenees were heavily soaked, and a significant Cévenol episode developed with accumulations of 300 to 500 millimeters. Rainfall was also notable in the Provençal hinterland and Corsica. These precipitations caused the flooding of numerous rivers, particularly in the Cévennes and eastern Pyrenees. Foehn effects were observed on the western slopes of mountain ranges, such as in Corsica and the Pyrenees, leading to significant disparities in rainfall over short distances.

Weather conditions cause extensive destruction in Andorra and around thirty French departments: collapsed buildings, uprooted trees, washed-away roads, overturned chimneys and antennas, stranded ships, destroyed oyster farms, etc. The port of Sète is heavily affected by the swell. Power outages impact 700,000 households, or 2 million people. The human toll includes fifteen deaths and sixty injuries in France and twelve deaths in Andorra.

The storm depression Ginger was a storm in May 2000 that affected parts of Germany and the Benelux countries, as well as, to a lesser extent, Denmark. The event surrounding Ginger is considered a rare occurrence of a storm depression in May, as the temperature differences during this time of year are usually too small to trigger strong hurricane-like storms. Ginger was the last in a series of severe storms in Central Europe that raged from autumn 1999 to spring 2000.

In Germany, Ginger primarily affected the federal states of North Rhine-Westphalia, Lower Saxony, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, as well as the city-states of Bremen and Hamburg. In Salzuflen, a spa guest was killed by a falling branch. In Essen, a driver died after colliding with a vehicle of the Technical Relief Agency that was in operation.  
Several tents on the Heiligengeistfeld in Hamburg, which had been set up for the 94th Catholic Day, were destroyed by the storm. On the Expo 2000 site in Hanover, the fire department had to secure numerous tents as well as the roof of the Dutch Pavilion. On Norderney, the head of a wind turbine was torn off. In Hürth, the privacy fence of the ongoing first season of Big Brother was blown over.  
The German Maritime Search and Rescue Service rescued a total of 96 people from distress situations in the North and Baltic Seas caused by the storm. Off Cuxhaven, a fishing cutter sank, but the crew was rescued by the rescue cruiser Hermann Helms.  
In the western Baltic Sea, the strong southwest and west winds caused low water levels, which partially disrupted ferry connections.
In Eindhoven, a man and a child were killed by falling branches. In Oosthuizen, a man died.

Whole_Text.content: Storm Otto is a storm depression in the northern Atlantic. It hit the United Kingdom on February 17, 2023, causing damage in Scotland and Northern England, including power outages in over 30,000 homes. In Denmark, the storm particularly affected the northwestern regions. Ferries and trains scheduled to depart on February 17 were canceled due to the storm. The strongest gusts in Denmark were measured at Hanstholm at 38.1 m/s, where the strongest average wind speed was also recorded at 27.3 m/s. This means that Otto in Denmark was classified as a storm on the Beaufort wind scale. The Øresund Bridge was closed for several hours due to the storm. At Copenhagen Airport, many flights were canceled, and several incoming flights could not land.

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit source code - edit Wikidata The storm in Tubarão in 2016 occurred on October 16, when the city of Tubarão witnessed one of its greatest catastrophes. Wind gusts of over 160 km/h hit the city in Santa Catarina, causing catastrophic destruction.

Posts were knocked down by the gale, houses lost their roofs, and walls collapsed. Warehouses and buildings were destroyed. There were power and water outages. An 8-year-old girl died after trees hit the car she was in, in the São João neighborhood. The child's father was hospitalized in shock. In total, 21 people were injured, and eight were left homeless. A thousand houses and thirty public facilities were affected.

The municipality of Tubarão declared a state of public calamity on the afternoon of October 21, 2016. The document was signed by the mayor. According to the municipality, the state of calamity was declared because the damages caused by the windstorm "clearly exceed the capacity of the local public authority to respond to the crisis and manage it," the city hall reported.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Janis (Typhoon Number: 9507, JTWC Designation Number: 10W, International Name: JANIS) was a typhoon that formed on August 22, 1995, and dissipated on August 26, making landfall on the Korean Peninsula.

Due to heavy rain that fell in the central region of South Korea from August 23, prior to the arrival of Typhoon Janice, over 50 people died, and property damage amounting to nearly 100 billion won occurred. As a result, reports continued to suggest that additional damage would occur with the landfall of Typhoon Janice. However, the typhoon, which had already significantly weakened, made landfall on the central-northern coast around midnight on August 27, and the initially feared heavy rain of up to 150 mm and significant damage did not occur. Subsequently, the Korea Meteorological Administration announced that Typhoon Janice had transformed into an extratropical cyclone in the early hours of August 27.

Whole_Text.header: Storms in October and November 2023 in Slovenia
Whole_Text.content: Storms in October and November 2023 affected areas in Gorenjska, Savinjska, and northern Primorska in Slovenia. They caused rivers to rise, leading to floods in some places. According to media reports, the worst-hit areas at the end of October were the settlement of Baška grapa in Tolmin, the municipalities of Kamnik and Železniki, and in Savinjska in Luče, Nazarje, and Ljubno ob Savinji. In some places, the situation was serious, as Slovenia had recently experienced extensive August floods. Due to the consequences of the October storm, slightly fewer than 150 people were evacuated. The November storm had greater impacts primarily in Podravska, with rivers rising across much of the country, the sea overflowing its banks, and 15 people being evacuated.

On Thursday, October 26, 2023, the Slovenian Environment Agency held a press conference to warn about the upcoming heavy rainfall. A red weather warning was issued for the northern and western parts of the country, while an orange warning was issued only for central Slovenia and the southeast of the country. For Friday, a rapid rise in rivers and torrential streams was forecast in the early morning hours. Residents of the mentioned areas were urged to take self-protective measures and move their vehicles and valuable items. They also warned of an increased likelihood of landslides. On Friday, October 27, 2023, heavy rainfall swept across the country in the early morning hours. A weather cyclone that formed overnight over northern Italy moved eastward across the northern Adriatic and Slovenia during the morning. On the coast, the sea overflowed its banks, triggering sirens in Koper, Izola, Piran, and Portorož. During the day, 158 liters of rain per square meter fell in the Logar Valley area. In Bovec, 22 liters of rain per square meter fell in just half an hour, causing the Bača River to flood its surroundings. The rainfall was accompanied by strong winds. The Savinja River rose significantly, and in the Upper Savinja Valley area, sirens were activated as a precaution to alert people to floods and landslides. Torrential streams flooded the road from Ljubno to Gornji Grad, but it was soon passable again. The Dreta and Ljubnica rivers also caused problems. In Kamnik, the Veliki Dam on the Kamniška Bistrica River became clogged, causing the river to rise and overflow in certain areas. According to the N1 media outlet, residents were fearful of a repeat of the August flood scenario, but no other major inconveniences were reported. In the afternoon, the weather calmed down, most of the day's rainfall had already occurred, and only short showers were still possible.

On Thursday, November 2, 2023, the Slovenian Environment Agency informed the public at a press conference that a red meteorological warning had been issued for the northwest and an orange warning for the rest of the country, specifically for Thursday afternoon and evening and Friday night. A red hydrological warning was also issued for the northern and eastern parts of the country, with water levels expected to rise in all rivers across Slovenia. Meteorologists estimated the total rainfall in 24 hours in northwest Slovenia to be between 120 and 240 liters per square meter. Due to the additional soil saturation, they also warned of an increased risk of landslides. Civil Protection Commander Srečko Šestan signed an order to raise the readiness of the relevant services across Slovenia, except for Prekmurje. In the municipality of Tolmin, the road between Bača pri Modreju and Petrovo Brdo was preventively closed on Thursday afternoon due to the risk of landslides. Accommodation capacities were also being prepared for potential evacuees. In Braslovče, the head of the Flood Recovery Service, Boštjan Šefic, met with residents, presenting them with flood risks and measures, with initial estimates suggesting around 150 people might need to be relocated. Civil protection representatives also visited the field in several other municipalities, such as Kamnik, Škofja Loka, Tržič, Prevalje, and Izola, to ensure preparedness. The port of Koper was closed to traffic due to strong winds. On the night of Friday, November 3, the strongest wind gusts reached speeds of 185 km/h at Kredarica. In Bovec, 222 liters of rain per square meter fell within 24 hours. Meteorologists confirmed in the early morning hours that conditions were calming down, and since the worst-case scenario did not materialize, the ARSO agency downgraded the meteorological warning. Rivers across Slovenia flooded, including the upper Sava, the Sava Bohinjka, which caused disruptions in Bohinj and its surroundings, and rivers in the upper Soča Valley. In Tolmin, some roads were closed, and the previous evening, 28 residents of Baška Grapa decided to temporarily relocate due to endangered houses. The Drava River rose more intensely and flooded on a larger scale. In the morning, sirens were sounded in Dravograd and Vuzenica to warn residents about self-protection, and later in several other municipalities in the Drava region. The flow of the Drava River was among the highest in recent years, flooding, among other places, a police station. Due to the danger, 15 people from nine buildings were evacuated along Ribiška Pot. In Kranj, the rising Sava River reached and covered a sewage pipe under the Planika Bridge. If the rising water were to damage the pipe, it would pose a threat to 25,000 residents of Kranj connected to the sewage system, as well as other parts of Slovenia. The Municipality of Kranj has therefore begun preparations to obtain construction documentation for building a new bridge.

On Saturday, October 28, 2023, Prime Minister Robert Golob visited Baška grapa and its surroundings. Together with the mayor of Tolmin, Alen Červ, the commander of civil protection, Srečko Šestan, and the head of post-flood reconstruction, Boštjan Šefic, he inspected the consequences of the storm. During the visit, the Prime Minister expressed gratitude to firefighters, civil protection, and the police, and in a statement to the media, emphasized the necessity of establishing systemic foundations for responding to natural disasters.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Goni, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Jolina, or Typhoon No. 6 in 2009 in Vietnam. The typhoon's developments surprised many meteorologists.

At the end of July 25, the JTWC reported that a convective area had formed in a monsoon trough approximately 815 km (506 miles) northeast of Guam. Deep convection was erupting around the low-level circulation center. An upper-level storm and a tropical upper tropospheric trough were providing outflow. Over the next few days, the disturbance gradually developed before being declared dissipated early on July 28 as the low-level circulation center became poorly defined and higher vertical wind shear affected the system. However, the disturbance was regenerated early on July 30 while located about 630 km (390 miles) away, with the low-level circulation center of the disturbance elongated and showing signs of multiple circulation centers. Later that day, PAGASA reported that the disturbance had developed into a tropical depression and assigned it the local name Jolina. Jolina then further intensified early the next day and was reported to have become a tropical storm by PAGASA, with the JMA designating it as a depression later that day. Early on August 1, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert as deep convection increased and began consolidating around a circulation center. However, later that morning, Jolina made landfall near Casiguran, in the province of Aurora in the Philippines, before emerging into the South China Sea later that day. Early the next day, the JTWC reissued their TCFA while PAGASA issued their final warning on Jolina as it exited their area of responsibility heading towards a landfall in China. Subsequently, the JTWC designated the depression as 08W that day as infrared imagery showed deep convection being drawn into the low-level circulation center. On August 3, the JMA reported that the tropical depression had intensified into a tropical storm and assigned the name Goni to the storm. At 1700 UTC on August 4, Goni made its second landfall in Macau. Early the next day, the JTWC issued their final warning on Goni. On August 7, the JTWC noted that the remnants of Goni had re-entered the Gulf of Tonkin and had a low chance of regeneration. Later that day, the JTWC reissued advisories on the system, upgrading it to a tropical storm near Hainan Island.

When near the Philippines, it affected 38,589 families or 160,038 people in 119 villages in 25 towns and five cities in Ilocos Sur, Batangas, Cagayan, Nueva Ecija, Rizal, Occidental Mindoro, Palawan, Iloilo, Negros Occidental, Lanao del Sur, and Sultan Kudarat town in Maguindanao. Three people died and five went missing.
In Hainan province, approximately 92,000 people have been evacuated by authorities, 575 houses were destroyed, and 2,311 houses were damaged.

Whole_Text.content: The extreme weather Ingunn was an extreme weather event that hit the northern parts of Vestland, Møre og Romsdal, Trøndelag, Nordland, Troms, and Finnmark from January 31 to February 1, 2024. Nordøyan Lighthouse recorded a highest average wind speed of 41.4 m/s, which was higher than during the New Year's hurricane, with the highest gusts at 51.5 m/s. On Kvaløyfjellet in Sømna municipality, an average wind speed of 54.4 m/s was measured, which was the strongest average wind speed recorded in Norway. The Norwegian Natural Perils Pool reported damages of up to 500 million kroner to houses, buildings, and contents.

Storm Rolf was a storm depression that hit Denmark on the night of Friday, February 23, 2024. The storm had hurricane-force gusts and was a national class 2 storm on the Storm List. On Friday morning at 7 a.m., it was located over Skagerrak, where the last but strongest gusts blew over North Jutland. Stenhøj in Vendsyssel was hit by a gust of 37.6 m/s, which was the highest wind speed the storm reached.

July 13–14, 2024, a hurricane struck the territory of the Republic of Belarus. The Gomel region suffered the most. About 2,000 settlements across the country were left without electricity. 7 people died.

In the second week of July, abnormally hot weather settled in Belarus. On Wednesday, the 10th, an orange level of threat was announced. Temperatures of up to +32°C were observed in the southern part, and +24—29°C in the rest of the country. No precipitation. The hottest day was Saturday, July 13, when the air in the south and center of the country warmed above 35°C (a red danger level was announced, with expected heat of +35—37°C). A record high of +37.9°C since 1959 was recorded at the meteorological station in Zhitkovichi. In Minsk, the 1936 record was broken with +35.2°C. During this time, meteorologists began warning about the likelihood of powerful thunderstorms. Belhydromet issued a warning about approaching storm winds. Meteorologist Dmitry Rabov stated that in the coming decades, the climate will change, noting that waves of intense heat with hurricanes and storms will become more frequent in summer. A similar opinion was expressed by Vladimir Loginov, an academician of the National Academy of Sciences. The specialist said that in recent years, the climate in the country has increasingly resembled a tropical one, characterized by hurricanes and typhoons.

On July 13–14, 54 settlements in the Grodno region were affected in the Dyatlovo, Ivye, Korelichi, Novogrudok, Oshmyany, Slonim, and Smorgon districts. Roofs of 169 private residential houses, 29 agricultural buildings, and 8 cars were damaged. On July 14, in the Brest region, 296 buildings were damaged in 12 settlements, including 115 residential houses (11 destroyed). Winds of up to 25 m/s were recorded, and cases of hail the size of quail eggs were noted. There were 23 reported cases of fallen trees, 459 transformer substations were de-energized, and electricity supply was disrupted in 37 settlements. The Luninyets and Pinsk districts were the most affected. On the same day, heavy rains with squally winds swept through the Gomel region. The hurricane felled a large number of trees, many of which fell on power lines, leading to widespread outages. Access to power grids was hindered by the large number of fallen trees and branches. The most difficult situation was in the Mozyr, Kalinkovichi, Rechitsa, and Gomel districts. Only a few stores equipped with their own generators were operational in the cities. Water supply and communication were also completely absent. Wind gusts reached 29 meters per second. The situation was worsened by heat exceeding +30°C. Technological disruptions in power grids were recorded over a stretch of more than 12.5 thousand km, leaving 1,175 settlements in the Gomel region without electricity. Six people, including two children, died from fallen trees and roof elements. About 700 road signs were blown away by the wind. In the Mogilev region, about 800 buildings were affected, more than 600 settlements were left without power, 5.5 thousand hectares of forest were destroyed, and 384 trees were reported to have fallen. In the Mogilev district, a five-year-old girl died from a fallen tree. Power outages were observed in the Klichev, Krasnopolye, Krichev, Bobruisk, Mogilev, Kostyukovichi, Osipovichi, and Slavgorod districts. Additionally, three fires occurred due to lightning strikes (barns in the Mogilev and Slavgorod districts, and a residential house in the Chausy district). In the Vitebsk region, the disaster most affected the Polotsk and Ushachi districts. Twenty residential houses were damaged, and 53 cases of fallen trees were recorded. In one case, a resident of Ushachi was injured. Power lines were damaged in the Glubokoye, Dokshitsy, Miory, Polotsk, Ushachi, and Verkhnyadzvinsk districts. According to updated data from rescue services as of July 23, 2,654 settlements in 44 districts of the republic were affected by the natural disaster (Brest region – 33, Gomel – 2,272, Grodno – 54, and Mogilev – 295). Roofs of 6,210 residential houses (3,883 restored), 302 social and cultural facilities (190 restored), 2,053 agricultural buildings (332 restored), 18 industrial buildings (3 restored), and 605 utility structures (65 restored) were damaged. According to Belarusian Railways, fallen trees caused delays to 46 trains in the Gomel and Mogilev regions, with delays ranging from 6 minutes to almost 8 hours.

President of Belarus Alexander Lukashenko took personal control over the elimination of the consequences of the disaster. Emergency teams from other regions were sent to the southeastern region, which suffered the most. An operational headquarters was formed. Energy workers, employees of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, and the Ministry of Forestry began eliminating the consequences of the hurricane immediately after it ended. In total, about 1,500 people and 276 units of equipment were involved in the region, including 474 individuals with criminal records and 100 servicemen from the 6th Separate Special Police Brigade. Local residents took the initiative to help clear debris and fallen trees, assisting utility workers. Energy Minister Viktor Karankevich reported at a conference call that, as of July 19, electricity supply in the Gomel region was restored in terms of power delivery to all settlements, but in 170 of them, this was achieved through the use of diesel generator installations. According to preliminary data, it will take up to a month to fully restore the power grids. In some villages, the networks had to be rebuilt from scratch, as the storm had almost completely destroyed them. Electricity was finally restored on July 26 at 22:40, when the village of Lozki in the Kalinkovichi district, the last affected settlement, was disconnected from the mobile diesel generator and connected to the main grid.

At the end of the month, the hurricane repeated. Wind gusts reached 25–27 m/s. Five cars were damaged by fallen trees in Grodno and Minsk. According to the Ministry of Energy, as of the morning of July 29, 566 settlements were left without electricity within a day, and 91 cases of tree falls were recorded. To eliminate the consequences of the bad weather, 246 people and 105 units of equipment were involved. The country's energy and emergency services switched to an enhanced work mode. On July 29 and 30, an orange level of danger was declared in the country due to strong winds. According to updated data from the Ministry of Emergency Situations, 316 cases of tree falls were recorded on July 28–29: in the Brest region — 29, Vitebsk — 7, Gomel — 15, Grodno — 137, Minsk — 58, Mogilev — 18, Minsk city — 52. Fifteen cars were damaged by fallen trees. Of these, one vehicle in the Gomel region, four in the Grodno region, two in the Mogilev region, and eight in Minsk. In the Grodno region, a passenger train was delayed for 47 minutes due to a fallen tree. Two people were injured (in the village of Yaremichi in the Korelichi district and in the city of Bobruisk in the Mogilev region). Earlier, meteorologist Dmitry Rabov warned of cooling, wind, and rain in Belarus during the week of July 29 to August 4. The weather was influenced by northwestern winds and cooler air masses. Accordingly, the temperature dropped. Fluctuations in atmospheric pressure were noted.

Lukashenko criticized the behavior of officials at various levels. According to the president, there were not enough active measures on their part to organize work on eliminating the consequences, providing prompt assistance to affected regions and people. Proper interaction between different bodies in taking emergency response measures was not established everywhere, and sometimes, instead of prompt actions, tenders were announced to find contractors for repair work and eliminating the consequences of the disaster. The procedure for receiving assistance from the reserve of material resources was also criticized. Alexander Lukashenko stated the need to mobilize the population and specialists to eliminate the consequences of the disaster, including political prisoners. He compared the disaster to a war, "only without shooting from rifles and machine guns." On July 20, the Minister for Emergency Situations, Vadim Sinyavsky, arrived in the Gomel region. During his visit, the official stated, "We lost because we did not expect such a destructive hurricane." According to the minister, the services "got carried away with preventive work. People received 'another message from the Ministry of Emergency Situations' about some storm, some wind, and considered it unserious." Additionally, Sinyavsky expressed dissatisfaction with the work on restoring electricity supply, as well as the communication of information about the progress of its restoration.

Whole_Text.header: Storm in São Paulo on October 11, 2024
Whole_Text.content: The storm in São Paulo on October 11, 2024, refers to several extreme weather events that affected various cities in the state during the afternoon and evening of that day. It was characterized by intense winds and large hail, as well as widespread power outages in the capital city of São Paulo. According to the state Civil Defense, at least 98 municipalities in the state recorded strong winds during the event. In total, eight people died in different cities. Winds that day reached a peak of 107.6 km/h in the Interlagos region, in the southern zone of São Paulo, during the night, the highest value ever recorded in the city since measurements began in 1995. The combination of strong winds and heavy rains caused destruction and a blackout in much of the São Paulo Metropolitan Region (RMSP), affecting 2.1 million customers. By October 14, the total damage had already reached R$ 1.65 billion solely in relation to the blackout. In Presidente Prudente, there was large hail on the same day, during the afternoon. According to MetSul Meteorologia, the phenomenon that hit Greater São Paulo had characteristics of a bow echo. The company estimated that winds in the southern zone of the capital could have reached 120 km/h. A similar event was identified by the IPMet/UNESP radar in the Piracicaba Metropolitan Region (RMP) at 7 p.m.

The Lyly storm was a small and powerful low-pressure system that moved over Western and Southern Finland in the evening and night of November 1–2, 2024. The first hurricane in Finnish measurement history was observed in Finnish sea areas when a 10-minute average wind speed of 33.5 m/s was recorded at Rauma's Kylmäpihlaja.[1] The strongest gust on land, 26.1 m/s, was measured at Pori railway station.[2] At its peak, over 40,000 customers were simultaneously without electricity.[3] The storm damage was relatively confined to a small area near the coast in Satakunta and Southwest Finland, but it was locally significant. The power grid was severely damaged in Eurajoki and parts of Rauma, where a total of about 900 customers were still without electricity three days after the storm.[4][5] Two power line pylons of the high-voltage transmission grid in Eurajoki also fell due to the wind's force.[6] Altogether, the Satakunta Rescue Department handled nearly 500 storm-related tasks.[7] In Southwest Finland, the corresponding number was over 250.[8] The intensity of the Lyly storm could not be accurately predicted. The storm was caused by a low-pressure system formed in a strong jet stream area and unusually warm seawater, which enabled a thick mixing layer of air and thus allowed winds strengthened by the jet stream to reach the ground.[9]

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Dianmu (English: Severe Tropical Storm Dianmu; Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Ester; International designation: 1004; JTWC: WP052010) was the fourth tropical cyclone to form in the 2010 Pacific typhoon season. Dianmu is the 100th name on the tropical cyclone name list, provided by China, meaning "Mother of Lightning," responsible for overseeing thunder and lightning.

Tropical disturbance 96W formed on August 2 near 8°00′N 136°00′E / 8.0°N 136.0°E / 8.0; 136.0 [3], initially moving northwest under the easterly flow brought by the subtropical ridge to the north. In a generally unfavorable atmospheric environment, it initially lacked organization and developed slowly. After several days of slow development, it intensified into a tropical depression within the monsoon trough on August 6. The tropical depression gradually strengthened in a favorable environment, becoming a tropical storm on August 8 and was named Khanun by the Japan Meteorological Agency. Khanun turned northward under the influence of the southerly flow brought by the subtropical ridge to the east. At this time, Khanun was still within the monsoon trough, with vigorous convection and good spiral structure, but concentrated in the eastern part, with the low-level circulation center partially exposed. Khanun intensified into a severe tropical storm at noon on August 9, with its structure further consolidating in the afternoon as the low-level circulation center developed under the convection and began forming an eye. Khanun reached its peak intensity on August 10, with maximum sustained winds near its center reaching 95 km/h and maximum gusts of 130 km/h. 

On the evening of August 10, Khanun moved to the northwest of the subtropical ridge, turning northeast, passing about 10 km west of Jeju Island [4], and crossing southern South Korea the next morning. At this time, Khanun began to weaken due to strong vertical wind shear and the terrain of South Korea, with convection starting to dissipate and shift eastward, exposing the low-level circulation center. Khanun made landfall in Busan at noon, passing about 15 km northwest of the city [5]. Later that afternoon, Khanun entered the Sea of Japan. Affected by low sea surface temperatures and strong vertical wind shear, Khanun weakened into a tropical storm early on August 12 and crossed Japan that afternoon, eventually transitioning into an extratropical cyclone early the next day [6].

Due to the astronomical high tide, areas along the Zhejiang coast such as Aojiang, Zhenhai, and Zhapu will experience tide levels close to or slightly exceeding the warning line. Therefore, authorities have issued a yellow storm surge warning and advised preparations for wind protection.

Affected by Typhoon Khanun, the wind in Naha began to strengthen on August 8. According to local airport meteorological data, strong southeast winds persisted starting the morning of August 9, later shifting to south winds later in the morning, with brief periods of gale-force winds, followed by sustained strong winds throughout the day. The day was mostly cloudy with occasional heavy rain. As Typhoon Khanun moved away, the wind in Naha began to weaken on August 10, with strong winds subsiding in the morning and showers decreasing.

Typhoon Khanun passed over Jeju Island on the evening of August 10. During the passage of the eye, local winds temporarily calmed, and the sea level pressure dropped to 989 hPa. On August 11, Khanun also crossed the Korean Peninsula, becoming the first tropical cyclone to directly impact South Korea this year and the first since Typhoon Kalmaegi in 2008. As Khanun approached, the sea level pressure in Busan began to drop on August 10, decreasing from 1011 hPa in the morning to 1007 hPa in the evening. The southeast wind also began to strengthen in the evening, reaching gale force on August 11.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Kompasu (English: Tropical Storm Kompasu, International Number: 0409, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 12W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Julian) was the 9th named tropical cyclone of the 2004 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kompasu" was provided by Japan, meaning the constellation Compass.

Kompas developed into a tropical depression approximately 620 kilometers southeast of Kaohsiung early on July 14. It strengthened into a tropical storm that afternoon and moved westward, crossing the Luzon Strait. After entering the South China Sea, Kompas generally took a northwest path toward the Guangdong coast. On July 16, Kompas turned to move northwest by north and made landfall in Sai Kung, Hong Kong, with maximum sustained winds near the center at 23 meters per second (approximately 85 kilometers per hour) and a minimum central pressure of 992 hPa. It weakened into a tropical depression that evening and then dissipated inland in Guangdong.
The highest typhoon signal issued locally: Typhoon warning for sea and land.

The Hong Kong Observatory issued the Standby Signal No. 1 at 10:55 pm on July 14, when Kompasu was located about 720 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. Due to the subsiding air currents of Kompasu, the weather was dry and very hot from July 14 to 15. As Kompasu approached, the Observatory issued the Strong Wind Signal No. 3 at 5:15 am on July 16, when Kompasu was about 170 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. At 5:20 am, the Observatory stated that it would consider issuing the Gale or Storm Signal No. 8 between the morning and noon. At 7:55 am, the Observatory further stated that Kompasu would come very close to Hong Kong, making the issuance of Signal No. 8 highly likely, and Kompasu's spiral rainbands began bringing showers to Hong Kong. Winds at Waglan Island gradually strengthened to gale force in the morning, and the Observatory issued a "Special Announcement on Tropical Cyclone" at 9:45 am, announcing that Signal No. 8 was expected to be issued by 11:45 am or earlier, when Kompasu was about 80 kilometers southeast of the Observatory. At 11:45 am, the Observatory issued the Northeast Gale or Storm Signal No. 8, when Kompasu was about 60 kilometers southeast of the Observatory, and subsequently changed to the Northwest Gale or Storm Signal No. 8 at 2:45 pm. Around 3:00 pm on July 16, Kompasu made landfall in Sai Kung. At the same time, it was closest to the Observatory headquarters, located about 25 kilometers east of the headquarters. After landfall, Kompasu moved across the northeastern New Territories. The Observatory changed to the Southwest Gale or Storm Signal No. 8 at 4:45 pm, when Kompasu was about 30 kilometers north of the Observatory. As Kompasu began to move away from Hong Kong and weakened into a tropical depression, winds within the territory gradually subsided, and the Observatory changed to the Strong Wind Signal No. 3 at 7:20 pm on July 16, when Kompasu was about 55 kilometers north of the Observatory. Subsequently, all tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 8:20 pm.

During Kompasu's closest approach to Hong Kong on the afternoon of July 16, strong winds were generally experienced within the territory, with gales over offshore waters and on high ground. The highest hourly mean wind speed recorded at Tap Mun was 47 kilometers per hour, with the highest gust reaching 79 kilometers per hour. Waglan Island recorded the highest hourly mean wind speed of 88 kilometers per hour, with the highest gust reaching 106 kilometers per hour. The minimum instantaneous sea-level pressures recorded at the Observatory headquarters, Waglan Island, and Ta Kwu Ling were 1,000.5 hPa, 995.7 hPa, and 1,001.0 hPa, respectively. Kompasu's rainbands and remnants brought heavy squally showers to Hong Kong on the afternoon of July 16 and the following day. The Observatory issued the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal twice, from 5:00 pm to 6:50 pm on July 16 and from 2:20 am to 3:30 am on July 17. The Observatory headquarters recorded over 120 millimeters of rainfall in total.

Additionally, during Kompasu's impact on Hong Kong, 12 people were injured, including two who were struck by falling objects in Tsuen Wan and North Point. The Leisure and Cultural Services Department received 19 emergency assistance requests for trees blown down by strong winds, blocking roads or posing dangers, with 4 cases on Hong Kong Island, 6 in Kowloon, and 9 in the New Territories. There was one minor flooding incident on Lockhart Road in Wan Chai, and no reports of landslides across the territory. The Home Affairs Department opened 25 temporary shelters, accommodating a total of 276 residents. Regarding maritime transport, most ferry services within the harbor and to outlying islands were suspended at one point. For land transport, the MTR, East Rail, West Rail, and Light Rail maintained limited services (the railway company was then known as KCR, now MTR), and public transport services gradually returned to normal in the evening.

The Observatory issued a "Special Announcement on Tropical Cyclone" at 9:45 am on July 16 and issued Signal No. 8 at 11:45 am. Many citizens only learned about the issuance of Signal No. 8 while commuting to work or after arriving at their workplaces (some had already been working for one or two hours), prompting them to rush home. Some citizens questioned why the Observatory could not issue Signal No. 8 earlier, before the start of work and school hours. Since Kompasu was only a tropical storm with a small circulation structure, its gale radius was only about 60 kilometers, and its strong wind radius was only about 150 kilometers. Therefore, slight changes in its path could significantly affect the wind conditions in Hong Kong. If Kompasu's path had shifted, making landfall east of Hong Kong along the eastern Guangdong coast instead of in Hong Kong, it might not have been necessary to issue Signal No. 8. As a result, the Observatory could only state that the chance of issuing Signal No. 8 was high without specifying the exact time. At 9:00 am on July 16, when Kompasu was about 100 kilometers east-southeast of the Observatory headquarters, winds in Hong Kong only reached moderate to fresh levels (not meeting the lower limit of Signal No. 3). Therefore, the earliest the Observatory could issue a Signal No. 8 alert was at 9:45 am. During the period when Signal No. 8 was in effect, only offshore waters and high ground experienced gale-force winds. After Kompasu weakened into a tropical depression, Signal No. 3 was issued at 7:20 pm on the same day.

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 2:25 a.m. on July 15, when Kompasu was located about 700 kilometers east-southeast of Macau. As Kompasu approached, the Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau upgraded to Typhoon Signal No. 3 at 11:30 a.m. on July 16, when Kompasu was about 110 kilometers east-southeast of Macau. By 1 p.m., Kompasu was centered 100 kilometers east of Macau, moving northwest at a speed of about 20 kilometers per hour, gradually approaching Macau. The wind intensified, and the Meteorological Bureau announced that there was a high chance of hoisting Typhoon Signal No. 8 based on the typhoon's trajectory. While residents were generally expecting Kompasu to bring Typhoon Signal No. 8 to Macau, Kompasu, true to its name, abruptly changed its course by 90 degrees, heading directly toward Hong Kong. It made landfall at the High Island Reservoir in Sai Kung at 3 p.m. After changing its course, Kompasu's impact upon landfall posed no threat to Macau and moved inland into Guangdong. At 4 p.m. on the same day, Kompasu was closest to Macau, located about 95 kilometers northeast of the city. As Kompasu weakened and moved away, the Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau lowered all signals at 9 p.m. on July 16. Kompasu was the only tropical cyclone in 2004 to prompt the hoisting of tropical cyclone signals in Macau.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴玉兔 (2001年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Yutu (English: Severe Tropical Storm Yutu, International Number: 0107, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 10W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Huaning) was the seventh named storm of the 2001 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Yutu" was provided by China, referring to the Jade Rabbit on the moon. Chang'e, the wife of the legendary tribal leader Houyi, stole her husband's elixir of immortality and fled to the moon with the Jade Rabbit. It is said that they still reside in the Moon Palace.

At 18:00 UTC on July 22, a tropical depression formed over the northeastern waters of Luzon Island. The tropical depression moved west-northwest. At 18:00 UTC on July 23, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm over the northwestern waters of Luzon Island and was named "Yutu." At 06:00 UTC on July 24, Yutu intensified into a severe tropical storm over the southeastern waters of Hong Kong. At 00:00 UTC on July 25, Yutu reached its peak over the southern waters of Hong Kong. Yutu had a compact circulation with an eye diameter of approximately 60 kilometers. Shortly afterward, Yutu made landfall near Bohe Town, Dianbai County, Maoming City, Guangdong Province. At 18:00 UTC, Yutu weakened into a tropical storm. Yutu turned westward. At 00:00 UTC on July 26, Yutu weakened into a tropical depression in southern China. By 12:00 UTC, it had completely dissipated. [1]
At 8:10 PM on July 23, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning. At 5:20 PM on July 24, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the sea typhoon warning.

Affected by Typhoon Rusa, approximately 4,650 houses were destroyed in Guangdong Province, with cities such as Maoming, Yangjiang, and Zhanjiang within the province estimated to have suffered a total loss of 700 million yuan.

Typhoon Utor was the second typhoon in July 2001 that required the issuance of the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal. This was the first time since 1966 that two No. 8 signals were issued in July. On July 23, a tropical depression formed about 600 kilometers northeast of Manila, Philippines, moving west-northwest at a speed of 25 kilometers per hour. By midday, it entered the Luzon Strait and strengthened into a tropical storm that evening, named "Utor." After entering the South China Sea, Utor shifted westward and strengthened into a severe tropical storm before noon on July 24, and further intensified into a typhoon within a few hours. Utor had a compact circulation with an eye diameter of about 60 kilometers. 

On July 25, Utor moved west-northwest, approaching the western coast of Guangdong. Early on July 26, Utor weakened into a severe tropical storm and made landfall near Zhanjiang around 5 a.m. It further weakened into a tropical storm in the afternoon and moved inland, eventually dissipating into a low-pressure area that evening.

In Hong Kong, the Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9:50 p.m. on July 23, when Utor was about 720 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. On July 24, as Utor continued to approach, its outer rainbands brought heavy showers and thunderstorms to Hong Kong in the afternoon, prompting the Observatory to issue the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 3:50 p.m. That evening, local winds strengthened significantly, with offshore areas experiencing strong winds. 

In the hours before midnight, Utor's central wind speed rapidly increased from 120 kilometers per hour to 148 kilometers per hour, with a gale radius of about 160 kilometers. At 12:30 a.m. on July 25, the Observatory issued the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal. By early morning, offshore and highland areas experienced gale-force winds, and the wind direction shifted from northeast to southeast. At 10:40 a.m., the Observatory issued the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, marking the last time the No. 8 signal was issued in this manner. Utor was closest to Hong Kong at noon, located about 180 kilometers south-southwest of the city. That day, gale-force winds were recorded in southern waters and highland areas of Hong Kong. Under Utor's influence, Cheung Chau recorded a maximum hourly mean wind speed of 68 kilometers per hour and a maximum gust of 115 kilometers per hour. Tai Mo Shan recorded a maximum hourly mean wind speed of 79 kilometers per hour and a maximum gust of 112 kilometers per hour. Torrential rain associated with Utor brought over 60 millimeters of rainfall to areas near Tsuen Wan, while most parts of Hong Kong recorded over 20 millimeters of rainfall. At 7:40 p.m. that evening, the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal was reissued.

During Utor's impact, 10 people in Hong Kong were injured in various accidents, and there were 11 reports of fallen trees. On Lower Albert Road, a six-meter-tall tree was blown down, temporarily disrupting traffic. Two trees were also blown down on Observatory Road in Tsim Sha Tsui, crushing a car and the canopy of a hotel. There were two incidents of scaffolding collapse in Yau Tong and Kwai Chung. Additionally, over 160 people sought refuge in temporary shelters across the city. During the period when the No. 8 signal was in effect, about 30 flights were canceled, and over 150 flights were delayed.

The Observatory hoisted the No. 8 signal on Wednesday, July 25, for a duration of 19 hours and 10 minutes, overlapping completely with mainstream working hours and the operation times of the commercial stock market. Since it was a regular working day (Monday to Saturday), most citizens received a day off. However, due to Typhoon Yutu's relatively small circulation (a gale radius of only 160 kilometers) and a path that was further south than expected (initially predicted to pass about 150 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong, but ultimately passing about 180 kilometers southwest-southwest of Hong Kong), Yutu only brought gales to the southern waters and highlands of Hong Kong. The impact on Hong Kong's urban areas was significantly less than the traditional impression of No. 8 signal wind strength. Urban weather stations such as Sai Kung, the airport, Tsing Yi, and the Kowloon Star Ferry Pier recorded maximum hourly average wind speeds of 49, 44, 43, and 41 kilometers per hour, respectively, which were still some distance from the gale threshold of 63 kilometers per hour. Moreover, Macau, which was closer to Yutu than Hong Kong, only hoisted the No. 3 signal. Authorities in other nearby cities (such as Shenzhen and Zhuhai) also did not issue similarly severe warnings to the public.

As a result, the business sector, led by then Liberal Party Chairman James Tien and then Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce CEO Eden Woon, criticized the Observatory for mistakenly hoisting the No. 8 signal under weather conditions that were not particularly severe. This caused most industries and the stock market to halt operations unnecessarily that day, reducing business profits and resulting in significant economic losses (estimated at HK$3 billion to HK$4 billion). Even then-Chief Secretary for Administration Donald Tsang (later Chief Executive) joined the criticism, stating that caution should be exercised in hoisting typhoon signals in the future. 

Following this incident, the Observatory, to avoid further criticism from the business sector, gradually adopted a more conservative approach to hoisting/issuing signals, basing decisions solely on wind strength within Victoria Harbour. However, the Observatory overlooked the fact that wind strength in the harbor was already shielded by buildings, resulting in lower wind readings compared to other exposed urban weather stations. For example, during Severe Tropical Storm Vongfong in 2002, the Observatory decided at 4 p.m. on August 19 that Vongfong had almost reached its closest point to Hong Kong, passing about 400 kilometers southwest of the city, and refused to issue the No. 3 strong wind signal as winds in the harbor had not reached strong wind levels. However, by around 8 p.m. that evening, Vongfong reached its closest point to Hong Kong, located about 390 kilometers west-southwest of the city, and made landfall near Zhanjiang. At 7 p.m., Kai Tak recorded an hourly average wind speed of 41 kilometers per hour, reaching strong wind levels, while the Kowloon Star Ferry Pier recorded an hourly average wind speed of 40 kilometers per hour at 1 a.m. on August 20, just shy of strong wind levels. Despite strong winds being recorded in the harbor, the Observatory did not mention this in its tropical cyclone warning, only stating that strong winds were affecting offshore and highland areas in the southwest of Hong Kong. The Observatory's increasingly conservative approach to hoisting/issuing signals indirectly contributed to the Prapiroon incident in 2006.

At 2 a.m. on July 23, a tropical depression formed northeast of Luzon and quickly moved westward at a speed of 38 kilometers per hour, heading directly toward the South China Sea. By 8 p.m. on the same day, it strengthened into a tropical storm while crossing the Balintang Channel (approximately at 20.1°N, 121.0°E), with a central pressure of 995 hPa and maximum wind speeds near the center of 65 kilometers per hour. It then steadily moved westward, and by 2 p.m. on July 24, it strengthened into a severe tropical storm in the South China Sea, 400 kilometers southeast of Macau (approximately at 20.5°N, 117.0°E), with a central pressure of 978 hPa and maximum wind speeds near the center of 112 kilometers per hour. Three hours later, it rapidly intensified into a typhoon near Dongsha, with a central pressure dropping to 960 hPa and maximum wind speeds near the center reaching 150 kilometers per hour. Between 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. on July 25, Typhoon "Yutu" passed closest to Macau, about 160 kilometers south to southwest of the city. It then slightly shifted to a west-northwest direction, heading toward the Leizhou Peninsula. At 2 a.m. on July 26, it weakened into a severe tropical storm over the sea west of Macau (approximately at 21.3°N, 111.3°E). Two hours later, it made landfall along the southern coast of China between Yangjiang and Zhanjiang. "Yutu" turned northwestward inland in China and gradually dissipated, weakening into a tropical storm at 11 a.m. on July 26 and further into a tropical depression by 5 p.m. During its impact on Macau, there were minor damages such as fallen trees and signboards, as well as flooding in low-lying areas.

Article_Name: 颱風愛茜 (1975年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Elsie (International designation: 7515, China designation: 7514, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 17W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Mameng) was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 1975 Pacific typhoon season and one of the few typhoons to directly hit Hong Kong in October.

On October 9, 1975, a tropical depression formed approximately 740 kilometers southwest of Guam, moving west-northwest, and strengthened into a severe tropical storm on October 10, named Elsie. On October 11, Elsie intensified into a typhoon and underwent explosive intensification within the next day, with its central pressure dropping by 69 hPa to 898 hPa in 24 hours, and its central wind speed increasing to about 240 kilometers per hour. Subsequently, Elsie crossed the Bashi Channel into the South China Sea. Its intensity weakened slightly, with maximum wind speeds of about 205 kilometers per hour and a circulation diameter of 555 kilometers. After entering the South China Sea, Elsie was guided by the westward-extending subtropical ridge, shifting to a more westerly direction and crossing the northern part of the South China Sea.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 Standby Signal at 10:45 PM on October 12, as Typhoon Elsie was centered about 740 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong, moving northwest at a speed of about 14 kilometers per hour towards the northeastern part of the South China Sea. After crossing the Bashi Channel, Elsie took a more westerly path. The Observatory replaced the Standby Signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 8:00 PM on October 13, when Elsie was centered about 350 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. Although Hong Kong was experiencing only light to moderate westerly winds at the time, Elsie was still expected to be intense and might pass close to Hong Kong, prompting the Observatory to warn residents to complete wind protection measures. At 4:30 AM on October 14, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 8 Northwest Gale or Storm Signal, as Elsie was centered about 190 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. At that time, Hong Kong experienced moderate to fresh northwesterly winds. As Elsie approached during the day, wind strength in Hong Kong increased rapidly, with gale-force winds recorded starting at 9:00 AM, when Elsie was centered about 130 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. Elsie remained well-organized and continued moving westward. At 11:00 AM, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 9 Gale or Storm Increasing Signal, indicating that wind strength in Hong Kong would significantly increase, as Elsie was centered about 70 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. By early afternoon, with clear signs that the eye of the storm would pass over the southern part of Hong Kong Island and its waters, the Observatory hoisted the No. 10 Hurricane Signal at 2:15 PM, with hurricane-force winds recorded offshore and in high-altitude areas. Elsie came closest to Hong Kong at 2:30 PM, centered about 50 kilometers south of the Observatory, moving westward at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour. During the afternoon, Tai Mo Shan recorded wind speeds of 130 kilometers per hour, with maximum gusts of 180 kilometers per hour, while Stanley recorded wind speeds of 141 kilometers per hour, with maximum gusts of 219 kilometers per hour. The instantaneous sea-level pressure at the Observatory headquarters dropped to a minimum of 996.2 hPa after 3:00 PM and quickly rose after the typhoon passed. 

Elsie began to weaken after passing south of Hong Kong. As Elsie moved away, Hong Kong experienced easterly winds in the late afternoon, and wind strength began to moderate. At 5:05 PM, the Observatory replaced the No. 10 Hurricane Signal with the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, as Elsie was centered about 50 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. Later, at 8:10 PM, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal, as Elsie was centered about 70 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. On the evening of October 14, Elsie resumed a west-northwest path and further weakened into a tropical storm. After 10:00 PM, it crossed the coast of southern China about 110 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong. Wind strength in Hong Kong continued to weaken, and all signals were canceled at 2:00 AM on October 15, as the storm was centered about 150 kilometers west of Hong Kong. With a cool northeast monsoon beginning to affect the southern China coast, Elsie weakened into a tropical depression within the next hour and eventually dissipated inland about 190 kilometers west of Hong Kong by early morning.

Before Elsie's approach, Hong Kong experienced sunny and hot weather on October 12 and 13. On the morning of October 14, the weather turned cloudy with scattered showers, and rain became more frequent and accompanied by strong winds during the day. As Elsie moved closer to Hong Kong, heavy rain began in the early afternoon. The heaviest rain occurred between noon and 2:00 PM as Elsie passed south of Hong Kong. As Elsie moved away, rain weakened slightly later in the afternoon. On October 15, the weather remained overcast with light rain and occasional squally showers. Due to the influence of the easterly wind surge, the weather did not improve significantly the following day.

Under the influence of Elsie, five ocean-going vessels in Hong Kong dragged their anchors, and 46 people were injured on land due to debris and collapsed scaffolding, but there were no fatalities. Over 1,000 people sought refuge in storm shelters.

After passing south of Hong Kong, Nesat continued to move almost due west and weakened into a severe tropical storm. On the night of October 14, when it was closest to Macau, it was only 28 kilometers south of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters. The Meteorological Bureau hoisted the No. 9 signal for the third consecutive year. Macau recorded a rainfall of 91.8 millimeters that day. During its impact on Macau, it caused minor property damage but no casualties.

Article_Name: 颱風雪麗 (1968年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Shirley (English: Typhoon Shirley, International Number: 6809, Mainland China Number: 6808, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 13W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Huaning) is a tropical cyclone that appeared in the Northwest Pacific. It is one of the few typhoons whose eye directly swept through the urban area of Hong Kong, and it is the first tropical cyclone since Typhoon Alice in 1961 to directly pass over the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters and trigger the issuance of the No. 10 typhoon signal.

On August 17, 1968, a tropical depression formed approximately 1,200 kilometers east of Manila, moving westward. At 6:03 AM on August 18 (Hong Kong time), a reconnaissance aircraft reported a sea-level pressure of 991 hPa near the eye, and the tropical cyclone was named Shirley. After forming, Shirley moved west-northwest, heading directly toward the northern part of Luzon Island in the Philippines. At that time, Shirley's diameter was approximately 580 kilometers. On the morning of August 19 (Hong Kong time), a reconnaissance aircraft recorded a sea-level pressure of 962 hPa near the eye, and Shirley officially intensified into a severe tropical storm. At 3 PM that afternoon, a weather station on Luzon Island, located 120 kilometers west of the eye, recorded a wind speed of 74 kilometers per hour.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 6:10 am on August 20, when Shirley was located about 650 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. As Shirley continued to approach, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 3 signal at 6:15 pm. Shirley changed direction to move northwest towards Hong Kong in the early morning of August 21, and the Observatory replaced the No. 3 signal with the No. 7 signal at 7:00 am, when the storm was about 280 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. Shirley intensified into a typhoon in the afternoon. Due to its strengthening circulation, the Observatory replaced the No. 7 signal with the No. 9 signal at 2:40 pm, indicating stronger gale-force winds. When it was confirmed that the eye of the storm would pass over Hong Kong, the Observatory replaced the No. 9 signal with the No. 10 signal at 4:10 pm, when Shirley was about 80 kilometers southeast of the Observatory. Shirley's eye passed over the Observatory between 7:00 pm and 9:30 pm, during which Hong Kong experienced a sharp drop in wind speed, with light winds prevailing and calm conditions lasting for about two hours, though it remained cloudy with rain. The typhoon appeared to weaken slightly. The Observatory recorded the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure of 968.7 hPa at 7:00 pm, the lowest on record for August. Shirley continued moving northwest at dusk, with most areas experiencing strong southerly winds starting at 10:00 pm. As Shirley weakened into a severe tropical storm at midnight, the Observatory replaced the No. 10 signal with the No. 6 signal at 11:45 pm, when the storm was about 90 kilometers northwest-north of the Observatory. As the winds gradually subsided, the Observatory replaced the No. 6 signal with the No. 3 signal at 5:25 am the next morning, when the storm was about 200 kilometers northwest of Hong Kong. Shirley significantly slowed down over Guangdong and finally weakened into a low-pressure area later in the morning. All signals were canceled at 12:10 pm. Shirley's passage over Hong Kong resulted in four injuries and caused a ship near the waters of Stonecutters Island to collide multiple times with another vessel.
Affected by Sherry, Macau recorded the highest hourly average wind speed of 74 kilometers per hour and the highest gust wind speed of 130 kilometers per hour.
